PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROUTINE OF BUSINESS AND GUIDELINES FOR MEMBERS' STATEMENTS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members will be aware, today is the first day of operation of the Sessional Orders agreed to by the House on 9 December last year. These orders provide for a new routine of business on Thursdays prior to 2 p.m. The new routine includes a set time for the presentation of, and debate on, the reports of parliamentary committees and delegations. It also provides significantly improved opportunities for private members to initiate debates on issues of concern to them. An entirely new feature of the proceedings of the House each Thursday is the 15-minute period during which members may make 90-second statements. In recommending the introduction of this procedure the Procedure Committee suggested that I should make a statement outlining certain guidelines for the conduct of this period. I do so now.

INTERJECT.PARA: I will be guided by the Clerks at the table to inform me when 90 seconds have elapsed for each statement. A stopwatch will be used for this purpose. I recognise that initially it will be difficult for members to know how much can be said in 90 seconds, but I will be looking for the cooperation of all members in ceasing their speech as soon as I call their attention to the fact that 90 seconds have elapsed. Sessional order 106a states that no Ministers may be called on during this period. The call will alternate between Opposition and Government members, as in Question Time, but the Opposition front bench will not receive precedence. I believe this is in accord with the spirit of the Procedure Committee's recommendations.

I also intend to allow a member to make up to three 90-second statements during each 15-minute period if no other member rises to receive the call. This is in line with the practice that operated for the giving of oral notices prior to 1985. The Standing Orders as they apply to debate and speech in the House will, of course, apply to these statements. The use of unparliamentary language and the making of personal attacks on those whose actions can be questioned only by way of substantive motion will be out of order. Members are reminded that they may give oral notices during this period. A written copy of any notice is required to be lodged with the Clerk at the conclusion of the statement.

Finally, I understand that this procedure has been popular and worked very well in the Canadian House of Commons. I urge members to make every effort to ensure that the potential of the procedure is realised in this House. The calling of quorums, the raising of specious points of order and other disruptive tactics will not be in accord with the spirit of the proposal and will not be looked upon with much favour. All the reforms the House is testing will be scrutinised closely by all members, not the least by front bench members on both sides. I commend the changes to honourable members and emphasise that the success or otherwise of the new arrangements will depend, in large measure, on private members themselves.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Jervis Bay National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

We, the undersigned concerned residents, visitors and holiday makers, call for the formation of Jervis Bay National Park. We support the inclusion of all Commonwealth controlled land on Bherwerre Peninsula, Beecroft Peninsula, and Bowen Island, in combination with suitable land around the perimeter of the Bay, to form a continuous National Park completely ringing Jervis Bay.
We support the proposal by the National Trust of Australia for the permanent protection of natural areas in the vicinity of Jervis Bay, as the minimum N.S.W. land needed for Jervis Bay National Park.
We support the inclusion of all Jervis Bay waters, and waters surrounding Bherwerre and Beecroft Peninsulas as part of Jervis Bay National Park.
We support the establishment of a Park management system based on the Uluru Model, and the establishment of a complimentary regional management plan for the Jervis Bay region.
We call for the Honourable House to implement Jervis Bay National Park to preserve this national heritage.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.

that we are totally opposed to the proposed closure of Holder Primary School in the Australian Capital Territory;
that such closure is a denial of our right to send our children to a traditional public school which is safely accessible to the children of Holder;
that our children's educational needs are being sacrificed in order to save money without other avenues being fully explored;

that the Holder Primary School buildings and grounds are more suited to the education of children and amalgamating with neighbouring schools than those neighbouring schools not threatened with closure;

PETITION.PARA: The tobacco industry wants kids.

Tobacco advertising is aimed at your kids by associating the things kids want-poise, friendship, sporting involvement, confidence, music and festivity, sexiness-with smoking.

Advertising is a legitimate part of business, but an industry that tries to get people addicted with a deadly drug, for profit purposes, should not be allowed the same right as a business with more benevolent aims.
To the Honourable the Speaker and members of Parliament assembled

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in presenting the Flags Amendment Bill 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: In presenting the Flags Amendment Bill I make it plain, on behalf of the Opposition, that the purpose of this Bill-and a Bill in similar form has been presented to the Senate-is to make it impossible for the present Australian flag to be changed without the approval of the Australian people at a referendum. In our view, that is a necessary protection for the Australian flag.

It is a flag which, I believe, draws the warmth, loyalty and affection of the overwhelming majority of Australians. It is very interesting that in recent years, when there has been debate about the form and style and content of our national flag, even those who a few years ago spoke in derisive terms of our flag and even those who a few years ago wanted to change the Australian flag now realise that the sentiment of the Australian community is overwhelmingly in favour of retaining the present Australian flag. No debate on this issue should be allowed to pass without it being pointed out that at all times both the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have strongly supported the retention of the present Australian flag.

Whilst I welcome the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) now says that he has no intention of trying to change the Australian flag and I welcome the fact that the Prime Minister has been dragged to an acceptance that the majority of Australians-including, I dare say, a majority of people who normally vote for the Australian Labor Party-want the present Australian flag retained, it is worth remembering that sentiment for the Australian flag was nowhere as strong a few years ago within the ranks of the Australian Labor Party. It is worth remembering that resolutions against the present Australian flag have been carried recently at national conferences of the Australian Labor Party. It is worth remembering, and many people will remember, the contemptible remarks made by the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) when back in 1981 he said:

. . . I think we can do rather better than the present undistinguished and indistinctive bit of cloth which we have inherited from our colonial past and which manifestly does not set anybody's pulse racing in the community at large expect, perhaps-
and this is the most contemptible reference of all-
the occasional Returned Services League blimp or a proportion of the tory back bench opposite.
Thus spoke the true feelings of the parliamentary ranks of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Senator Evans, the Minister for Transport and Communications. Thus spoke the true sentiments of the parliamentary ranks of the Australian Labor Party only a few years ago. The only thing that has changed that attitude is their realisation that hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians who habitually support the Australian Labor Party are as contemptuous of that comment by Senator Evans as are the members of the back bench of the Liberal Party and the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: We bring this Bill forward not because we do not believe there is overwhelming support for the retention of the present Australian flag, which in my view is a beautiful and provocative emblem and one of which all Australians can be proud, and not because we doubt that it has overwhelming support, but because we simply do not trust the present Government. We do not believe that at some stage the Government might not try to change it. What this Bill will do is something the overwhelming majority of the Australian public wants, that is, to put it beyond doubt that our present national flag, of which we on this side of the House are immensely proud, cannot be changed without an affirmative vote of the Australian people.
Bill read a first time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISTRIBUTION OF X-RATED VIDEOS IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House stresses the need to stop the distribution of X-rated videos in the ACT which allow State laws to be easily circumvented and family life undermined.

Canberra is, unquestionably, the video porn capital of Australia. It and the Northern Territory-the two Commonwealth Territories-are the only places in Australia that allow X-rated videos to flourish and, therefore, a mail order system enables X-rated videos to spread throughout all of Australia in total defiance of the banning of X-rated videos in all States of Australia. In the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) 250 people are employed in the X-rated video porn trade alone. Even if one puts aside the M-rated and R-rated distribution points, there are 250 people purveying X-rated videos. In the ACT there are a dozen major distribution agencies. One of the principal distributors has said that he has in excess of 50,000 people on his mailing list alone. Moreover, there are 2,000 X-rated video titles to choose from, and each title can sell, the evidence shows, between 1,000 and 25,000 copies. That means that there are in the order of 2.5 million legal X-rated videos available throughout Australia.

There are lingering stories, which have not been properly rebutted or even addressed by the Government, that organised crime is largely behind the manufacture and distribution of X-rated videos in the ACT. I should think very few people in the community have a true appreciation of the dimensions of the problem. However, I appreciate greatly the House acknowledging the seriousness of the problem by allowing, in the new arrangements for private members' business in this place, for this motion to be listed as No. 2 after the introduction of the private member's Bill by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). That is some indication at least that the legislators in this place are finally beginning to respond to community pressure.

All members have received representations from people of all different political affiliations within their electorates. How do we get to this point? Even if the Government were to finally wake up to its responsibility and give proper credence to the worries of ordinary, decent Australians, it may not be able to stop the problem. It will be very much like closing the stable door after the horse has bolted. With more than two million X-rated videos circulating throughout Australia, how does one now rein in the problem? At least we know that we have to start to make the effort.

If I may, I shall outline how we have arrived at the present position. In July 1983 the Attorney-General at that time, Senator Gareth Evans, called a meeting of all State Ministers responsible for censorship laws. That meeting was held in Brisbane. At that time there was no regulation that controlled the selling or hiring of videos. It was agreed at that meeting of Attorneys-General and various Ministers that there should be a uniform scheme. It was agreed that the ACT would be the model with its Classification of Publications Ordinance. So far, so good. Action was taken in July 1983 and everyone agreed that the ACT should be the model. Some model it has proved to be.

At that meeting the majority of States agreed on a classification scheme. The various categories agreed upon were: G, PG, M, R, and X. Two States-Tasmania and Queensland-dissented from accepting the X classification, but the majority of States agreed with the X classification. It was further agreed that the Commonwealth would exercise its control on the importation of X-category videos. The X-category prohibited child pornography, bestiality, sexual violence or manuals on hard drug use, terrorism or violence. That was the system. In February 1984 that ordinance was brought in here in the Australian Capital Territory.

Throughout 1984 debate raged in the community about the unsatisfactory practice of the spreading of X-rated videos. All State governments came under great pressure throughout the community to ban X-rated videos. So strong was that uprising that by the end of 1984 all States banned X-rated videos. At least the majority of States-Labor States, I hasten to add-which allowed X-rated videos soon woke up to the folly and sought to redress it. All the massive debate in the community finally had an effect. It was a very good example of how people can force governments to respond to a grass roots feeling.

Moreover, in June 1984 more reform took place. All videos had to be classified; it was a compulsory scheme. Before that date videos could voluntarily be classified-only if the producers or distributors wanted them classified need they go to the Commonwealth Film Censorship Board. In 1985 a Senate select committee issued an interim report recommending that a moratorium be placed on X-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory. In other words, it wanted a banning of X-rated videos in the Australian Capital Territory for the time being, for so long as it took the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, which had been formed in the meantime, to report. In other words, the Senate select committee, on the evidence available to it before it was wound up to be replaced by a joint select committee made up of House of Representatives and Senate members, called for a banning of X-rated videos. The Government, and more particularly Senator Gareth Evans, took that request for a moratorium on X-rated videos to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly which rejected it. The reasons are a little vague, but apparently the education and community affairs committee of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly had decided that the system was working well. It had conducted a number of investigations with its limited resources and decided that the system was working well. That was the let-out Senator Evans wanted. In total disregard of the desires of the various States, of the national populace, Senator Evans hid behind the irrelevant House of Assembly committee. It fitted in with Senator Evans's own beliefs on censorship that, unless there is contrary evidence, X-rated videos should be freely allowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —How irresponsible.

—It is irresponsible, that is the whole problem. Senator Evans went along with the House of Assembly and pretended that the matter could be solved once the Joint Select Committee reported. We have lived to rue that day. The State laws banning X-rated videos have amounted to nought because the Commonwealth Government has turned a blind eye to the flourishing and dangerous pornography industry operating within a walk of the precincts of Parliament House. It is a matter of shame for this Parliament that we have allowed that industry to start up and then to flourish, lining the pockets of the purveyors of filth.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some evidence that criminal operations in Melbourne and Sydney are duplicating the X-rated videos and then redistributing them. What is happening is that the distributors are advertising in a number of adult publications with specific titles. In the more general publications such as Australasian Post, People magazine and the Truth newspaper, X-rated videos are able to be advertised so long as no specific titles are used. So in adult publications-presumably Penthouse and Playboy and those types of publications-specific titles can be advertised but in magazines and newspapers that are often brought into homes and are open to inspection by children, X-rated videos can be advertised only if specific titles are not used. People then get onto the mailing lists of distributors in the ACT, and away they go.

It is not just the Commonwealth which has been at fault. The States, whilst banning X-rated videos, have done little, and certainly not enough, to enforce their own laws in regard to these videos, so they are fairly easily available in the States through a number of outlets. The policy of the Government under this Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is to wait for the Joint Select Committee on Video Material to report. I understand that after 2 1/2 years certainly, approaching three years, it will report on 28 April. The excuse given by the Attorney-General whenever this matter is raised with him is that the Government always thought that the Joint Select Committee's report was a few months away; it was always around the corner. Why that Committee has taken so long to address the problem is a matter for the Chairman and others to explain. It has been of tremendous concern to other members in this place. I do not wish to be critical, because it has been an extremely complex matter with a mountain of information to wade through. More than one member has said to me that it is the most difficult job he has ever been involved in in this place over many years of service.

The Commonwealth Government assures us it will act on the report. To what extent we do not know. This is a really enormous problem. We know from surveys that more than half of Australia's homes have a video recorder, and tapes are easily duplicated. To complicate things even further, a substantial amount of material which does not fit even within the Film Censorship Board's X category is flooding in from overseas. I am not sure how we can stop that, except by giving the Australian Customs Service more resources. At present the Service, because of limited resources, must list its priorities. The first priority is the apprehension of drugs; the second is firearms, of course, with the terrorism implications; and coming in after that is the detention of plant life and diseases, and video pornography. So even if we do arm the Australian Customs Service to the teeth, we are still not going to stop the importation of videos containing child pornography and bestiality because it is too easy to copy these videos and transmit them through the mail or have them carried in from overseas by ordinary citizens.

Nonetheless, we have to make a start. It is no good members in this place, or public commentators, or even law enforcement agencies, throwing their hands up in despair and saying that there will always be a market for pornography. Of course there will, but the problem is that it is too open, it is too accessible to children, and it is proliferating throughout the community because, admittedly, of new technology. We seem paralysed by either an inability to understand the dimensions of the problem or a desire not to do so. A great many members on the Government side believe in no censorship, in allowing anything to be seen; but there is much evidence available to show that video pornography has a very serious effect on children, especially, but also on adults.

With only five minutes remaining I cannot hope to make out the case that needs to be made out on the deleterious effect of video pornography on the weak and susceptible in the community. It is not just video pornography; often it is media news and media programs that need to be addressed. We also worry about that. After all, a study by Dr Thomas Radecki, a psychiatrist who heads the Chicago-based National Coalition on Television Violence in the United States, has estimated that by current standards an average viewer will see 45,000 murders or attempted murders on television by the time he or she reaches the age of 21 years. This bombardment of violence is appearing nightly on our television screens-in the news as well as dressed up as entertainment.

Most people, through common sense or their own observations would link violence, or at least violence against women, with violent sex videos and perhaps even with explicit sexual videos. In the time remaining to me let me at least address the effect it has on our children. A report released in 1986, which has received widespread publicity, was entitled Kids and the Scary World of Video, and was compiled by the South Australian Council of Children's Films and Television. The authors of that report interviewed 1,400 children between the ages of 10 and 11. Their conclusions are frightening. The report found that about six in 10 children had access to a video recorder at home and more than 85 per cent reported watching videos at homes of friends. Moreover, a high percentage of those children reported having nightmares on something approaching a regular basis following those sorts of viewings. It is undeniable that that report, which is probably the most comprehensive and certainly one of a very few in the world, is compelling. The report found, as most people would accept, that many young people have very easy access to explicit material in the form of both R- and X-rated videos. It is estimated in that report that one-third of the children of Adelaide have been exposed to graphic scenes of mutilation, dismemberment, rape, and approved violence and murder.

The other evidence that I wish to cite in arguing that video pornography is a dangerous form of supposed entertainment is, of course, the report of the Meese Commission in the United States, which report was also released in 1986. It was ordered by the United States Attorney-General, Edwin Meese. It found that there was a more than casual relationship between specific sexual videos and violence in the community.

As I draw my remarks to a conclusion, I wish to stress that the Opposition has issued a proposal to deal with this evergrowing problem. We would immediately ban X-rated videos in the Commonwealth Territories. We would reclassify some violent M- and R-rated movies to X-rated and ban them outright. Moreover, we would initiate a Government information campaign to inform the community about the classifications. Studies have shown that more than half of the Australian population has no knowledge of the classifications. We would impose tougher penalties on non-compliance with these laws. We would prohibit the importation of material which otherwise would be refused, rather than impose point of sale restrictions which are so difficult to enforce.

It is a tremendous problem which worries not only many members of this place but so many people in the community. The Government is totally to blame for the position we have reached, which will be extremely difficult to redress. But I know, and my colleagues would agree, that we have to start the process now without any more delay. The longer we delay, the sicker and more violent our society will become.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that today, the first day of the new type of private members' business, is being taken up with the type of motion and business that is going on today. It shows Parliament at its worst-hypocrisy competing with motherhood for votes. First we had a Bill introduced by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) dealing with the flag. Then we have a motion moved by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) which is quite meaningless. I do not necessarily disagree with any of the motions I am criticising. I am criticising the fact that time is being wasted. We have the motion by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) with which I agree, although I do not think we should spend three-quarters of an hour on it. It criticises the Soviet Union's lack of civil liberties. We have the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) coming in on multiculturalism. Finally we have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) coming in on St Patrick's Day this afternoon. With all due respect to the fact that the Deputy Speaker is leading a delegation to Ireland later this year--
—The honourable member for Prospect was about to become out of order.

—It is depressing that this Parliament deals with these sorts of motions when it is supposed to be dealing with private members' business. The honourable member for Gippsland has just given an example of why he is generally known as the poor man's Reverend Jimmy Swaggart. He is in the tradition of the Reverend Jimmy Bakker last year, the Reverend Elmer Gantry many years before. He acts in exactly the same sort of way. I am Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.
—It has done nothing for three years.

—If we had wanted to come out with a simplistic statement which was completely meaningless we should have let the honourable member for Gippsland run the Committee. My belief is that to every complex problem there is a simple solution, and it is always wrong. It is a complex problem. We had absolute confusion on the part of the honourable member for Gippsland. He talked about child pornography, bestiality, violence and tied them all in with X-rated videos. Let me give honourable members the definition of what an X-rated video may contain. X-rated videos may contain `material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults but does not include and depictions suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind'. In other words X-rated videos may not contain any violence, any suggestion of rape or any of those things. The honourable member for Gippsland was in utter confusion. If the Committee had the vast knowledge of the honourable member for Gippsland it could have come out with a report the day after we first met. But if the honourable member really wants to look at the facts and find out what is going on, let us do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member talked about child pornography and bestiality allegedly being multiplied. He talked about two million pornographic videos, reaching 25,000 copies each. Recent figures published by the video industry show that the two top hired videos last year were Top Gun and Crocodile Dundee. They reached 20,000 copies. Is the honourable member really suggesting that X-rated videos reach anything like that number of copies? They do not. All the evidence we have shows that the figure is up to 500. Once one has seen one X-rated video one has seen the lot. Let us be quite clear about it. X-rated videos are extremely boring. They are all right for the voyeur but they have no story-line, no redeeming features for practical purposes. The honourable member for Gippsland has confused X-rated videos with violence. Let us be quite clear what is banned in Australia; in other words, what is refused classification. With regard to sex, child pornography and bestiality are banned; in other words, they cannot occur in any of the classifications. Detailed and gratuitous depictions of acts of considerable violence or cruelty and explicit or gratuitous depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons are banned; they are not allowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —They circulate.

—All right, they circulate, but what am I supposed to do then? Lots of things circulate in the community which are illegal. All we can do as people advising law makers, if we are on a committee, is surely to suggest what the law should be. We should not go out and chase people who may have videos with bestiality on them which allegedly circulate in National Party territory and are enjoyed by members of the National Party of Australia. It is depressing to me that masses of people in the community believe that things like child pornography, bestiality and all the films associated with violence, et cetera, are in the X-category. They are not. I have give honourable members a clear definition of what X-rated videos contain. I will repeat it for the benefit of honourable members. They contain:

SPEECH.PARA: Material which includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, but does not include any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are very naive and it worries me that you are Chairman.
—I go back to the point that this is an extremely complex problem.
—Go back and collect your money.
—Order! I understand the honourable member for Gippsland was heard in silence. He should hear other members in silence.

—If it had been a simple problem the Committee would have reported some considerable time ago. The Committee was ready to report in the sense that the so-called Chairman's report was ready for discussion a year and a half ago. While the discussion was going on an election was called last year. Then, to accommodate the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine who participated in the debate for some considerable time on the Committee, we had to extend the size of the Committee. So four or five new members came onto the Committee and, quite justifiably, they wanted to look at the evidence. We have again reached the point, hopefully, where we are about to report.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a proposition also that somehow violent videos have caused lots of crime and that violence in society is increasing to a very significant extent. I will give honourable members the latest figures about violence in Australia. These figures are a report by the Australian Institute of Criminology entitled The Size of the Crime Problem in Australia. It is worth noting that the murder rate per 100,000 population for Australia in 1973-74 was 1.88 and in the last year, 1986-87, it was 1.94. For New South Wales the respective figures were 1.94 back in 1973-74, dropping to 1.77 last year. Proportionately the biggest increase in the Australian States occurred in Queensland-from 2.00 murders in 1973-74 to 2.54 in 1985-86. The latest figures for 1986-87 were not yet available in Queensland. In a similar period the rate for break, enter and steal offences increased at a huge rate. Nobody is suggesting that that is due to videos. Rape reports increased from 5.6 to 12.1, but it must be noted that the law was changed in New South Wales from 1 July 1981 to include cases previously not included. Therefore, they are not comparable figures.

In the Australian Capital Territory-one of the two Territories mentioned earlier-where X-rated videos became legal in 1984, the rape reports dropped from 3.91 per 100,000 in 1982-83, which was the last year before X-rated videos were available, to 1.89 per 100,000, or less than half, the 1986-87 figure. I am not suggesting that rapes decreased in the Australian Capital Territory because X-rated videos became available; I am saying that there is no evidence that they have increased. All those figures came from the Institute of Criminology.
I return to the original proposition. It is terribly depressing that the very first day on which these private members' debates occur, time is taken up by motions which are--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not important?
—It is an extremely important issue, but not for somebody who came to me yesterday afternoon to ask me whether he could contact my secretary to get some facts about videos.
—The secretary of the Committee. What is wrong with that?

—The secretary of the Committee. For the first time yesterday afternoon the honourable member decided to find out some facts. It is obvious from his speech today that he was unable to get those facts.
—Why don't you get out of this place, Dick? You are old and useless.
—Order! If the honourable member for Gippsland continues to interject the Chair will deal with him.
—It is depressing that he was not able to get any facts.
—You are old and useless. Get out.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—I will finish on that point. It is depressing to me that the person who claims to have the solution for that problem had not thought about it before yesterday afternoon and obviously showed in his speech this morning that he had not read any of the literature associated with it and had not thought about it.
—That is a lie.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland will withdraw that interjection.
—I withdraw.
—The honourable member for Gippsland will stand on his feet when he withdraws the interjection. One does not withdraw an interjection while sitting in one's place.
—I withdraw.
—This report will be of some 1,000 pages with lots of dissenting points. It cannot be summarised in a 10-minute address to this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) for a number of reasons. Firstly, I know of the work the honourable member for Gippsland has put into this matter over a number of years, his great concern about this matter, and the great support he is gaining from a good part of his electorate and from people throughout Australia. Secondly, many people in my electorate of Riverina-Darling have written to me expressing concern about the flood of this material which is coming from the Australian Capital Territory because of the lack of action by this Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: While I will concentrate on X-rated videos, I am equally disturbed by those videos and films that are branded with an R category. They contain bad language, discreet sexual violence, explicit scenes of violence and the depiction of drug abuse. A lot needs to be done in that area also. I hope that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, when it finally gets around to presenting its report, will say something about that. I have seen some of these videos recently. One does not have to go to the R-rated videos or films to see people falling from buildings onto meat hooks, cut in half with machine guns, or having their throats cut. These explicit scenes can be seen on television, which is not my idea of what people, especially children, should be watching.

I am aware of the various ratings of the Film Censorship Board, which tend to state that films are restricted to certain age groups. Having raised four children, I know that it is almost impossible to keep young children under 18 years of age from seeing X-rated or unclassified videos. No matter what we try to do or what discipline we instil in our children, if the material is there young children will see it.

The honourable member for Gippsland has touched on the sad history of this affair, but it goes back even further, to the late Justice Murphy who, when Attorney-General in the Whitlam Government, instructed Customs officers not to enforce the law on the importation of pornography. This was revealed in 1985 by the General-Secretary of the Customs Officers Association, Mr Spanswick, who gave evidence to the Senate Committee during its inquiry. He said that on 29 June 1973 the Department directed its senior management to verbally instruct the bottom rank officers in the service, inter alia, to `see pornography and not to see it'. From that time until shortly before 1 February 1984 no judgments at all were made. Mr Spanswick added that during this period Customs officers took action a number of times to seize or detain imported goods in the belief that they ought to be referred to the Attorney-General. But senior officers of the Department took the goods from the officers concerned, cancelled the seizure notices and handed them back to the importing people. So, how do we resolve that? The situation in the Australian Capital Territory today, with the distribution of this pornographic material and of violent videos, is not much better.

The Murphy liberalisation was carried further by Senator Evans when he was Attorney-General. According to the Vice-President of the Customs Officers Association, Mr Peter Bennett, Senator Evans promulgated customs regulations which allowed any printed material, videos or films to be imported into Australia unless there was a specific decision by the Attorney-General, or a person authorised by him, to prohibit it. Mr Bennett added.

. . . because of the way in which the regulations were interpreted, instruction manuals on rape, murder, incest, fraud, blackmail, arson and theft were not prohibited imports, which was now confined only to political terrorism.
You can get a video tape instruction manual on how to commit all manner of crimes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Evans has a lot to answer for.
—That is right.
—He used to be Murphy's secretary.

—He was Senator Murphy's secretary. According to the Liberal Party's Senator Peter Durack, the Government's decision in late 1983 to relax customs regulations on the importation of videos was followed by a flood of X-rated videos entering the country.

SPEECH.PARA: So, we come to the present situation: we have been waiting for three years for a report from the Joint Select Committee on Video Material and, while we have been waiting, X-rated video material has been flowing into all the States where X-rated videos have been banned. I do not envy the Committee its job, but many people are looking forward to seeing its report to be brought down on 28 April. Those so-called liberal thinkers who believe that people should be able to read or watch anything would wonder why there is all this fuss. But I can tell them that, although arguments have been put to the contrary, the dangers of exposing children to the material available in X-rated videos have become more obvious. Dr Elizabeth McMahon, a medical adviser with the People Against Child Exploitation group, illustrated some of these dangers in a recent interview that was reported in the Melbourne Herald. Despite the assertions made by the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), who has just spoken, Dr McMahon says about the number of children sexually abused:
There's a lot more danger in video porn than, say, magazines.
Because it's audio and visual messages together, there are stronger images that mean more to an impressionable child.
Dr McMahon says that gratuitous sex and unchecked violence in the videos lead to the `worst possible kind of sexual exploitation for children'. She continues:
Watching pornography desensitises children and gets them to accept new norms of sexual behaviour.

Of course, this does not apply only to children. That is why I would like to see the membership of the censorship board changed very regularly. We do become desensitised. Things that only a few years ago we thought were abhorrent, today we just accept as part of the norm, and we believe that there is nothing we can do about them. Dr McMahon continues:
It teaches them sex without dignity, tenderness or relationship.
It says sex is necessarily aggressive and treats people as disposable bodies on demand.
Dr McMahon says that recent research has shown that such videos have a detrimental psychological effect on children. She also says:
The South Australian Council for Children's Film and Television recently surveyed about 1500 primary school children for their report on `Kids and the Scary World of Video'.
They found the majority of children had easy access to R-rated material, often in the privacy of homes of trusted friends or family.
That is what I was saying before. She continues:
The saddest thing, though, was that 80 per cent of the children surveyed said they had seen things they now wished they could forget.

I do not know about other members, but I remember, as a child of about 10 years of age, seeing a pornographic magazine, and I wish I had not seen that. I see people on the other side laughing. That type of material does have a very detrimental effect on the minds of children, which lasts for the rest of their lives, and it is something we should avoid.

The honourable member for Prospect was ridiculing some of the reports about the effect this has on people. But even in Russia growing street crime is partly attributed by officials to the influence of video pornography and violence, particularly that coming from the West. We, in a capitalist society, have a lot to answer for as the people who use the production of pornography use it mainly as a money making machine. That is what it is all about. Another newspaper article states:
Dissemination of pornographic material was always regarded as a crime under Soviet law, but there were no provisions in the Criminal Code dealing with explicit violence on film or videotape.

Now, with rapidly increasing numbers of video-recorders and tapes, both imported and locally produced, new legislation was passed last year . . . making manufacture, distribution, demonstration and storage of films and videotapes that `promote a cult of violence and cruelty' a crime with a possible jail sentence of up to two years.

So, we find that even in the Soviet Union people have realised the effect of what we would call R-rated and X-rated videos. If anyone has any doubts about the trade in X-rated videos-the honourable member for Prospect had a few words to say about the numbers refuting what the honourable member for Gippsland said-we have only to read about a case last year when the Australian Federal Police confiscated in one raid 2,000 pornographic videos which were obviously meant for the mail order trade. If 2,000 videos were confiscated in one raid, we can imagine what is going on throughout Canberra. No doubt, this is just one of the types of instances that most members of Parliament can recall when some people in their areas have been charged with having this type of material.

Recently I was appalled to read what the Canberra Chronicle-I must admit that I found this article just as it was about to be wrapped around the vegetables, but it is obviously a very good paper and widely read in Canberra-had to say about X-rated videos from Canberra. It said that they:
are destroying families throughout Australia and should be immediately banned pending the report of the Parliamentary Committee looking into film classification . . .
Of course, it is still not beyond the powers of this Federal Government to ban those X-rated videos even before the Committee's report comes out. The article continued:
Mrs Dawn Casley-Smith said there was no doubt that x-rated videos were destroying families and that they had contributed to the disturbing increase in violent sexual crime in the ACT.

A minister of religion appeared before the Committee and said that the last four marriage break-ups he had had to handle occurred as a result of X-rated videos and the way they had affected the husband and wife relationship, demeaning in particular the wife. That is simply not good enough for Australian society.

I believe that the parliamentary committee on video material has nearly completed its report, and I look forward to reading its findings, given that it has a tremendous responsibility not only to the people in the Australian Capital Territory but to the people of Australia. I hope that when that report comes out it will recommend that something be done in the interests of the welfare of the Australian people and about stopping the people engaged in this. I hope that the honourable member for Prospect will ensure that this is the case and stop those people who are becoming millionaires by putting forward these tapes on pornography and violence, which not only are having a detrimental effect on the minds of young people in Australia but also are destroying families and helping to destroy our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have only a couple of minutes in which to speak, thanks to the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) speaking for a lot longer than the time agreed among the two Whips.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be recognised that this motion is being put forward today only because the honourable member for Gippsland knows that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material is due to report within the next few weeks. The Opposition has done nothing for a couple of years and it has come forward today to do a bit of grandstanding, as the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has done over the last few weeks, knowing that the report is about to come down. It should be interesting to most members to note that, whilst there are a number of National Party of Australia members in the chamber, one of the governments in Australia that allows X-rated videos is the Country-Liberal Party Coalition Government in the Northern Territory. The mates of those opposite up there have not banned X-rated videos, and they are still available in the Northern Territory.

Like the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), I am not going to enter into the debate on the whys and wherefors of X-rated material here. I will do that when the report is brought down. Because I am a member of that Committee, I am a little limited in what I can say. Suffice it to say that what the honourable member for Prospect said was quite correct. There is a total misunderstanding about what is in X-rated videos. In fact the West Australian newspaper, on Monday, 22 February, said, in relation to a move by the Western Australian Government:
. . . The WA Government should be commended for its action. The stuff of which X-rated videos are comprised-bestiality, child sex and sadism-are beyond defending in any society . . .

The facts are that none of those things are in X-rated videos. They are all banned now and have been for ages. What is now in X-rated videos is boring nonsense. I do not necessarily agree that we should have X-rated videos. I will debate that at another time. Suffice it to say that my thoughts are probably a little closer to those of the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) than they are to those of the honourable member for Prospect. Nevertheless, the rubbish we have heard today does not add to the debate on what is a very complex issue. It is not an easy issue. There are thousands of pages of evidence, documents and papers before the Committee. Honourable members will see the outcome of that in a few weeks when the Committee reports to Parliament on what is a very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The honourable member for Isaacs shall have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: UKRAINIAN AND OTHER HELSINKI MONITORING GROUPS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that-
(a) on 1 August 1975 the Final Act of the Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe was signed at Helsinki, Finland, by 33 European States, together with Canada and the USA;

(b) the signatories committed themselves under Principal VII to ``respect human rights and fundamental freedoms, including the freedom of thought, conscience, religion or belief, for all without distinction as to race, sex, language or religion'';

(c) the signing of the Final Act raised the expectations of the peoples of the Soviet Union for greater observance by the Soviet Union of human rights, gave rise to the formation of the Moscow, Lithuanian, Georgian, Armenian and Ukrainian citizens' monitoring groups to inform the peoples of the Soviet Union and the world about the Soviet Government's compliance with the Final Act;
(d) 9 November 1987 was the 11th anniversary of the establishment of the largest such citizens' group, the Ukrainian Public Group, to promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords;

(e) three members of the Ukrainian Group, Oleksiy Tykhy, Yuriy Lytvyn and Vasyl Stus died after years of inhuman treatment in Soviet labour camps while a fourth, Mykhaylo Melnyk, committed suicide as a result of continuous KGB persecution; and

(f) seven members of the Ukrainian Group are still imprisoned under a severe regime, 3 are in internal exile in remote parts of the Soviet Union, while 17 have been released from prison and are living in the Ukraine and 9 have been forced to emigrate to the West after serving prison terms;
(2) acknowledges the concern felt by members of the Australian community over the continued harassment of the Ukrainian Public Group to Promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords;

(3) seeks assurances from the Government of the Soviet Union that members of the Ukrainian and other public Helsinki Monitoring Groups be released from their incarceration and allowed to return to their homelands or, if they wish, emigrate to the countries of their choice;

(4) seeks to convey to the Government of the Soviet Union its belief that such humanitarian acts and the demonstration that its citizens have freedom of expression will serve to reduce tensions between East and West and help to erase doubts about Soviet commitments to their international obligations;

(5) calls upon the Soviet Union to allow Ukrainian Helsinki Monitor, Yuriy Shukhevych, together with his family, to emigrate to Australia, where they have family members willing to sponsor them, as an immediate demonstration of its goodwill; and
(6) requests the Speaker to bring this resolution to the attention of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR.

I might say that that motion, by consent, has been updated to reflect the accurate position at this moment. This is an historic day. It is historic in a number of ways, not the least because, while I move this resolution, we have in Australia a lifetime fighter for human rights in the Soviet Union. I speak of Mrs Oksana Meshko, a very fine lady of some 83 years of age who is presently visiting Australia, and I signal to her in the gallery. It is a pleasing day in a sense that an element of liberalisation is occurring such that this lady is able to be in Australia for a period of three months to have an eye operation. We certainly hope that that operation is successful. I know from speaking with Mrs Meshko that she has a great spirit and a desire to return to the Soviet Union to work for the freedom of those with whom she has been associated in monitoring the Helsinki Accords.

She is a remarkable lady, not just because of her age and because of the faith that she has that carries her on and has seen her through a great deal of personal hardship. In February 1947 Mrs Meshko was charged with a political offence and was sentenced to 10 years imprisonment in a region of Siberia inside the Arctic Circle. She was released in 1956. Thereafter she was active in human rights issues again. Some would say she was haranguing the Soviet Government. In 1980 that led to a further term of imprisonment for this grand lady. She was sentenced to the wastelands once more, a labour camp for six months, and then exiled for five years to a small, remote village called Habarowsk in the far east of the region. Honourable members can see why I mention this lady and her presence in the chamber today and why this is a unique motion.

Honourable members will know that we in the Australian Parliament have a Parliamentary Amnesty Group which has, in non-partisan political terms, an interest in pursuing without fear or favour human rights questions, wherever they occur throughout the world. I am a member of that group and I pursue these questions not only in relation to the Soviet Union but in relation to other countries, some that are seen to be allies of ours and some that are seen to be non-aligned. I pursue this matter in that same spirit because I believe human rights questions quite properly have to be pursued in a non-partisan way and at all times.

It was remarkable 11 years ago that 33 countries came together and set down certain declarations of principles to guide states. Those declarations of principles, known as the Helsinki Accords, covered a large range of matters relating to building confidence for peace in Europe in the future and minimising the sorts of issues that have placed this world at risk from time to time. Amongst the issues that were important were human rights questions. I have to simply record those principles as guiding states because I think they put into some perspective what these people about whom I am speaking today were seeking to monitor. Principle 1 is sovereign equality, respect for rights inherent in sovereignty. Principle 2: refraining from the threat or use of force. Principle 3: inviolability of frontiers. Principle 4: territorial integrity of states. Principle 5: peaceful settlement of disputes. Principle 6: non-intervention in internal affairs. Principle 7: respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, including freedom of thought, conscience, religion or belief. Principle 8: equal rights and self-determination of peoples. Principle 9: co-operation among states. Principle 10: fulfilment in good faith of obligations under international law.

A number of groups were set up within countries, and particularly within the Soviet Union and its various constituent states, to monitor the implementation of the Accords. There have been, and there could be available to honourable members, as there have been to me, documents which have been put together as groups of nations year after year come together to discuss the Helsinki Accords and the way in which they have been implemented. There have been conferences in Madrid, conferences in Vienna and conferences elsewhere in Europe from which we obtain reports year by year on the way in which the Helsinki Accords are being implemented and on the circumstances of individuals.

These monitoring arrangements are particularly important because they reveal the real human dimensions. I wish to bring to the attention of honourable members, without quoting at any length, some of the speeches of Warren Zimmermann, the Chairman of the United States delegation, particularly his speeches of 14 November 1986 and July 1987 in Vienna. Honourable members will find there, documented in the most comprehensive way, the manner in which human rights abuses have proceeded in the Soviet Union, and the large number of people who remain incarcerated still because of their political views and their desire to monitor the way in which human rights issues are addressed.

As a member of the Parliamentary Amnesty Group I simply note that some of those who have been placed in prisons from time to time, or sent to labour camps, are those who have been involved in Amnesty in the Soviet Union and who seek merely to take up human rights questions wherever they arise. In the short time that I have available to me I am able only to gloss over the great deal of information to which I have access. I wish to record that at this time in the Soviet Union there have been a number of moves that evidence a change of attitude. I welcome those changes and I am sure that all people of goodwill would want to acknowledge those changes that suggest that the Soviet Union's attitude towards political questions, even within the Soviet Union, might be undergoing a period of review.

I note that some commentators who are experts in these matters, have drawn attention to the establishment of the Soviet Human Rights Commission, which was announced on 31 July 1987 to deal with various humanitarian issues and to inform Soviet citizens of their rights. I note also that the Soviet Union claimed in 1986 that it was liberalising its approach to immigration, one of the important human rights questions that are monitored from time to time. I also note that the Soviet Foreign Minister in that year, Eduard Shevardnadze, proposed that Moscow would hold a conference to discuss the whole range of problems in the field of humanitarian cooperation, including human contacts information, culture and education. I have also seen reports that Soviet psychiatric hospitals are about to undergo a change; they may be moved from the Soviet Minister of the Interior, where the staffs wore uniforms in the past, to the Health Ministry. That move may be the forerunner of an improved situation.

I wish to make those points in the following way: it seems to me that they are general comments of prospective change, and if we are able to see, through those steps that are being taken, changes on the human front, no doubt glasnost, as we have heard it discussed, will take on a new dimension. This motion names a number of people still in detention, and it seems to me that if we reach a situation where those people are released, and are able to return to their homes and monitor the situation in the Soviet Union freely, we will have a changed situation. I would certainly urge honourable members to continue to monitor the situation. If change is really occurring, we will see it carried through in the human terms that are so important.

Finally, I wish to make a plea, particularly in the case of Levko Lukyanenko, a prominent Soviet lawyer. Our guest here in Australia, Mrs Meshko, makes the point that he is a man before his time. Lukyanenko, as a lawyer, was trained to defend people, but, because of his involvement in defending those who were put on trial because of their political views, he became a political prisoner himself. A great deal of information about him is available. Because of the time constraints upon me I seek leave to table a publication produced by the Committee for Defence of Human and National Rights in Ukraine on Lev Lukyanenko, to ensure that it is available for honourable members.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to table a further document with information on other Ukrainians that was prepared for the tenth anniversary of the Ukrainian Helsinki group, which records the background and experience of the large number of people involved in monitoring human rights issues in the Ukraine. It is one of the largest and most notable organisations of its kind.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to have had the opportunity today in this debate to mention particularly our guest, Mrs Meshko, and Mr Levko Lukyanenko, the lawyer, a contemporary of Prime Minister Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. I simply note that this man for his beliefs has spent 25 years in Soviet concentration camps. He has now been sent into exile where the only available work for him, if he were to be employed gainfully, is the felling of trees. The real concern for Ukrainian monitors at this time is that this gentleman may well not survive his next five years in exile.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a plea at this stage that his cause be taken up anew, that we seek to have him released, and that we hand to Mrs Meshko a message of support, strength, and encouragement that she can take back to her fellow citizens in the Soviet Union, as they work on human rights issues and work for the release of their friends and colleagues involved in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be no-one in this House who would oppose the motion of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). Indeed, I am sure there would be wide bipartisan support for the view that the rights of individuals are being threatened and suppressed, not only in Hungary, Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union, but throughout the world in many areas. I am pleased to see in the gallery our visitor from the Soviet Union. I welcome her on behalf of the Government and assure her that the Government, and members of the Government, also view with concern the fact that individuals in the Soviet Union and its satellites are denied the rights and freedoms that we in Australia take for granted, that we in Australia believe should be universal and that we expect all governments, no matter where, should give to their citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: I give credit to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas. I note the presence in the gallery of Senator Puplick, another noted civil libertarian. It is pleasing also to see that there are, among members of the Opposition, those who support, universally, rights and freedoms throughout the world. It is important that that recognition be given in a debate such as this.

But what is equally tragic is that at this very moment there are six black condemned people sitting in a cell in South Africa who face the gallows tomorrow, having been charged with and convicted of an offence that did not involve evidence being required of their participation-the offence of murder. Rather their crime was that they were adjacent to and part of a general public political protest, and as a result of their presence at that protest they have been convicted of the principal crime of murder about which there is no evidence of their participation and for which they face the gallows on Friday morning. There could be no greater breach of a human being's rights than to be convicted of a homicide about which there was no evidence of participation. Having convicted those black South Africans, the South African Government is taking that action, despite pleas from around the world. I note with pleasure that even the President of the United States, not noted for his views on civil liberties, has now publicly joined the rest of the world in seeking that that tragic event not occur. Yet we in this country know from the record in South Africa, as in many other parts of the world, that the likelihood is that those six black South Africans will pay the supreme penalty of death in the morning-death by hanging. Although in all sincerity I acknowledge the work done by individual Opposition members, I am ashamed of the fact that Opposition members have yet to stand up publicly and condemn that act which will occur in South Africa tomorrow. It is surely a tragedy that in Australia, a country which recognises rights and liberties, the Opposition has not yet joined the rest of the world leaders in condemning the events that will take place tomorrow.

The honourable member for Dundas, who has credibility as a backbencher in talking of civil rights, referred to the Helsinki Accords of 1975 but made no mention of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. This country is a signatory to that Covenant, but a Bill to enshrine those rights provided in the Covenant was rejected by the numbers in the Senate. Therefore, even today this country does not by legislation recognise the most fundamental and basic principles of human rights. It is a shame that that is the case in this country. It is a shame that we as parliamentarians, no matter what our political views or parties, have not enshrined those rights in legislation-the very rights that we demand from other countries. As a parliament and as a nation we should demand legislation enshrining those rights. Those rights which this Parliament rejected only last year are basic rights which no-one in this House individually would oppose. The rights are very simple. They are the right to life; freedom from torture and inhuman treatment; freedom from slavery, servitude and forced labour; the right to liberty and security of the person; the right of prisoners to be treated with humanity; freedom from imprisonment for failure to fulfil a contractual obligation; the right to freedom of movement; the rights of aliens in respect of expulsion; rights in relation to the criminal process, including the right to a fair trial; protection against retroactivity of the criminal law; the right to be recognised as a person before the law; the right to privacy; the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; the right to freedom of expression; a ban on propaganda for war, or advocacy of national, racial or religious hatred; the right to peaceful assembly; the right to freedom of association; the right to marry and found a family; the right of children to measures of protection; the right to take part in public life, electoral rights and the right of equal access to public service; and last, but very importantly, the right of equality and non-discrimination before the law. Those are the very rights that this motion demands that a foreign government give to people now imprisoned. However, we as a parliament and as a nation have failed to enshrine those rights in our own legislation. How can we condemn other countries for failing to give those rights when we, as a parliament, have failed to enshrine them in our own laws?

Yet this motion is not about that, although it gives me an opportunity to express those strong personal views. The motion is about individual human beings-people whom I have never met. Because those people have a view and want the right of expression and freedom of thought, they have been imprisoned. That has happened, without fair process of trial, not because they have done any harm to the state in which they live, but because their views are contrary to the views of the political leaders in that state. These rights should apply to people in the Soviet Union, or to negroes living in the American southern states who have yet to achieve economic freedom-although the American law may well enshrine the rights of American negroes, it is true that their economic freedom is far from established. These rights should also apply to South America, Costa Rica, Brazil or the Argentine, and to the people of Afghanistan who are fighting the Soviet Union in seeking the right of self-determination. Whether these provisions apply to people who live in Namibia, or to people anywhere in the world, I believe that this House has a concern to express often and publicly its strong and collective view that those rights are inalienable, and that they cannot be fettered or removed. In one sense they do not even need to be written. Certainly without them a person is less than a human being. Without them, one is not a political person and one has no political rights. The motion is important. It is self-evident and it raises far broader issues than are expressed in written form. The motion deserves bipartisan support from all honourable members of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is about the denial of human rights in the Soviet Union, and I am pleased to second the motion moved by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). This is an important debate, as the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) said. It is important that it be understood by the Soviet Union that there is a bipartisan approach by members on both sides of the political spectrum in this Parliament as well as people in this nation. The term `human rights' sometimes appears esoteric because we in Australia take those human rights and fundamental freedoms for granted, but those rights are denied to people in many countries. I can get up in this Parliament and say anything about anybody, subject to the Standing Orders; the fact that we have a free Press; people are free to practise the religion of their choice and to come and go. Freedoms we exercise from day to day without thinking are denied to others. That is particularly so in the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McEwen attacked the Opposition on its stance on the hangings of the Sharpeville six that are proposed to be carried out in South Africa tomorrow. I put it on record that yesterday in the Senate a resolution was passed unanimously condemning the intended hanging of the Sharpeville six in South Africa. That resolution called on the South African Government to exercise clemency. In fact, Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and Senator Hill spoke on behalf of the Opposition and supported the resolution. I also take this opportunity to ask the South African Government to exercise clemency. It would be a futile act if that Government were to carry out those hangings.

On the important subject of human rights, it is only since the Second World War that `human rights' has been in the dictionary and in our lexicon. President Roosevelt delivered a famous four freedoms speech to Congress in 1941. He defined the four basic human rights essential to the restoration of world order as freedom of speech and expression, freedom of religion, freedom from want and freedom from fear everywhere in the world. Subsequently those thoughts were incorporated in the Atlantic Charter, a set of postwar aims announced by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill. After the Second World War the United Nations (UN) Charter in articles 55 and 56 adopted human rights definitions. It said that that international organisation would promote human rights and fundamental freedoms for all without distinction as to race, sex, language or religion.

Following the setting up of the UN declaration, as there was a need, regrettably, throughout the world for other forums and agencies to pursue human rights because of the denial of them, the next step was the formulation of the Helsinki Accords of 1975, which are the subject of this motion I am seconding. The Helsinki Accords define certain human rights and extract promises from signatory governments, including European governments, the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). The tragedy is that the USSR has not honoured and carried out its obligations under the Helsinki Accords, and that is why the honourable member for Dundas and I and members of the Government have to speak in this House in a bipartisan way condemning the Soviet Union for not putting into effect the Helsinki Accords.

I acknowledge that there is some change taking place, some liberalisation, in the Soviet Union under the so-called spirit of openness, or glasnost. We are yet to find out what that really means. There is certainly a state of change, a state of flux, in that country, but whether it is more than rhetoric, whether it will become reality, we are as yet unable to judge. We must hesitate to make a judgment; it is too early to say. We saw changes after Khrushchev succeeded Stalin and he exposed the Stalin camps. We must refrain from making early judgments even though, as I have said, there are changes and they are welcome.

I want to refer to some documents, including Amnesty International reports, that are relevant to this matter. There is also a relevant United States State Department report that is regarded by observers as objective. I shall refer quickly to the Amnesty report on religious prisoners, because I have a concern about prisoners of conscience in the Soviet Union. There is an offence there referred to as malicious disobedience, and the Amnesty International Report of 1987 says:
Despite official moves towards glasnost, individuals who communicated uncensored information on controversial topics faced imprisonment under laws restricting freedom of expression.
The report refers to the fact that people were sent to gaol and exiled, and continues:

Another 30 individuals received sentences of up to three years' imprisonment on the less serious charge of `circulating anti-Soviet slander'. They were mostly religious believers convicted of distributing or printing Bibles and prayer books produced on home-made presses.

I want to conclude by paying tribute to a very brave lady who is in the gallery today, a Mrs Oksana Meshko, who is out of the Soviet Union to undergo an eye operation in Australia. The honourable member for Dundas referred to her bravery. When I talked to her earlier in the day, she was more concerned about the plight, the fate, of Levko Lukyanenko than herself. She is a lady who is brave, and who has faith. She was 10 years in Stalin's camps, and in the 1980s she spent six months in a KGB prison and five years in exile. She is an inspiration to us as she sits here today representing not only people from the Ukraine but also Christians, Jews and people of all races and creeds in the Soviet Union who cry out for freedom. I asked her what kept her going, and she said, `My love for human beings and a sense of duty to the community, and a sense of patriotism'. I honour her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, before us today we have an important motion on human rights, and in particular human rights in the Ukraine as they affect particular individuals there. I wholeheartedly endorse the remarks not only of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton), who has just resumed his seat, but also of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who I thought made a very fine contribution on human rights in general a little earlier in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that a final act of the conference on security and cooperation in Europe was signed in Helsinki on 1 August 1975 by 35 nations. That became known as the Helsinki Accords. The West gained some Soviet acceptance of provisions guaranteeing basic human rights and freedoms, and the rights of national groups to self-determination. However, the Soviet Union does not have a great record on human rights, particularly the rights of its ethnic groups such as the people in the Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia, and of course in the Ukraine, which is referred to in the motion before us. Many people in those areas have struggled for many years, for many decades, for basic human rights not only for themselves but also for others. They have fought to retain their own culture, traditions and language so that they are not submerged into the Russian culture that surrounds them. The people of the Ukraine have been struggling for many years for self-determination, to be a separate state and to have their own culture-or should I say to keep their own culture and traditions.

I welcome Mrs Meshko here today. She is a very fine lady who is here representing those people in the Ukraine. She is staying with her niece, Mrs Hrudka, who is from the lovely bayside suburb of Edithvale, in the middle of my electorate of Isaacs. Hopefully I will see Mrs Meshko more throughout her several months in Australia. If she stays with her niece she will be only a stone's throw from my office. She is in Australia, and here today, not only for her eye operation, which we hope is successful, but also on behalf of the people of the Ukraine to put the case in person so that we can understand the situation properly. All too often, particularly here in Australia, which is a long way from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), we talk ad nauseam about various subjects but it is of great assistance to us when we meet people from various parts of the world or when we travel to various parts of the world to get first-hand experience of what these people have to put up with.

In the Ukraine, as I have suggested, the people have had to put up with all too much over the last 50 years or so. I have a number of friends in Australia who come from the Ukraine and the Baltic states and I applaud them for their efforts on behalf of their friends and relatives back in their homeland. Many people here in Australia through their local organisations-for example, the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations-do a tremendous amount of work for the human rights of people back in their homeland. One of the people covered by the motion is a lawyer, Mr Lev Lukyanenko. He is an important person because he has struggled for many years. He has put himself out, he has been in prison and he has had his human rights denied. We are asking the Soviet Union to give basic human rights and freedoms to these people immediately. As the honourable member for McEwen said, there are many human rights abuses around the world. The two Opposition speakers, the honourable member for Higgins and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), have been assiduous in their efforts on human rights issues, as have many members on this side of the House over the years. It is extraordinary that on the first day on which we have debated private members' business we have such an important motion before us.

I endorse the remarks of the honourable members who have already spoken. I understand that this motion will be passed unanimously so that we can send a clear signal to the Soviet Union that the basic freedoms and rights of people under its umbrella-be they from the Ukraine or the Baltic states or be they other minority groups throughout the USSR-should be recognised immediately. It is interesting to see some of the changes that are occurring in the USSR. I will be interested to talk later to Mrs Meshko about those changes and how real they are. Glasnost appears to be working, but ever so slowly. Of course, if one lives in a country which has had an authoritarian regime for 70 years, one cannot turn things around overnight. There is much opposition from members of the hierarchy of the USSR leadership who are fighting Mr Gorbachev on many of his reforms. Let us hope that Mr Gorbachev and others of a like mind have the will to pursue the reforms for the good of the vast majority of the people under the umbrella of the USSR. As I say, I endorse the remarks of honourable members who have spoken. I hope that the motion will be passed unanimously. I welcome Mrs Meshko and thank her for putting the case of the Ukrainian people to us.
