Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House reaffirms its commitment to the establishment of a multicultural society in Australia and in particular recognises that-
(1) Australians of all backgrounds are free and able to participate at all levels in the political, administrative, legal, economic, cultural and artistic life of the nation;
(2) there should be freedom to maintain one's cultural heritage within the context of a common legal and political system, with English as the accepted national language;
(3) all Australians should be free from discrimination on the basis of race, ethnicity, religion or culture, and should have equality of opportunity and equitable access to programs and services;

(4) programs and services provided to the community as a whole should, as far as possible, be made accessible to all Australians by being sufficiently adaptable to cater to the specific needs of those born overseas and those whose preferred language is other than English, as well as the Australian-born, but, where necessary and appropriate, separate and specialised services should be provided;

(5) programs and services should be designed and developed in consultation with all potential client groups, including those born in Australia and those born overseas, and should involve their active participation; and
(6) a just and equitable society should be promoted which accepts all people irrespective of their ethnic and cultural backgrounds.

In speaking to this motion I wish to say that the multicultural idea is at the moment at the crossroads, 14 years after it was first supported and implemented by the Whitlam Government. At first seen as a novel and exciting concept with enormous potential for social change and greater equality in Australian society, it is now being questioned by some people and attacked by some conservative writers, especially the New Right. While the Australian Labor Party is firmly committed to a policy of multiculturalism and the Liberal Party of Australia has also stated its commitment to it, genuine implementation still has a long way to go. It is vital in 1988, while the Government correctly continues its commitment to immigration, while a growing proportion of Australians come from non-English speaking backgrounds and while general economic problems face the community, to restate the meaning and aims of multiculturalism and to ensure its implementation.

Let us go to the heart of the matter. The kernel of multiculturalism is that a diversity of cultures have a right to contribute to the evolving Australian culture; that is, the Australian culture of the future involves a synthesis of the elements of many cultures which immigration has brought. Multiculturalism in this sense is a completely different model from the assimilationist view of the past. Whereas assimilation required the eventual destruction of other cultures and the assimilation of people into a dominant norm, multiculturalism is the opposite. It promotes the co-existence of diversity, with equal rights and participation, precisely so that these cultures can contribute to the evolution of the Australian culture of the future.

However, multiculturalism is not-I emphasise not-cultural apartheid. It is not a matter of live and let live in the sense of the dominant culture permitting the existence of other cultures and cultural groups, but not allowing them to make any impact on its own evolution. Those critics of multiculturalism who claim that it is identical to cultural apartheid have missed the essential elements of multicultural philosophy. One of those critics is Professor Geoffrey Blainey who, as late as last Saturday in the Australian, again attacked multiculturalism, calling it a dangerous slogan. It is quite clear in his interpretation of multiculturalism that he understands it to mean some form of cultural apartheid which, of course, it is not intended to be, and which it is not. So his arguments are addressed as a red herring against the actual concept of multiculturalism as it has been understood.

One of the problems with Professor Blainey and a number of other academic critics of multiculturalism is that they criticise some conception that they have in their mind rather than the actual notion of multiculturalism which has been developed over a long time. We have been talking about this concept for 14 years. They keep claiming that it is vague, that they do not know what it means and that it is a dangerous notion. Frankly, I am starting to question the motives of some of these people who keep saying these things when they know very well that there are specific definitions of multiculturalism of the kind that I have given here today and of the kind embedded in this motion. If they want to debate it, let them debate that concept and not some false conception which they try to put up.

Returning to the central point, I am saying that multiculturalism is not, as some like to believe, just tolerance of a wide diversity of people and cultures. It is not a superficial promotion of outward cultural features such as dance or cuisine. It is a very real commitment to planning policy and action to ensure that equal status is accorded to the diversity of cultures and equal rights to their claim to contribute to the evolution of Australian culture. A multicultural plan of action involves a program for the whole of society, an attack on major inequalities due to cultural differences, for it is a fact that when we look at high unemployment, poverty, the lack of cheap accommodation and inadequate health and education services it is very often the migrant communities which suffer the most. Therefore, it is very important as an aspect of multiculturalism to emphasise the removal of these inequalities through an access and equity program.

The question of equal access is a key and important matter. It has been referred to in a number of reports. The Government has recently adopted an access and equity strategy and has brought out a report on it. Let me say something about what the Jupp report said about the access and equity strategy. It said that the strategy should be concerned with three elements of social life: participation in our social, economic and political structures; the opportunity to use, and be fairly treated in relation to, programs and services; and participation and consultation on the ways in which these programs and services are planned, delivered and evaluated. In other words, access and equity is concerned with ensuring a fair go in the very broadest sense, according to Dr Jupp. Similarly, as the final report from the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs states, the effective implementation of the Government's access and equity strategy can be brought about in the future only through detailed examination of major areas such as education, employment and social welfare and by the development of detailed measures to ensure effective change. In this regard the capacity of the Office of Multicultural Affairs to initiate such reviews, comparable to the Institute's work on the aged and on labour market programs, will be critical, as will be the availability of sufficient resources to utilise the findings of such reviews to bring about change. It is important that change take place in those directions.

Perhaps I should outline some of the sorts of policies that are involved in the promotion of a multicultural society. Often the critics of multiculturalism get them wrong. They do not zero in on or identify what the policies and strategies are. The initial requirement of all Australians, if they are to have full opportunities, is an adequate skill in the English language. The teaching of English and the provision of courses for adults and children are a crucial aspect in the promotion of a multicultural society. In this regard it is very important that all governments and all parliaments do whatever they can to promote the teaching of English.

At the same time, while learning basic English skills is important, people must have information about the country they are living in, their rights, the services available to them, the way institutions operate and how they can gain access to them. This is best conveyed in the language people understand best-their original language. This may seem a simple thing, but I know for a fact that many people in the community are not gaining access to services because of the insufficient provision of material in ethnic languages. We need to make that material available to them in the community languages.

Employment is another area where assistance is needed. Many people, on migrating to Australia, do not have the benefit of career guidance or vocational advice and have the disadvantage of not having their qualifications and skills recognised in Australia. Whilst the Committee for the Recognition of Overseas Qualifications is doing a good job, it is important that we stress the need for greater emphasis and greater resources in this area as well as ensuring that in the case of some professions, such as the medical and legal professions, there is more flexibility-by the Australian Medical Association, for example-in the recognition of qualifications.

Not only should we be encouraging a working knowledge of English in the community but also we should be implementing a national language policy. The Government has announced the national language policy. It is important to get further resources for funding the national language policy. The introduction of the national language policy was a very positive development. We should ensure that it is possible for children to learn languages in this country other than English not only because the promotion of multiculturalism in the future depends on the capacity of people to speak languages but also because we need the knowledge of other languages in the broader international context if we are to be a sophisticated community.

Community languages should be taught in schools because most communities wish to pass on their first language to their children and, as members of the community, have the right to ask this of the education system. Literacy and fluency in one's original language assist greatly in the learning of another language, which is particularly important for adults in the learning of English. I hope that the national language policy will be promoted further in this regard.

I could refer to many aspects of the motion, for example, migrant education, multicultural education, multicultural policies for the promotion of cultural activities, the arts, the grant-in-aid program for the provision of welfare for ethnic communities, the provision of translator and other services in the mainstream, the provision of community and governmental services and the provision of a multicultural media which, fortunately, continues to be provided in this country through the excellent service of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). The SBS needs more funding so that it is able to provide more programs in the future. We need to provide more locally produced programs by actors, writers, producers and others who are very well qualified in this country and who are from a non-English speaking background. In addition, it is very important for us to ensure that we develop a greater understanding and tolerance in the community.

As Professor Donald Horne has written, to suppress the ethnicity of migrants is literally inhuman since culture is one's definition of one's humanity. Ethnicity is a real, persistent human and humanising focus of group life and we should not be sweeping it under the carpet or regarding ethnic or cultural differences as a problem. Rather, we should regard them as an enrichment of our culture and, as such, as a focus so that we can gain the contributions of the many cultures in this country towards the evolution of a future Australian culture which we all look forward to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us a very important motion, which I believe and trust will be supported by all members of this House. I am very pleased and very proud that of all the cultures in the world the Australian is probably the most multicultural.

SPEECH.PARA: Our history is based upon immigration. Originally, in the nineteenth century it was probably to escape from poverty and persecution that many migrants came to Australia from a number of countries. For example, the Irish were escaping from subjugation and the potato blight. The Chinese came to join the gold rush and in many cases finished up only one stage away from slavery. We must remember that these people came to a country with challenges and hardships probably unknown to most other parts of the world. They took up those challenges and, because of their indomitable spirit, were successful and helped make Australia the great country it is today.

In the postwar era I am happy to give credit where it is due and to recognise Arthur Calwell who, as a Minister in the Chifley Government, played a major role, with his vision, in breaking down bigotry and racism and setting the framework for the postwar immigration boom. That opportunity was seized by the Menzies Government, whose record for humanitarianism in accepting displaced persons from Poland, Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia and neighbouring countries in the early 1950s was a proud one and one which was later continued by the Fraser Government in relation to Vietnamese refugees. I think it is fair to say that the Menzies Government was particularly successful in achieving a balance between skilled and contributing immigration and family reunion. This was done at a time when there was the maximal rate of immigration and yet there was virtually full employment in Australia.

It is fair to say that historically our country has been based upon a number of cultures, the Aboriginal culture initially and, subsequently, an Anglo-Saxon and Judao-Christian culture with a system of Westminster government. More recently it has had input from continental Europe, South East Asia, India, the Pacific Islands and many other communities with a number of religions-Christianity, Buddhism, Islam, Hinduism and many others-all with the very precious freedom to worship in their own ways and all, I am very pleased to say, relatively free of interdenominational strife and bigotry, with a mutual acceptance and tolerance which I think is unparalleled elsewhere in the world.

The motion itself is in the nature of a motion which supports motherhood. Surely no-one in this Parliament would disagree with it. It goes without saying that this House reaffirms its commitment to the establishment of a multicultural society in Australia. But I am pleased to take this opportunity of reaffirming those values on behalf of the Liberal and National parties. The other aspects of the motion are freedom to participate at all levels in all aspects of the nation's life; freedom to maintain original cultural heritage within the Australian system; freedom from discrimination with equality of opportunity, most importantly, and access to programs and services; and making those programs and services adaptable enough to cater for the needs of migrants as well as those born in Australia. The overall summary of the motion is that we should be able to live in a just and equitable society which accepts all people irrespective of their ethnic and cultural backgrounds.

I, as a fairly recent migrant to Australia, like the member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), who is about to speak, am delighted on behalf of the coalition parties to reaffirm our commitment to these principles. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) reminded us that multiculturalism is not a superficiality, it is not just an increase in the numbers of pizzas or chop sueys or balalaika music. It is much deeper than that. It is a blending and yet it is the preservation of ways of life which may have different emphasis in different cultures. It is a blending, for example, of the values not only of the immediate family, but also of the extended family, the importance of the work ethic and the importance of other ethics.

The concept and the social ideal of multiculturalism were developed and enhanced by past Liberal governments to create acceptance, respect and understanding of individuals from a number of different backgrounds. We, the coalition parties, very sincerely endorse the objectives of a cohesive society within which people are entitled to express their own identity. We of course support equality of opportunity to participate in our society and of course we encourage a commitment to the national well-being of Australia. Economic migrants, refugees, displaced persons and family reunion migrants all look for many of the same things in our society. The first settlers wanted liberty and opportunity and now people have been striving for the same goals for 200 years-since the birth of modern Australia. These values are the very core of our current nation-freedom, access to opportunity and family.

People in Australia should be citizens and residents who are able to live in an environment which allows everyone to achieve his own individual potential, which allows equality of opportunity to participate in what is a competitive society in regard to the local community, to State and national affairs, and which encourages people to share both the commitment and the responsibility of the benefits of our country. Very clearly, it must be in order for our society to develop a commitment to the concepts of social cohesion, cultural identity and equality of opportunity. This equality must be of opportunity and not of outcome. We should all be able to reach upwards, not to be brought down by the Government to the lowest common denominator.

The current Government has rejected these concepts; we in the coalition reaffirm them. Our opponents' concern with immigration numbers and the threat to jobs was enshrined in the prices and incomes accord. The significance of the different philosophical outlooks between the parties is easily demonstrated when the commitment of the coalition to the individual is contrasted with the socialist categorisation of individuals as class groups.

I point out that during this Government's term there have been four Ministers for immigration. This indicates the lack of importance which is placed upon this portfolio by the Hawke Government. Let me remind honourable members about the importance this Government actually places on multiculturalism-the facts, not the rhetoric. In August 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
The Government through the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and on this occasion, through me, commits itself unequivocally to enhancing multicultural values.

How did he and his Government respond to this? They merged the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service and then they unmerged SBS. They still do not know what they are going to do with SBS. They abolished the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, they abolished the multicultural education program; they slashed the English as a second language program, one which the honourable member for Calwell himself has just pointed out to be of significant importance to the ethnic communities; and they closed six regional offices of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

The Government did give a 12.1 per cent increase in grants-in-aid to migrant community groups. I laud the Government for this increase. But let us put it into perspective. At the same time as it gave a 12.1 per cent increase to the migrant groups, it gave a 23.1 per cent increase to the trade unions in grants-in-aid; almost twice as much. Quite clearly, this Government thinks it is twice as important to look after the unions as is to look after migrant groups. I say this not with a sense of gloating or point scoring, but with a sense of sadness.

What the Prime Minister has given to migrants is the opportunity to be hit first and hardest in the firing line of past and probably future Budgets cuts. The Government has denied equal opportunities to migrants with its ad hoc and second-hand ethnic affairs program. What the Prime Minister has offered and will offer will, I believe, have disastrous implications for those people and their families seeking to make a secure economic base for their future and on the capacity of community groups to participate in equitable access to these services.

The coalition has a commitment to freedom in all senses of that word and to all the people of Australia regardless of their race or religion. We sincerely welcome this motion. We hope that for once the Hawke Government's performance will live up to its rhetoric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to second this motion today. I congratulate the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) on his initiative in moving the motion. It is indeed an excellent motion and something which is very close to the heart of the honourable member for Calwell. I have listened to the remarks made by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods). He is an immigrant, as are all of us who have spoken on this motion. I think he is a little out of date because a lot of those matters which he complains of have been reversed anyway. New offices are being opened and there is an Office of Multicultural Affairs which advises the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Perhaps he did not do his research as well as he should.

SPEECH.PARA: There are 4.5 million postwar migrants in Australia, which makes the consideration of this motion an absolute must for this House. Honourable members will note that the motion calls for this place to reaffirm its commitment to the establishment of a multicultural society in Australia. This is because the process of multiculturalism is an ongoing one and is obviously closely linked with the question of immigration. If one accepts the argument that migration is necessary and desirable for economic or cultural reasons, one needs to be prepared to support the points raised in this motion to bring about a society which can take full advantage of the cultural and economic benefits which migrants bring to this country. In my view the immigration debate makes the debate on multiculturalism in this place necessary. The very public views of the likes of Professor Geoffrey Blainey, Bruce Ruxton and, more recently, Senators John Stone and Glen Sheil also make this debate necessary.

Headlines such as `Migrants: Libs on Attack; Shared policy to go after 43 years' indicate to me that we need to debate this issue in the Parliament. John Stone recently proposed the policy that only English speaking persons should be allowed to migrate to this country. This is an interesting point of view considering the great wealth of experience and culture which migrants of all nationalities have brought to this country regardless of whether or not they could speak English upon their arrival. At the time of Senator John Stone's comments I was quick to admit that when I came to this country at the ripe old age of four I was not able to speak English, nor were my parents. His proposed policy, if in place back then, would mean, in effect, that I would not be standing here today as a member of parliament representing a constituency of Australians.

It is the experience of the Italian migrants with which I am most familiar because of my own heritage. I was told recently by my good friend Nino Randazzo, the Editor-in-chief of the Italian newspaper Il-Globo, that Sicily, my home country, was where multiculturalism was invented. It is perhaps for this reason that the Italians generally and the Sicilians in particular have integrated so well into Australian society. I must add though that, while we may have been successfully integrated, we have, in accordance with the terms of this motion, maintained our cultural heritage-so much so that many who return to Italy find that the customs and practices of old Italy are in much better shape here than in their home country. Not only have we maintained our heritage, but we have also integrated a few Aussies into our way of life. Who could imagine life in Australia without the occasional pizza or spaghetti bolognese, for example? I am sure that the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), would have enjoyed that. John Cattalini, the Italian born Mayor of Fremantle, was quoted in Times Australia recently as saying:
I don't think that Italians care too much about whether or not we're accepted. It's irrelevant because we are part of the community.

The Italians are the second largest migrant group in this country and it has been estimated that nearly one million Australians have some Italian heritage. Italians have a long and proud history in Australia. We began arriving in this country early in the nineteenth century and our presence has been felt in a number of social and economic ways. The overwhelming majority of Italians who came to Australia were not particularly skilled or educated but they have made their lives here and many have succeeded in their chosen professions, trades or businesses. The Italian presence in Australia is such that we can honestly say that we have our own unique culture and history here in this country which is inextricably linked to Australia's. Take, for example, the role of Raffaello Carboni in that most famous and, many would argue, uniquely Australian rebellion which took place in 1854 on Eureka Hill under that uniquely Australian symbol, the Southern Cross. Carboni was a gold digger in the Victorian fields of Ballarat. He was also a writer, leaving behind him the only written eyewitness account of the Eureka Stockade rebellion. Carboni was put in charge of the `foreign battalion' of miners by that other famous migrant of the time and now folk hero, Peter Lalor.

My own situation is probably evidence of the way in which Italians have integrated into this society. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, my constituency of Bowman does not have a particularly high mix of migrants; yet the people of Bowman had little hesitation, I am proud and happy to say, in electing me to the Federal Parliament. It is always difficult to interpret events, but I would say that the fact that I was born in Italy had virtually no effect whatsoever on the results for Bowman in the last Federal election. I am sure that that is the case in other areas where successful candidates have been born overseas. Most of them, I am happy to say, are on our side of the House.

Election to parliaments or the attainment of high public office is probably a reasonable measure, in a quantitative way, of the acceptance of a person and that person's culture and heritage. There is a bond of trust between a member of parliament and his or her constituency which is inherent in the very act of electing that member. Italian participation in public life in Australia dates back to the nineteenth century. In the Australian Labor Party there are four Italian born members of legislative councils around the country. They are Giovanni Sgro in Victoria, whom the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, would know, Franca Arena in New South Wales, Mario Feleppa in South Australia, and Sam Piantadosi in Western Australia. For the Liberals, Frank Calabro sits in the Legislative Council of New South Wales, although I understand he has recently retired so it will leave them all on our side of politics.

Another highly respected area of public affairs is the judiciary. In this field two Italians have excelled. Perhaps the best known of these is Justice Sir James Gobbo of the Victorian Supreme Court. Whilst it is a little more difficult for parents who still remember the old ways of their home, integration for their children comes more naturally.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Irish?

—There are plenty of them, too. It is St Patrick's Day today, is it not? The children of migrant parents often show a great understanding of the hardships faced by their parents and an understanding of the fact that their parents migrated to this country to give them opportunities which they never had in their own country. This fact is borne out by the number of participants in higher education who are the children of migrants. It is proportionately higher than that for children of the Australian born. People by and large appreciate the opportunity which their new life in Australia has provided them. The Government's and this Parliament's commitment to continue multiculturalism is essential, not just for humanitarian reasons, but also for economic considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986-87 migrants brought $2.1 billion into the country, which is vital for our country to overcome its balance of payments problem. But it is not just a matter of having migrants bring their money with them; it is the economic contribution which migrants who are here, and have been here for years, are making which needs to be considered. At the moment three-quarters of all of our exports are sold to non-English speaking countries. In the early 1950s it was only one-quarter. Why the change? The reason is that our multicultural society is acting to make us aware of what the world desires. The creation of markets in Australia which cater for a variety of foreign tastes has heightened our ability to trade with the rest of the world. In addition no-one should underestimate the effect on purchasing habits of personal letters sent by migrants to their relatives in foreign lands.

The motion being debated makes reference to English being the accepted national language. While this is obviously not in dispute, it is relevant to talk in the context of the economic benefits of multiculturalism about the benefits of a society filled with people who understand more than one language. After all, the language of international trade, it has been said, is not English but the language of the customer at the time. The proportion of secondary students currently studying a second language has declined markedly over the years. This is an alarming trend in what is encouraged to be a multicultural society. Multiculturalism has much to offer in the field of languages of which we should be more aware. For example, much has been done by the various ethnic groups themselves to teach their Australian children the home language.

In a whole range of ways the Australian Government, the private sector and, for that matter, the trade union movement need to lift their awareness of multiculturalism and the effect which cultural diversity has on individuals and the nation as a whole. In a speech at the end of last year at the Flinders University, the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs indicated that for the sake of efficiency, as much as equity, we as a nation cannot ignore the existence of cultural diversity. The benefits to employers of cultural awareness in the world of markets and economic hard times include lower levels of staff turnover, less industrial unrest and more cooperation. These have direct economic benefits for those who wish to pursue these policies.

It is heartening to see in the same context that this Government has provided funds to encourage tertiary institutions to have cross-cultural training incorporated into the training of future professionals. In the same speech as I mentioned before, the former Minister, of whom we have heard a lot over the last couple of weeks by way of certain conduct by the Opposition, revealed some disturbing statistics--

TALK.START.PARA: —All his own work.

—I am glad I got Opposition members to say something. It shows they are listening to my speech. In the same speech as I mentioned before, the former Minister revealed some disturbing statistics in relation to the work which migrants to this country are performing compared with the work they are doing in their home countries. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission survey of people undertaking an advanced English as a second language course at a technical and further education college found, firstly, that less than half the people who enjoyed skilled jobs abroad were similarly employed in Australia; secondly, that less than one in four who had office jobs were similarly employed here; and thirdly, that less than one in six who previously held professional or technical jobs were utilising those skills here. These are amazing stories, particularly when one considers that our current migration test-quite rightly in my view-takes into account the skills level of a particular applicant. It is reasonable to require migrants to have the skills necessary to be able to contribute to their new home in a positive way, but there is a massive inconsistency when, once they arrive, they find that conditions are such that these skills, for whatever reasons, are underutilised.

SPEECH.PARA: These facts point to the ongoing need to incorporate multiculturalism in the policies of government in the private sector and into the way of thinking of every Australian. It is through this incorporation that the economic and social benefits of multiculturalism can be realised. It should not be forgotten that the Business Council of Australia, which, not unlike the Liberal Party of Australia, is a representative organisation of business, seems to want to treat migrants as though they were raw material to be shipped in and out of the country as required. While the Business Council's suggestion to increase overall intake has merit because it will increase our consumer demand and arrest the population slide threatening our economy, to treat migration as a substitute for investing in Australians, including existing migrants and their children, is wrong. It is a quick fix approach to our training and education problems. It is the equivalent of wanting to buy a ready-made product from overseas rather than developing it in Australia. In this respect, it is the same attitude that has plummeted Australia into the external debt problem which we now face.

Earlier in my speech I offered the names of many prominent Italo-Australians as evidence of the extent of Italian integration into Australian society. I know from my contact with the Italian community that we are grateful to Australia and its community for the opportunity given to us to make this place our home. I regret that this can probably not be said of all the various ethnic groups which go into making our society. The process is often slow. This motion sets out the fundamental conditions which are necessary, both attitudinal and practical, for a successful multicultural society to thrive, and for this reason, I urge its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to support this motion moved by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). Given that 40 per cent of the Australian population either were born overseas or have one parent who was born overseas-and I am amongst that 40 per cent-and, perhaps more importantly, given that 25 per cent of Australians claim their ethnic roots as something different from the majority of Anglo-Celtic Australians, this debate assumes very great significance. Indeed, in my electorate of Chisholm, in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, there are large communities of people who were born in Southern Europe or South East Asia. They came to this country in recent years for very similar reasons to those why my family came to this country in the last century: looking for opportunity, looking for a future and looking for hope.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of multiculturalism is supported across both sides of the House. It is an issue that seeks tolerance, understanding and an acceptance of others who may have a vastly different background. It was born out of an aim for equality of opportunity rather than equality of outcome. It is far more than pizza or chianti; it is far more than accepting that we have a lot of restaurants in Lygon Street. It seeks a real understanding of people from different backgrounds.

I would like to address specifically some aspects of multiculturalism that are raised in this motion: the freedom to maintain one's cultural heritage within the context of a common legal and political system with English as the accepted national language. An individual is entitled to express his or her own identity. Some years ago I spent some time studying at the University of Wisconsin. In that state there are a large number of ethnic communities who, over 100 years after they settled in that state, still maintain very strong ethnic identities, particularly the Norwegians, the Swedes and the Finns. I visited a Norwegian community in which they still had a Norwegian-speaking church, the children were taught Norwegian, they had Back to Norway weekends and the children sought to go and visit the land that their great-grandparents and great-great-grandparents left. Yet in spite of this very strong identity with their cultural roots they were all great American patriots.

Part of my cultural heritage is part of my family that came from Scotland. On occasions I very proudly wear a Gunn tartan tie as evidence of my ethnic roots, even though that part of my family left Scotland over 140 years ago. Equally so, a newly arrived Australian has just as much or even more right to express his own cultural identity within the context of living in Australia.

Another aspect of this motion is freedom from discrimination. This is essential, as discrimination and the prejudice that it fuels eventually endanger society as a whole, because ultimately they deny us all the possibility of having a fair chance. This was put in A Man for All Seasons, when Sir Thomas More was speaking to William Roper and said, `And when the last law was down, and the Devil turned on you, where would you hide?'. This motion talks about equality of opportunity, which is absolutely fundamental to Liberal philosophy and Liberal policy. Indeed, in our own immigration and ethnic affairs policy at the last election we stated that `equality of opportunity is achieved when people of different backgrounds are able to participate in Australian society on the same basis as other Australian residents'.

This motion talks about policies and the services available to ethnic communities. This is a very important aspect as it is this area of multiculturalism that is most misunderstood. Many people believe that providing separate services may in itself lead to separatism. My Party has an extremely proud record in this area, about which I will talk in a moment. I do believe that people who come from different backgrounds, who are newly arrived in this country, may very validly require additional help and assistance in order to become full participating members of the Australian community. However, I do not agree with the views of those, generally on the extreme Left, who believe that people, by virtue of being immigrants to this country, particularly ones with a non-English speaking background, are cheap and malleable labour, and who see non-English speaking migrants and their children today as continuing victims of this system. It is very commonly accepted that people suffer disadvantage simply by virtue of not speaking English. Recent evidence has shown this not to be true, and the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) alluded to this.

A recent article by two Monash University researchers, concerning a longitudinal study over five years of 3,000 students in secondary education, showed that if a student came from a background where both parents did not speak English he had a greater chance, other things being equal, of completing schooling. They gave figures of groups of low IQ-whatever that means-and of low socioeconomic status whereby, if both parents came from a non-English speaking background, there was almost three times the chance of a student completing schooling as there was if both parents were born in Australia.

I wish to talk now about the achievements, and the proud achievements, of the previous Government formed by the Liberal Party of which I am a member. In terms of services to the ethnic community, the Fraser Government established the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs; created the Special Broadcasting Service; extended ethnic radio dramatically; established the English as a second language program and included a great upgrading of the facilities for teaching English as a second language; established the adult migrant program; established 16 new migrant settlement hostels, about which I will speak in a moment; employed ethnic health workers, ethnic children's service workers and ethnic workers for the aged; established migrant resource centres; established post-arrival programs; made a great extension of the telephone interpreter service and, as a doctor, that is something I have used many times; expanded the role of the information branch of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; and appointed ethnic liaison officers in the Commonwealth department.

These programs were aimed at helping newly arrived Australians to settle fully into the community. I do not wish to make this debate party political, but if we look at what is happening today we see that the Government has attempted to merge the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). We have recently seen a lengthy report on the future of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, but nothing at all has been said about the SBS. Migrant groups in my community are particularly concerned about the future of the SBS and are wondering whether it is in fact going to continue or whether its future is threatened. The English as a second language program has had its funding cut quite dramatically and the funds have not been restored. Of the six regional offices that were closed, after a great public outcry only two were reopened after it was shown that it made no economic sense whatsoever to close them in the first place.

The honourable member for Bowman mentioned that his Party had people of Ethnic background in State upper Houses. I wish to note on this occasion that my own Party in Victoria, in the seat of Waverley Province, part of which encompasses the Federal electorate of Chisholm, last Sunday preselected on the first ballot Savvas Grigoruepoulos, a man who is doing strong and active work in the Greek community and who will win that marginal seat. So, my Party, too, shows a commitment to giving people a wide range of ethnic backgrounds full and equal opportunity in this society.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the consideration of private members' business is concluded.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Soviet Union: Proposed New Embassy Site-Bondi-New South Wales Election-Road Funding-Harassment of Aboriginals-Death of the Most Reverend Sir Guilford Young-Conservationists-Queensland Local Government Elections

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity in today's Grievance Debate to raise a particularly disturbing matter of national security. What I am referring to is the offer by the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) to the Soviet Union of a new embassy site in the area bounded by Forster Crescent, Flynn Drive and Coronation Drive. The offer of this site is more than naive-it is downright stupid. The reason for the concern about this site is that it is in the critical foreshore area stretching from the Scrivener Dam to the East Basin on Lake Burley Griffin. The significance of this critical area is that it does put the en poste Russian intelligence service officers in a position where they can take full advantage of the direct line of sight the area offers to the Black Mountain telecommunications tower. Furthermore, it is perfectly placed to monitor a variety of communications from the diplomatic establishments of other nations, particularly those of our close allies. The friendly diplomatic establishments most affected are those of New Zealand, the United Kingdom and Canada, who will, if the NCDC gets its way, be direct neighbours of the Soviets. These three embassies are located on the opposite side of Forster Crescent. Perhaps it is the desire of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the words of his 1987 Singapore lecture, `We seek mutually beneficial cooperation with the Soviet Union in a sincere and open-minded way', that has led the NCDC to select this prime intelligence site as the new area for the new Soviet embassy.

SPEECH.PARA: I have ascertained that the NCDC in selecting this proposed site informed, but did not consult, the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). Had it consulted ASIO, as it should have done, it would have been informed that the site is regarded as entirely inappropriate, primarily because of the concerns regarding Soviet signals intelligence (SIGINT) activities but also because the site would pose enormous operational difficulties for our own security service. In addition, it has been brought to my attention that elements of the Defence Department, notably the Defence Signals Directorate, are extremely alarmed by the NCDC's offer of the site to the Soviets.

Whilst the United Kingdom's opposition to the NCDC's decision is well-known, it is the New Zealanders who have so far been the most vociferous opponents to this proposal. The New Zealanders have explained their feelings to the NCDC, which in turn has relayed them to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Some people would say that that could often be a mistake. That would appear to be the case because the doves in Foreign Affairs, who are always obsessed with never offending anybody about anything, have a vested interest in the Soviets acquiring a site of which the Soviets fully approve. Of course, the Soviets will fully approve only if the site accords them a better line of sight to the Black Mountain tower than their present location on Canberra Avenue in Griffith.

The vested interest I refer to relates to negotiations that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been having with the Soviets in an attempt to obtain a site for a new Australian embassy in Moscow. The present embassy at 13 Kropotkinsky Lane is considered too small and is now overlooked by a high-rise building dotted with antennae that are believed to be monitoring communications and other emissions from our embassy-another part of the Soviet's massive SIGINT operation. The greatest fear of the doves in Foreign Affairs is that any controversy about Soviet SIGINT operations in Canberra will impede their efforts to move to a larger site in Moscow. Therefore, it is apparent that Foreign Affairs' best interests are served by suppressing any controversy rather than comprehensively addressing it with a view to minimising the threat to Australia's national security.

The Soviet's SIGINT capability is massive. It is a worldwide effort and employs some 350,000 personnel. Of those, 1,000 are currently collecting SIGINT from diplomatic premises, including through their Canberra embassy. Approximately 55 Soviet employees are living and working in the Soviet embassy in Canberra, with about half a dozen engaged in SIGINT activities. Two areas of Soviet SIGINT interest in Canberra can be identified, and they are both fairly disturbing. The first is the monitoring of ASIO radio traffic through which the KGB resident can determine if and when covert operations might be mounted or ASIO counterintelligence operations frustrated. The second area of concern is the monitoring of Australian Government, diplomatic and military transmissions, the high frequency communications of other embassies and microwave telecommunications to and within Canberra.

In this respect, it is worth noting that the Black Mountain tower carries 70 per cent of telecommunications traffic into Canberra. It is a vital link in Australia's communications system. The Soviets had the good sense to recognise this basic reality very early on. In 1976-77, soon after it was announced that the tower was to be built on Black Mountain, the then Soviet Ambassador, Mr Basov, submitted a request asking for a site on which to build a new embassy, an ambassador's residence and staff quarters. The two sites proposed were on Red Hill or at Attunga Point. The Red Hill site was to be close to the Deakin centre. It should be noted that both sites have direct line of sight to the Black Mountain tower. It can be seen from this that the Soviets' interest in facilitating their SIGINT operations in Canberra is by no means a new phenomenon. Unless the NCDC has acquired amazing new talents of which the rest of us remain ignorant, I would have thought that the NCDC was the least qualified to determine where to locate a new Soviet embassy. The security implications involved in the siting of the Soviets' embassy should be the primary concern when selecting the site. From that it follows that ASIO, as the principal domestic authority on security matters, needs to be involved heavily in coordinating the selection of the new site.

I conclude by calling on the Prime Minister personally to intervene in this matter to ensure the protection of Australia's national security and put a decisive end to the interdepartmental wrangling that has been going on over the siting of the new Soviet embassy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I participate in the grievance debate today because of a possible threat facing a place dear to all Australians. I am talking about Bondi. Along with kangaroos, koalas, the Opera House and vegemite, Bondi means Australia all round the world. It is part of our national image and it is part of our national heritage. The threat is that, rather than Bondi being looked after, cared for, restored, preserved, Bondi as we know and love it could be irreparably damaged, its character destroyed, if current plans being implemented by the New South Wales Government are replaced by those of the Opposition. A battle is being waged for Bondi. It is between those who prefer an established environment with local traditions, and those who like or profit from the `sort of city of newer societies which encourage continual redevelopment and less complex city planning'. That statement is taken from an article written by Michael Dickinson in the Bulletin that I would like to talk about later. The battle is about those who prefer the urban development which is becoming more demanded by the public now and those who would wipe it aside for commercial profit.

SPEECH.PARA: What is it that makes Bondi so special? Why is it so associated in the public mind with our national and international image? It is a stunning and magnificent sight. Nothing will change the beach itself. Then there is Bondi the suburb. It is so near the city. It is so accessible to all Australians and it is so associated, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you are well aware, with the history of the great Australian surf life saving movement. Indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will agree-even though you have your own loyalties-that the surf life saving movement began in the Bondi area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chair cannot be brought into debate.

—I beg your pardon, Mr Deputy Speaker. Bondi the suburb is home for 20,000 people. Let me read from the Michael Dickinson article in the Bulletin to tell honourable members a little of the history of Bondi and why it has become the way it is. Michael Dickinson said:

SPEECH.PARA: The locals have long seen Bondi as a special place. For centuries, the vast sand dunes separating the ocean from the harbour were used by the Port Jackson tribes as workshops to produce stone implements. After 1897, the Bondi tram deposited much newer tribes at the southern end of the beach . . .

They were those who came to visit the aquarium and roller coaster at the Tamarama Wonderland and those who trekked over the sandhills to Sydney's largest two-up school at North Bondi. He goes on to say that the dunes were subdivided in the 1920s and 1930s when Campbell Parade became a resort fronting a mostly lower middle class hinterland. He pointed out that of course the rich in Sydney always used the harbour as their watering hole. Then the colonnaded beach pavilion was completed in 1928 and Bondi dubbed itself the playground of the Pacific. After the war, like other similar resorts at St Kilda, and Miami in Florida, Bondi went out of fashion and settled into a scruffy somnolence. Now, of course, like St Kilda and Miami, Bondi has once again become hot property and the stories are similar.

The battle for Bondi is on. There is a big difference between the attitudes of the two political parties struggling for government in New South Wales. Let us look initially at the attitude of the New South Wales Government towards Bondi and what it has been doing for Bondi. The New South Wales Government recognises, first, that each year millions of tourists visit Bondi and, second, that thousands of people work and live in Bondi; 20,000 people call Bondi home. Bondi is a dynamic, commercial, and recreational centre. The Government of New South Wales says that to preserve Bondi we do not stop change. To preserve Bondi we guide change so that the future stays true to the past; so that its greatest asset, the beach, is not ruined; so that its 20,000 residents, as well as those who visit the area, can enjoy it more. To preserve Bondi the Government of New South Wales recognises that we need a plan. That Government, along with Waverley Council, led by the local member Ernie Page, have a plan, and that plan is already working.

The Bondi beachfront park redevelopment has already seen much work completed. There has been brick paving of paths and roadways, landscaping, and the planting of native plant varieties has been carried out already by Waverley Council and the New South Wales Government. On 22 January Premier Unsworth announced that beachfront development would be limited to five storeys. That means the beachfront park will not be overshadowed by high rise towers nor will it be swept by wind gusts created by anti-social overdevelopment. That announcement is in stark contrast to some of the desires of Liberal Party members. The five-storey limit is a positive decision to shape the future. Values along the beachfront will stabilise. Renovating existing buildings is now a good investment. Vacant land will not have its price inflated by speculative buyers. New developments will be approved on the ground that they fit in with existing building and services.

To enhance the existing buildings, colour schemes of beachfront buildings will be guided by an overall plan that will reduce costs. Already the New South Wales Department of Environment and Planning has released a draft scheme for repainting premises along the beachfront. A community-based committee was set up a couple of years ago by Ernie Page, which has been looking at the beachfront development and has approved the plan for repainting. The paints will be provided at discount prices and already several owners are very enthusiastic about the scheme. The colours will be in harmony with the style of the area and, of course, with the beach.

This plan for Bondi is a complete plan. It has the support of the residents and of all Australians who value this part of the nation's heritage. Ernie Page and the New South Wales Government is committed to implement the plan. But what of the Opposition in New South Wales? Mr Greiner says that Waverley is high on the priority list for the Tourism Commission. Does that mean that Bondi will be taken over by the commission? If that happens, who will protect the needs of the residents? With that type of government will its members be completely heedless of the wishes of the residents, as the Liberal council was when it was in control in Waverley. That is exactly what it did; it rejected the wishes of the residents in relation to Bondi. That Liberal council was rejected at the September local government elections; it was thrown out. Indeed, one of the candidates who gained election last September ran on the single issue of the preservation of Bondi beach and the suburb of Bondi.

At least one Liberal alderman is talking about Bondi being our Darling Harbour. Does that mean that the Opposition will allow, as one has projected, a 15-storey limit along Campbell Parade instead of the five-storey limit proposed by Mr Unsworth. Mr Greiner has talked about 50 per cent restoration and 50 per cent development along the beach front, but which half is going to be knocked down? Which half will he restore? Bondi pavilion is the absolute heart of the community of Bondi and the place that the Liberal council wanted to commercialise by selling it to the Hastings Development, but that proposal was totally rejected by the community. They do not even mention the pavilion. The Bondi pavilion is the heart of the community of Bondi. It has recently be repainted, it offers an information centre, a currency exchange, a gift shop, vacation and after-school child care, educational courses and exhibition space; it is a popular venue for public meetings, concerts, dance and drama performances and other activities.

Let us look at the public attitude to urban environment nowadays. We have come a long way; people simply will not accept wholesale unplanned development. Bondi is home to 20,000 people but the Libs just have not caught up with that. They do not represent the interests of the people, they represent the interests of the developers. There is no doubt Ernie Page will be re-elected because the people in Bondi have known him for over 25 years. His understanding of the electorate assures his re-election but the fact is that we need a New South Wales Labor Government to preserve Bondi for the people of Australia and for all Australians. Bondi needs not only Ernie Page; it will continue to have him, and it must have the New South Wales Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Local Government Association of New South Wales has been very forthright, because it has looked at some of the options that are being examined at present. Those are four very important issues, so far as we are concerned.

Mr Deputy Speaker, let it be quite clear that for the past five years we have not seen any increase in moneys coming from the Commonwealth to the States, to local government, for road funding purposes in Australia. Twelve hundred and forty-five million dollars is the amount-we have pointed this out time and time again when the legislation comes yearly before the House-but that is a 31 per cent cut in real terms of the money to be available. There has been a 31 per cent cut since 1984-85. All the options that are being considered at the present time would appear to be the options that may maintain the present level or cause a reduction in the funding for roads generally throughout the Commonwealth.

The present level of funding from the Commonwealth is 5.333c a litre, of which 2c is from the Australian bicentenary road program. There is 5.333c under the Australian Land Transport Fund. There is a strong argument for the indexing of, say, 6c a litre for money to be returned to the States and to the councils for roads. There is a general dissatisfaction of the States with the funding, particularly over the allocations and very much so so far as a designation of those categories is concerned. Local roads particularly need a guaranteed increased annual funding. The councils feel that at least 25 per cent of the tax returned ought to go to our local roads and particularly the rural local roads throughout the Commonwealth.

I know that we must have increases for national roads, but we do not want to see the money going to national roads to the disadvantage of the arterial and the local roads generally throughout the Commonwealth. The Shires Association of New South Wales and the Local Government Association met on 29 February. There were 350 representatives of local government throughout the State present and they voiced the very concerns that I have just been speaking about. They then issued a communique of the meeting which has appeared in the Press.

Local government looks after approximately 80 per cent of the roads within Australia. They are its total responsibility. The other 20 per cent are the responsibility of the governments. As I said earlier, a number of the States, particularly New South Wales, have their own petrol tax, from which they collect approximately $200m per year. But none of that funding, we are told, goes back on to the roads and the bridging or the maintenance or actual construction of the roads within New South Wales.

Let us look today at the need for the extra funds because of the damage that is caused to roads, particularly by the increased traffic. Of course, there has been a lot in the Press lately concerning death by guns and it has been pointed out in an advertisement in the local State papers I have before me that substandard roads kill 150 times as many people as weirdos with guns do. It points out the reasons. These are facts, because it is not the gun problem which is of concern today but to a great degree the condition of the roads throughout the Commonwealth. I could say a lot today about the Pacific Highway because the chief engineer of the National Roads and Motorists Association has made certain comments concerning the roadway. He said that it is totally inadequate to meet the demands that are made upon it today.

It is one of the busiest routes in Australia yet the overtaking is still effectively stopped for 52 per cent of its length and 468 curves still require speed warning signs. Even though it is not a national road, the Pacific Highway warrants a special grant not only to maintain it but also to improve it and get rid of the inadequacies and black spots along its entire length. Those are the facts. It is estimated that it is costing Australia $5,700m a year because of the deaths on the roads of the Commonwealth. That is one of our greatest killers today and if the Government wants to talk about priorities--

There had been two meetings previous to my attendance. Some of the Aboriginal people-men and women-were suggesting that they start defending themselves; that they get their own guns and start protecting their homes.

I sought permission to speak once these types of things were being said and I spoke against the law being taken into people's own hands. I suggested also that I would undertake to go and meet the police, either after that meeting or immediately on the Monday, to see what the police had done about the complaints that had been given to them about a week before.
