They also wanted to go public to try to engender a bit of interest in the police force so that they might act and do something about the complaints that had been made before.

I was informed at that meeting that the Human Rights Commission had already been asked to come so I said to the leaders that they needed to make sure that they were fair about it. I urged them to prepare a submission that could go to the police prior to its going to the Human Rights Commission otherwise they would simply have police saying, `We did not know about it'.

On the Monday following that meeting, the seventh, I met with police at 12 o'clock and put to them the concerns that people had. The result I got was mainly one of anger about the publicity and they claimed that there had been some sort of breakdown in communications. They had tried to contact the Legal Aid Service in the past but nothing came of it. I went to some pains to urge the police that the investigation that they should carry out should be centred on the harassment claims and that a claim about sighting some people in gowns up on Mount Archer was another issue. I said that they should put that aside. I told the Human Rights Commission exactly the same thing because I felt that the real issue was harassment and that they ought to check out why people were saying that these people who were harassing them in some instances were like the KKK.

I did not want the issue clouded and the police promised to investigate everything, but clearly they were angry that none of the Aboriginal and Islander people had come to them. They said there were 85 police officers in the town and no-one had been approached. But they did start a full inquiry, which I think started really Monday afternoon, but regrettably finished Thursday morning because they rang the legal service people and told them that they were closing off the whole thing at 12 o'clock, and if they had anything else to bring they ought to get the people up there. It was rather ridiculous that they would do this and I suggest that the police have trivialised and ridiculed all the aspects of this matter.

I suggest that they should not have got involved in this Mount Archer issue about the gowned people because it had nothing to do with the harassment issue. But that is what they did. They centred their whole investigation on a claim by Anita Brown, who unfortunately made a mistake about the date she was up there. The fact that she made a mistake is immaterial because there have been 14 pages of statements of people who have seen strange happenings on Mount Archer.

A white man and woman found a scorched cross on Mount Archer. There have been couples who saw a procession of fire sticks on Mount Archer. A Mount Archer resident came across candles and all sorts of items in the rocks that had been part of a ritual and two other families saw a burning cross only a week or so ago half-way up the mountain. But the police still put their emphasis on that and I think that was regrettable, because later on they came out and said that what was on Mount Archer was a Christian group. They made a joke of it and ridiculed everything that Anita Brown said.

They also came out with a report saying that the car they had investigated had, in fact, been driven by Aboriginal people. They did not bother to talk about the other three registrations that had been given to them; they simply centred on that. Then they came back to a group called SPONGE, which regrettably the Caroll at 7 program on Channel 7 in Brisbane also ridiculed and made fun by saying that this was just a drinking group of students, despite the fact that the SPONGE group was called the Society for the Prevention of Niggers Getting Everything which appeared in posters in April 1986; despite the fact that the local institute said there was no such drinking group at that time nor has there been; and despite the fact that the fellow went on Channel 7 and told the police that he was a student, which was a lie.

He is not a student but the police centred on this and made it public to make a joke of what did happen back in 1986 when a group from the institute were going to harass Aboriginal people. As it was, the administration of the institute reprimanded that fellow and really put him down because of the very sick and racist joke that he had been involved in.

I want to raise the point here as to why I believe the police have tried to whitewash this issue, as I said in the media, whiter than Tom Sawyer's fence. The reason is, Mr Deputy Speaker, that they know that if this investigation goes any further and into some depth, it will be the police who will be targeted. It will be the police who will have to answer. I say this because of the reports that have taken place not just in April 1986 but also in more recent times. Only last week a man in Rockhampton sustained wounds that he claims were forced upon him by a dog that was held by police. The wounds, as a doctor has said, are consistent with a dog attack and his bruised and tender sternum is in keeping with his claim of having been kicked by the police. That happened only last week.

Only a few months ago an Aboriginal juvenile, of something like 14 or 15 years of age, claimed that he was with a group of young people when the police came along; they started to run away; they were called to stop and when they did not stop the police put the dog on the boy. There is a medical report that backs up, again, that the wound is as if a dog had bitten him. The interesting thing here is that, whilst the police went after the boys, they did not even bother to question them, nor did they charge anyone. We also had a situation last year where a white witness came forward to the Legal Aid Service about an incident at the airport when the police with their dog squad had called on a fellow in some pipes to come out and give himself up, or they would put the dog on him. As the witness says, the fellow gave himself up and then they put the dog on him. Is it any wonder the people out there are concerned?

Other allegations have been given to the legal service and also to Father Neil Forgie, an Anglican priest who works with Aboriginal people. An allegation has been made of a police car driving past an Aboriginal meeting place with a policeman hanging his arms out of the window and going rat-a-tat-tat, as if he had a machine gun.

We have had allegations, too, of an attempted arson of a car in which some Aboriginal people had slept. There have been two allegations of attempted arson and fire bombing-one, admittedly, in 1984. The police caught two fellows and charged them. But the last one I do not believe they even investigated-a fire bomb against the Toonoonba meeting centre. There have been allegations of uniformed men putting dogs on people down at the river bank and throwing their belongings into the river; of people being refused entry into nightclubs; of overcharging in an hotel; of children being stopped in the street and threatened; and of hooded men sitting outside a house where Aboriginal people live.

There are problems on both sides of the street, I realise that, because there are allegations also of whites being bashed by blacks. I note, and I want to say it emphatically, that Rockhampton is not a racist city, but we do have a problem, and this problem must be investigated thoroughly. It is not proper for police simply to cast it aside because they might have the spotlight put on them in the future. I also believe it is time that the Channel 7 Caroll at 7 program got a bit of a conscience, because I believe it contrived the whole program that it did in Rockhampton, by bodgying up a group of fellows drinking in a club, pretending that they were some sort of drinking club.

I want it said in this House, and I say it, that I do not intend to back away from my responsibilities to pursue the case of justice for the citizens whom I represent and I do not care what colour they are. I think it is time that police took away the blinkers and realised that there is a problem; that people have been harassed; that their dog squad is in the centre of this; that police officers have taken a wrong attitude, even threatening to charge members who came forward giving false information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) and the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) join with me today in mourning the passing of the Catholic Archbishop of Hobart. Neither is a Catholic, I am a Catholic, but I am sure that they join with me in remembering the Archbishop of Hobart, the Most Reverend Sir Guilford Young, who died yesterday. He was born in 1916, the son of a Queensland shearer who was an Anglican and later became a Catholic. He was educated at the Presentation Convent in Longreach, where he won a scholarship to the Christian Brothers College at Rockhampton. From there he went to St Columbans College in the Blue Mountains to begin his studies for the priesthood. In 1934 he entered the Propaganda College in Rome.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Guilford was a most fluent speaker, eloquent, with a brilliant command of the English language, and was a great Tasmanian and a very charitable man and his passing will be mourned by many Catholics in Tasmania, in Australia, and by many other non-Catholics throughout Australia. He was a very charitable man. He and I had our differences. Of course, everybody differs with me, but there was one thing that we always stood together on and that was our hatred of communism. Sir Guilford got very embroiled in the communist influences a long time ago and he was attributed with many controversial remarks on communism. He was quoted as saying: `If we do not stop it in South Vietnam, it will embrace not only all of south and South East Asia but even Africa and Latin America as a preliminary to world domination'. He continually said that and I think he was right.

It is St Patrick's Day today and I love the colour green. I notice that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) is at the table wearing green. She remarked, `Why am I always in the House when you are here?'. Mr Deputy Speaker, of course, has green on and I am wearing a green tie. But I have come to hate the colour green and I will tell you why. It is because of the greenies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was about to say that this might just be out of order.

—No, I am too cunning for that. I have come to hate it and I have become paranoid about it. When the decision was handed down by the judges of the High Court the other day, I was extremely upset, like many other Tasmanians. I thought to myself that these judges--
—You cannot impugn the judges.
—I have parliamentary privilege, have I not? I will do what I like in here, thank goodness.
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin may have parliamentary privilege, but the standing order provides that you cannot call into question the activities of the judiciary.

—All right. I can talk about these legal gentlemen who have had very little experience of getting up early in the morning and going out to chop a tree down and trying to work with their hands to survive. I am afraid that that is what has happened in Australia today. Regrettably the once famous Labor Party, those fellows who supported the workers, has gone. The honourable member for Denison is in the chamber and we will have some arguments over the years. When I saw him sitting down with the greenies having a drink of champagne with them I thought, `Well, Duncan, you have to represent those workers out in the northern suburbs, mate. You want to be very careful at the next election because they will turn away from you'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have found that one cannot have it both ways in this world. One cannot support these greenies, and I use the term `greenies' because I have found that they are the most difficult people to deal with, as the honourable member for Braddon knows. They are the most difficult people. They are like people who want it all their own way. I do not agree with everybody, honourable members know that. If one does not agree with them, one is the worst person in the world and everywhere one goes they make it very difficult for one. They are very, very cunning.

They conned the old Hawke Government. The night before the election when Hawke became Prime Minister I said to the honourable member for Braddon, `They are going to win that dams issue'. Mrs Hawke had `Save the Dams' on her earrings affixed to her ears and I thought to myself, `They are going to win that'. The honourable member said, `No, Bruce, they will not win the dams issue'. They won it, and that is only the beginning. They got into bed with the Labor Party or the Labor Party got into bed with them and they will live to regret it. I have been watching a few advertisements about the Monaro electorate-`Come on, Mr Unsworth, you have sold us down the chute'. They are very, very good advertisements and they are going to influence a lot of ordinary, hardworking people. When the judges made that decision on the dam, they did not know very much about those poor workers who had their trucks and their families-the old Labor Party.

I do not mind dealing with the people within the Labor Party; perhaps their representatives in here are all right. They are here to represent people like me; they do not just stick to one thing. They are not so bad, but they have got embroiled with these greenies who are only using them. The greenies are only using them and they have got so involved they cannot get out. Poor old Duncan is over there-`Have a drink with Duncan'. The workers out in the northern suburbs will not, Duncan, at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would ask that the honourable member refer to other honourable members by their correct title.

—The honourable member for Denison; they will be watching him very closely, having a few drinks with the greenies. They will be watching him and those workers out there will say to themselves, `This is not a Labor man. Crikey, he is a greenie, he has lost touch'. I have been reading a few editorials about this decision. Coming back to the judges again, I can say what I like about the judges.
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin--
—They are not elected by the people.

—Order! The honourable member for Franklin should realise that standing order 75 provides that he cannot cast aspersions on members of the judiciary except by substantive motion. If he wishes to criticise a judgment of the courts, I imagine that that would be in order, but he cannot criticise the judges.

—All right, the judgment. I will go back to that judgment. We have people making decisions who are not elected by the people. They are placed in positions by governments and by other people. Then all of a sudden they can override a State decision. Really what they are doing, as the honourable member for Braddon knows, is slowly eroding the rights of a government to make decisions-for example, on the dams issue. On this last decision, 30 per cent of Tasmania is locked up already and we have these silly, rotten coots from the mainland who think that it is a haven to put a haversack on their backs and have a look at the beauty down there. They forget about the ordinary people down there who earn a living from the bush, who earn a living from chopping down the trees to provide the timber for Parliament House. The roof in this building is made of blackwood. They forget all about that, all because they think it should stay as it is and nobody should touch it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a letter-I will pull it out of my pocket where I put it this morning-about a lady from Launceston. She is one of those greenies, one of those who are rude to me everywhere I go. They say: `That is Bruce Goodluck; turn your back on him'. Everywhere I go, they are rude. I am reminded of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) the other night. I know that the honourable member for Denison was not the cause of it. I went there, not to help the ABC, because I think at times it has gone overboard with the greenies, with the conservationists on the dams issue. I am still bitter about that. There are a lot of good employees at the ABC and there are going to be changes there. So I went there to represent them but I knew that I would not get to first base because most of the people there are of the same yolk-that is not a foul one either. But they are all the same, they are all of that same type and are against us.

They are trying to beat us at every opportunity but they will not, because the average, ordinary working person in Tasmania is starting to realise what is going on. We are being taken over and the Unsworth Government, mark me, will lose on Saturday. It will lose because the workers and their families are starting to realise that this is not the old Labor Party of the past; not like my poor, late father who was a member of it. He was a union secretary who worked to give me a good education. He would not be a member of this Labor Party. As I have said before, in 1983, Mr Hawke is like Dorian Grey-he has sold his soul to the devil and by `the devil' I mean the greenies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Saturday, 19 March, elections will be held to elect representatives of the people on a system of electoral boundaries which is unfair, which is undemocratic and which will lead to the election of people unwanted by the majority of the electorate. This electoral system is supported by a State government which is interested in maintaining a system which is to its political advantage but to the disadvantage of the vast majority of voters.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you may be relieved to realise that I am not speaking of the State election in New South Wales but of the Queensland local government elections. Local government in Queensland is older than the State itself, as Brisbane was incorporated into a local authority area some time before Queensland separated from New South Wales. Local government in Queensland is 45 years older than our national Government. Local government in Queensland is on the whole elected on boundaries which are nearing their centenary and which have not been comprehensively reviewed in those 100 years.

The first comprehensive Queensland legislation on local government was the Municipal Institutions Act of 1864 which embodied the voluntary method of incorporation by petition from residents in local districts. This method was abandoned and replaced some 15 years later by the Local Government Act of 1877. Further refinement and amendment continued in the 1880s, culminating in a royal commission on local government which reported in 1896. Its recommendations form the basis of the existing system in Queensland and were largely implemented through the Local Authorities Act of 1902.

Between 1902 and 1936, reforms provided for universal adult franchise, compulsory voting, direct election of chairmen by the electors and triennial elections. The greater city program during 1916 to 1919 expanded Ipswich, Charters Towers, Maryborough, Toowoomba, Bundaberg, Townsville and Rockhampton. Greater Brisbane was created in 1924 and incorporated some two cities, six towns and then 10 shires. In 1927, there was a royal commission on local authorities boundaries but its recommendations were not acted upon to any large extent and only in 1948 were some boundaries altered as proposed.

In 1957, when the Country Party won office in Queensland, local government was in fairly reasonable shape. For instance, at the 1952 council election for the Shire of Pine Rivers-which is the major council within my electorate-the proportion of voters for each of the three electoral divisions was as follows: division 1, 896 voters; division 2, 1,209 voters; and division 3, 722 voters. As honourable members can see, there was a rough equality between those three electoral divisions.

In the mid-1970s the then Deputy Premier of Queensland, Sir Gordon Chalk, commissioned the Queensland University's Department of Town and Regional Planning to undertake a study of local government in Queensland. A feature of this report was a recommendation that Queensland was the only State that had not commissioned a complete review of its local council boundaries and that this review was long overdue. The majority of the boundaries existing in Queensland was drawn in the 1880s and the 1890s. No action was taken on this report.

In the late 1970s the Government did intervene in some nine councils to introduce single-member ward divisions, but this was without local resident or council input. However, no comprehensive review has been taken of Queensland local government boundaries since the 1880s. As a result of the Queensland Government's deliberate inaction, many Queensland voters on Saturday will vote on boundaries which are simply a rort. They favour the National Party, especially those candidates who hide under the utterly false claims of being independents. For instance, in the Shire of Pine Rivers some 600 voters in one division can elect one councillor, while in another division it takes 6,000 voters to elect a single councillor.

The fact that the State Government's motive is to maintain a political advantage for its supporters rather than their simple incompetence is revealed by the actions in Pine Rivers. In Pine Rivers the council took the initiative of inviting public submissions for a new electoral system. Having done this and getting overwhelming public support for a system which removed the sort of anomaly which I have just outlined, the council then requested the State Government to change its internal electoral boundaries, so that some fairness was removed. The Government for nearly one year simply refused to reply to this request. This was despite numerous follow-ups to the local government department and to the Minister.

After that year a simple letter was received saying that no action would be taken; no reasons were given, simply that no action would be taken. The National Party-the National Party State Government, in my opinion-perceives that it benefits from the existing system in Pine Rivers. It refuses a request from a council, supported by the majority of the councillors on that council, to bring in a new system. It not only refuses the request, it does not have the courtesy to reply for one year to the request and when it does reply it simply says, `No, we are not going to agree to this'. No reasons are given, it simply ignores it.

I have contacted the new Minister for Local Government in Queensland, Mr Randell, and I am pleased to report that he has agreed to meet with me to discuss particularly the situation in Pine Rivers but also the overall situation of local government boundaries in Queensland. This meeting will obviously take place after the council elections on Saturday. However, I wish to make some points clear. If this meeting with the Minister fails to convince me that the so-called new-look Ahern National Party Government will tackle the problem of unfairness in local government in Queensland, then I will ask for some assistance from this Government.

Currently the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters is considering the Michael Macklin Bill on electoral systems in Australia. I believe that this Committee should expand its terms of reference to have a look at the situation in local government. If at some time later this year or early next year a referendum is to be put to the Australian people on the question of one vote one value, I believe the Government should give very serious consideration to its implications for local government, for local residents are equally entitled to have the same sort of guaranteed fairness towards the election of their local representatives as they are towards the election of their State and their Federal representatives.

The principles, the questions are equal-it is all about providing people with the right to choose, the right to choose in a fair system. This is a major challenge which faces the new National Party Government in Queensland. It is a challenge which it must tackle if it is to retain any credibility as a government which is willing to consult, which is willing to take into account the views of the public. In the past its record has been poor and, as I have outlined, it has refused to accept the views of an individual council. I hope that it is simply an outside example.
