DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Bicentennial Products-Sale of Goods to Children-Nursing Homes-Tobacco Advertising-Australian Media-South Africa-Proposed Telecom Charges-Commonwealth Bank-Tariff Cuts-Archbishop of Hobart: Death-Medibank Agencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, thank you for the honour to be the first to make this quick statement. I am highly offended by an advertisement that recently appeared in a magazine in Australia. It is extremely divisive and I will just read parts of it. It says: `Be a green and gold Aussie for the Bicentenary. If you are a real Aussie then these products are definitely for you. Beautifully made in striking green and gold, our national colours. They represent the true spirit of Australia. Be a proud and green Australian'.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that are for sale is a flag in these colours which is advertised as an Australian flag-`Fly an Australian flag', it says-and there is a flag with a kangaroo on it. But there is also a T-shirt which is available and which I will show it to honourable members. It has on it this flag and underneath it has `The Republic of Australia'.

I think that is highly misleading and the people who are promoting this are misleading Australia. They are being extremely divisive and it should be offensive to all people who believe in the Constitution. It shows a complete lack of respect for the monarchy because we are still a constitutional monarchy and I think it is up to the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to investigate this matter. Finally, Madam Speaker, I seek leave to table a copy of this advertisement.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I want to appeal to the State governments, irrespective of their political persuasion, to act to address problems in the marketplace where violent and unfit goods are being placed on sale in stores frequented by children. Some weeks ago I raised the matter of edible condoms, edible panties and edible jockettes being sold by home improvement firms in amongst toys and dolls and things like that. There was also `Happy Sperm' soap and 18 months ago chocolate ice block moulds used for children were actually in the shape of vaginas and penises, actually sold in a grocery store.

SPEECH.PARA: I just do not think it is satisfactory that we should have these types of things on sale in this country. We have pornographic comics being sold, we have the victim and violent toys being sold and the point is that the Federal Government does not have any power. It is up to the States to come to grips with the retailing activities of those in the marketplace.

I do not think any honourable member here would believe that we ought to have pornographic comics that are promoting violence and violent sex sold in newsagencies. Even incest is in one of the comics given to me by a local minister. There is a need for a greater responsibility of retailers, a code of retailing and for them to put aside the cash register mentality where children are involved. So I make this appeal that the States come together with the Federal Government to let us set down a code, let us set down some laws that will control the marketing of products where children frequent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I would like to draw to the attention of the House a problem that I have in my electorate concerning nursing homes. Recently an elderly lady, who lives with her husband in a nursing home, was taken to a hospital to have an amputation. As soon as possible she was reunited with her husband at the nursing home where she had to have dressings on her amputation wound. The problem is that in nursing homes the Government allows only from 15c per day per resident to about 30c per day per resident for non-prescriptive items. So over a period of a month this lady had a bill of $400.

SPEECH.PARA: Who is to pay for it? The doctors are not to pay for it, the hospital cannot pay for it, the nursing home certainly cannot pay for it because it is outside its jurisdiction and it just cannot afford to pay for it. I think this is a disgraceful situation which the Government must look at. I do not think 15c today will cover the price of a band-aid and the labour to apply that band-aid. So I would ask the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to look at this situation in order that people in nursing homes receive their proper attention and the nursing homes need not go broke when these matters arise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use this opportunity to issue a challenge to the publishers of major Australian newspapers and magazines to exercise some social responsibility and ethics in what they publish. My great concern is that so many magazines and newspapers continue to publish what I believe are reprehensible advertisements by tobacco companies trying to encourage young children to smoke. I believe that all members of the House ought to unite behind the call I am issuing to ensure not only that these publishers fulfil their minimum legal responsibilities but also that they go beyond that and take up the sort of moral values and standards that Australian of the Year in 1987, Dick Smith, has sought to instil in business.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that it falls to those newspapers and to those publishers to take that stand because the tobacco companies clearly are out to encourage young Australians to smoke. One of the most reprehensible campaigns is that initiated by Amatil Ltd in its attempt to encourage a greater market for its product Freeport. The promotion of these cigarettes is directed towards teenagers and towards the children of the mothers and fathers around Australia and it is about time that we, as an Australian community, adopted the approach that is increasingly being adopted around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I want to renew today my call for a royal commission into the ownership and control of the Australian media. I believe it is of paramount importance that we are in no doubt that there is a diversity of ownership and that the owners do not interfere with the way in which the editors and the journalists write what they believe to be correct about Australia. There is nothing more important than the flow of information, ideas, opinion and news and yet we are seeing examples of news management, particularly by the Murdoch Press.

SPEECH.PARA: I find the greatest difficulty in getting information into Murdoch Press even when it is written and I know it is written by journalists employed by News Ltd. There are links between News Ltd and the Packer organisation regarding the Canberra Times, there are links between News Ltd and other people allegedly in competition with them in Adelaide. We have seen the closure of the Brisbane Telegraph and the Sydney Sun and now the Times on Sunday and many closures are not just related to declining circulation or the mismanagement by Fairfax but to other deals that we all know are being done in the marketplace.

It is time we examined the relationship between Murdoch and certain of the television station owners, especially Mr Lowy, and it is time that the Australian public was satisfied. It can be satisfied only by a royal commission into this most important area so that we know that this commodity which is different from any other is being administered in the interests of the public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday six black residents of Sharpeville are due to be executed by hanging, three days short of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the infamous 1960 Sharpeville massacre during which 69 black people were killed when South African police opened fire on demonstrators protesting against apartheid. The executions will take place, not because the six prisoners physically killed anyone, but because they were part of an angry crowd which beat the deputy mayor of Sharpeville to death for suspected collaboration with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Government leaders from all over the world have made pleas to President Botha for clemency for the Sharpeville six, but mercy for black people in South Africa is not high on the political agenda of the Botha Government. Our own Government has added its protests against the appalling and inhumane sentence in support of which no evidence was presented but which was based on a doctrine which allows African judges to rule that all members of the crowd shared a common purpose guilt with the unidentified murderers.

Apartheid is a creed which strikes at the core of humanitarian values and transcends all normal differences in political ideologies. South Africa should be outlawed from all world activities and, whilst I in no way condone the killing of the black councillor, I hope that our Government will, in recognition of the Sharpeville six who may be forced to pay the supreme sacrifice, scale down our diplomatic representation in Pretoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, the new system in relation to petitions prevented me from presenting a petition today and I would like quickly to read it. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: To the honourable members of the Parliament: If the Federal Government in its deep community concern intended supporting Telecom's proposal to charge local telephone calls according to length of time of the call, the undersigned call on the Hawke Government to indicate immediately that it would not give the approval required to make Telecom's proposal reality.

Unfortunately, the wording of that petition was such that it was not accepted under the new rules and I am passing it on to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans). It is a great pity because this petition would have set a record today, under the new system, of 9,248 signatures. It is an indication of how the people of Australia feel and I would say to the people of New South Wales right now who might be listening that I am not convinced that the Hawke Government has not just put it away until after Saturday. That is the way it performs all the way through. Be on your mettle and be alert and do not trust them as people in this country have sadly in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two and a half years ago I urged the Commonwealth Bank to establish a branch at Monbulk and/or Mount Evelyn, two rapidly expanding townships in my electorate. The shopping centres have grown quickly but bank customers have had to travel five to 10 kilometres to have access to a Commonwealth Trading Bank or the Development Bank. The bank replied that the townships would be studied and I would be kept informed. Last month I advised the people's bank that its monitoring of the situation had not led to any action but in the meanwhile private banks, including a new branch of the Challenge Bank, had further consolidated their positions.

SPEECH.PARA: I was staggered a few weeks ago when the bank's response was to admit that it had missed the bus but hoped to set up an electronic funds transfer at point of banking system at the Mount Evelyn and Monbulk post offices. This is simply not good enough for a government owned bank. Rather than downgrading its services, making it ripe for privatising, the Commonwealth Bank should be injecting real competition into the industry through more initiative and by setting an example of service and standards. This area, a farming community, with small businesses, is thus missing out on a service unique to the Commonwealth Bank-the Development Bank with low interest loans for approved enterprises.

Privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank would not increase the level of competition but reduce it and the community would lose an important avenue of government policy at the grass roots. I urge the Government and the Board to revitalise the people's bank rather than bend to demands to sell it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no better time than now for the Government to revitalise the economy by bringing in an across the board tariff cut. Tariff levels were put in place years ago when the exchange rate of the Australian dollar was much higher than it is today. Since then our dollar has collapsed by 35 to 40 per cent. This has forced import prices up by a similar amount, resulting in a de facto increase in protection to protected industries over and above the levels previous governments intended they should have.

SPEECH.PARA: Tariff protection imposes an enormous cost on society. We do not want to add to that burden through windfall increases that have flowed through from a devaluation of the currency. We could reduce tariff and other forms of protection by substantial amounts and still leave our protected industries in a position at least as favourable as before. The winners of a tariff cut would ultimately be all of us, but especially our export industries, our consumers and our industries with little or no protection.

Basic items like clothes, shoes and cars would tumble in price. This would reduce inflation and so ease the pressure on wage rises. The low income earners and pensioners in society would be especially advantaged as the poorest 20 per cent of them now pay more in tariff taxes than they do in income taxes. Jobs overall would not be lost but rather increased and located in more productive areas. The concept of an across the board tariff cut is an exciting one and I urge the Government to grasp the magic moment that exists and to do it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to add my voice to the expressions of sympathy that have already been put before the House by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) in respect of the death of the Archbishop of Hobart, the Very Reverend Archbishop Sir Guilford Young. Sir Guilford Young was an articulate and widely respected spokesman of the Catholic community in Hobart and he will be mourned by many of nearly one-quarter of the Hobart population who profess the Catholic faith. Let me say that he certainly was a controversial man who involved himself in the controversies of the day and there were instances where he expressed views which I am certain I would have been strongly against.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, he was always a rigorous and vital intellectual force in the community. He always articulated the views in which he professed his belief and I join with the honourable member for Franklin in expressing, on behalf of this House and in my particular concern on behalf of the people of Denison, our last respects to the former Archbishop of Hobart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even at this late stage I want to appeal to the Government to change its mind over the closure of Medibank agencies. The Government is bringing in this measure which will be very damaging and difficult for people living in country areas throughout Australia. Through the tax system the Government is forcing people throughout this country to participate in Medicare but through closing agencies it is making it very difficult for people to get reimbursement of their costs.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this is one measure the Government is using to try to force doctors to bulk bill and that is the only reason it is bringing this in. The Touche Ross organisation has pointed out that this will not save the Government money; in fact, it will cost taxpayers money, it will cost jobs in country areas, it will be very difficult and inconvenient for people in country areas and I appeal to the Government to change its mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, will be absent from Question Time today. He is attending the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in Brisbane. Questions normally addressed to the Attorney-General should be directed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Holding.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that present in the gallery this afternoon is Mr Caspar Weinberger, former Secretary of Defense of the United States of America. Mr Weinberger is visiting Australia as President Reagan's official United States representative to the bicentennial celebrations. On behalf of the House, I extend to him a very warm welcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to the established rules regarding post-separation employment which requires senior public servants or equivalents to obtain official assent if they wish to take up employment within two years of resignation or retirement from public employment in businesses or other bodies which may be in or anticipating contractual relationships with the Government, those in which the Government is a shareholder, those in receipt of government loans, guarantees or other forms of capital assistance and whose primary purpose is to lobby Ministers, members of parliament and government departments. In view of the Prime Minister's recent enthusiastic endeavours in relation to the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the fact that Mr Young has already obtained consultant employment with a body in which the Government is the sole shareholder, will he undertake to allow senior public servants to pursue similar post-separation employment opportunities to Mr Young?
—I have no reason to believe that in the case of Mr Young's activities what he will be doing will compromise in any way the proper arrangements which have been made in regard to public servants.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What representations has the Government made to the South African Government to stop the execution of the Sharpeville six?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hunter for his question. The Government has indeed made a number of representations to the South African Government on behalf of the Sharpeville six since December last year when appeals against their convictions were rejected. As recently as 15 March the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade instructed our Ambassador to South Africa to make a further urgent appeal. This morning I called in the South African Ambassador to add my personal representations on behalf of the six. I told the Ambassador that my Government is strongly opposed in principle to the death penalty but that its application in this case is particularly abhorrent.

ANSWER.PARA: The crux of the matter is that none of the six was directly involved in the murder with which they have been charged. I said that we believed that the execution of the six would exacerbate an already volatile political environment in South Africa. If the six are executed, this will only add to black bitterness at a time when there is a great need, as we would all appreciate, to break this cycle of violence in South Africa. I put it to the Ambassador that, by the same token, an act of clemency would be interpreted as a gesture of goodwill and would contribute to internal stability in South Africa. I asked the Ambassador to convey my appeal to state President Botha, and he undertook to do so. Our embassy in Pretoria is also being instructed to convey these views to the Government of South Africa.

Obviously this is not the occasion, nor do I seek to make it the occasion, to rehearse the fundamental differences which the Australian Government has with the South African Government over the general situation in South Africa. I did not seek to do so in my discussions with the Ambassador. We are concerned to save the Sharpeville six. I believe that our concerns about them are shared by all members of this Parliament and that we will all be hoping that our appeals, and those of so many others in South Africa and in the international community, will help persuade the South African Government not to go ahead with these unjust and unjustifiable executions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of the gravity of the legal opinion presented to the Prime Minister on Tuesday regarding the involvement of the Minister for Community Services and Health--

—Well, he is not laughing-regarding the involvement of the Minister for Community Services and Health in releasing confidential Health Insurance Commission reports and the ongoing investigation into the incident by the Australian Federal Police (AFP), has the Prime Minister now forwarded this opinion, together with that of the Solicitor-General, to the Director of Public Prosecutions; and, if not, why not? Will the Prime Minister now ask the Minister for Community Services and Health to stand down until questions as to whether charges should be brought against him have been determined?

—I have had a copy of the opinion provided to the Australian Association of Surgeons and the Australian Society of Orthopaedic Surgeons referred to the Attorney-General. The matters to which this opinion relates are the subject of a current investigation by the Australian Federal Police. In the circumstances it would not be appropriate to comment on those matters and I do not propose to do so. The Attorney-General does not propose to forward a copy of the opinion to the AFP or to the Director of Public Prosecutions. Both organisations will obtain any necessary legal advice from appropriate persons in the appropriate way. As to that part of the question from the honourable gentleman which refers to my colleague the Minister for Community Services and Health, I make it unequivocally clear that I do not intend to ask the Minister to stand down. The Solicitor-General adheres to the opinion he has given, and it is not appropriate for us in this Parliament to engage in a debate on the respective merits of different legal opinions.

—Will the Treasurer identify and explain the importance of some of the economic developments that have taken place and the economic indicators which have been released since the Parliament rose in December last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The economy has been performing quite well. The balance of payments figures, which came out the day before yesterday, revealed that the current account forecast is still on track. The February figures show that employment has grown by 116,000 since October 1987. Unemployment is down to 7.4 per cent of the work force. Inflation in the December quarter was 1.7 per cent, or 7.1 per cent over the course of the year, but on track for 6 per cent over the balance of the year to June as forecast in the Budget. Average weekly ordinary time earnings were up by a modest 1.2 per cent in the three months to November and by 5.3 per cent over the year. Plant and equipment investment was up 10 per cent in actual figures in the December quarter, 5 per cent in total. But, importantly, expectations for investment for 1988-89 show plant and equipment investment running at around 10 per cent real. Housing approvals were up 29 per cent, higher in the three months to January than in the corresponding period the previous year.

ANSWER.PARA: A lot of data has been published since late last year. We have had the November, December and January balance of payments figures, publication of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development Economic Outlook, the December quarter's consumer price index, employment growth figures for November, December, January and February, the national wage case, a raft of leading and partial indicators of economic activity, forward estimates, the Industries Assistance Commission program, and then, this week, the February balance of payments. Not one of those issues has sparked a question from the Opposition about economic policy. Despite that enormous raft of partial indicators and quarterly figures, there has been not one question from the Opposition about any matter of substance. Instead, what we have are, as usual from the Howard-led Opposition, personal attacks on members of the Government in substitute for decent policy or questions about the economy.

It is interesting that the Leader of the Opposition cannot ask me a question about the economy but he can discover some letter in some obscure casino about some breach of some rule in relation to gambling; nor could he discover letters from the Commissioner of Taxation for five years about the massive criminal avoidance of the tax system. He can put his hand in my letterbox but he could not discover the massive criminal avoidance of the tax system. Is it any wonder that the people of Wollstonecraft have got their letter boxes locked. I am sure some think that in those moist leafy glades, where the best protector of letters is basically a handful of redbacks, there is no need for a lock. But, I am sure, no self-respecting redback would bite the Leader of the Opposition. The fact of the matter is that we have not had one question of substance from the Leader of the Opposition or his front bench about any matter of importance. On 3 March the Sydney Morning Herald, talking about the Leader of the Opposition's economic credibility, had this to say:
To maximise the Liberal vote he turned his back on economic rationality. Mr Howard's approach seems to have damaged the Opposition's credibility with business generally.
So it should. The Sydney Morning Herald went on:
He will be without the intellectual direction and policy content that made him an attractive alternative to Mr Peacock. He will become Mr Peacock's poor substitute.

This is the view of the Sydney Morning Herald. I know the Leader of the Opposition cannot cop it. Whenever we say anything to him he has a conversation with someone, so of course it is all deflected. He gives the impression he is unworried, unconcerned. We always have this little bit of theatre. The Sydney Morning Herald also said:
The opinion leaders in business believe that it is time for the micro-economic reform that Mr Howard always intended but never quite got around to.

He is Mr Nearly. He nearly deregulated the financial markets, but Fraser would not let him. He nearly got control of the Budget, but Fraser blew it out at the end. He nearly cracked down on bottom of the harbour schemes when they first came to light, but of course the Cabinet would not let him. He nearly took action to reform the tax system and broaden the tax base. In short, he nearly tried to do something but never got around to it, and now that this Government is reforming Australia the best he can do is throw muck at the Prime Minister, after he authorises his front bench to throw muck at me, the Minister for Community Services and Health or any other Minister, rather than deal with any issue of substance. The fact is that, as Mr Greiner has said, Mr Greiner does not have a John Howard problem but the Federal Opposition has a John Howard problem, and it will not regain any decent standing in the eyes of the Australian public until it gets back to the main game and deals with the issues of substance concerning the economy and Australian life instead of making public attacks on the private affairs of Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy confirm that the Treasurer's close friend, Mr Warren Anderson, the owner of the Northern Territory cattle station Tipperary, has been given unrestricted approval to import between five and 20 tonnes of gamba grass from Brazil? Does the Minister realise that there is a grave risk of introducing exotic plants, insects and diseases such as foot and mouth disease in such a large consignment from Brazil, particularly as it could contain 40 per cent vegetable matter in the form of chaff and straw, both of which are prohibited imports? This is a very serious matter, so the Minister should listen. Is the Minister also aware that parthenium weed was introduced in a similar manner with buffel grass, and that it is only now that a new crop disease has been identified on imported millet introduced by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation under far more restrictive quarantine conditions than those applying to the gamba grass approval? Will the Minister now agree to the representations of the Cattlemen's Union, the Grains Council of Australia and other organisations and require the slower but safer restrictive method of introduction, which necessitates multiplying seed stocks under quarantine?

—I will give a detailed answer to the honourable gentleman's question. I know nothing about Warren Anderson; I know nothing about him even having cows. I will give the question of the importation of plants serious attention. Basically, I will answer the honourable gentleman in detail.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES CHILD CARE SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Can the Minister explain to the House the Federal Government's attitude to the announcement by the New South Wales Premier that the expansion of child care places will be cost shared with the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, along with the Prime Minister, welcome very much the initiatives of the New South Wales Premier in this area. Our two governments have worked very closely together over the past three years to expand dramatically the number of child care places in this country. The New South Wales Premier has set a fine example to other State governments with his commitment to the provision of child care. As I have previously reported, the Commonwealth will fulfil its commitment to establish 20,000 new places by the end of this year. This is a major achievement, one of which we can all be proud. It has been possible only because of the cooperation between the Commonwealth, the States and in many cases local government.

ANSWER.PARA: I should like to point to the outstanding contribution made by the New South Wales Government to child care. It was the New South Wales Government which pioneered cooperative arrangements with the Commonwealth to expand child care services. The result has been 169 new child care centres opened or approved since 1983 in New South Wales. It was New South Wales which provided over $15m in the last three years for the entire construction cost of centres built under these arrangements. New South Wales is the only State which has met the full capital cost. The New South Wales State Government's commitment is further demonstrated by its very generous contribution to recurrent funding-about $6m a year. In view of the past record of the New South Wales Government we very much welcome the initiative announced last week by Mr Unsworth, which will build on his Government's substantial achievements. Families in New South Wales can now look forward to the continued expansion of affordable, quality child care services tailored to their needs.

We hear nothing, of course, about child care services, health services or anything else from the collection of muckrakers opposite because their concern is with the gutter and not with policy. They have no child care policy; they have no health policy. Indeed, all they say about child care is that they will promise government subsidies to their friends in the private sector. That will mean no new child care places in this country. Their priority is simply subsidising the well off. Our priority and that of the New South Wales Government is about providing more child care places for ordinary families.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to his interview with the Sydney Morning Herald, reported on 10 March, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I think if the Government was going to be consistent about its line on reducing tax avoidance, then it has at least got to look at the superannuation area within that context.
What evidence does the Minister have to support his contention that superannuation funds and, by extension, their 2.7 million contributors are engaged in tax avoidance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government, of course, is involved in occupational superannuation in that it gives very substantial tax concessions to encourage employer and employee involvement in occupational superannuation. In 1986-87 the cost of these concessions was estimated to be $3.5 billion. While responsibility for superannuation issues rests with the Treasurer, it is a concern for the social security portfolio because both superannuation and age pensions aim to provide retirement income for older people.

ANSWER.PARA: A major issue, of course, is the relationship between superannuation arrangements and the age pension system. The question of the relative roles of superannuation and the age pension is fundamental to the nature of future retirement income arrangements in Australia. An immediate issue of concern is the interaction between superannuation and age pension systems because inadequacies in superannuation arrangements in terms of coverage, vesting, age and access to benefits and reasonable benefit limits mean that superannuation does not necessarily mesh well with the age pension. It is also a fact that superannuation coverage is incomplete and uneven. Women, part time and casual workers, blue collar workers and low income earners are significantly under-represented in superannuation schemes. Benefits are often available before age pension age. Where lump sums are spent prior to pension eligibility, individuals can receive a government pension in addition to the tax concessions provided through superannuation.

What is more relevant to the question is the fact that, as part of its review of the business taxation system, the Government is reviewing superannuation concessions. The review is still in progress. The Government has before it no proposals for change on superannuation or anything else to do with the review. With regard to superannuation, honourable members will know that the Prime Minister has given several undertakings and they are that the Government will not consider any changes which would impact adversely on already accrued superannuation benefits, that the Government will not make any changes which would stop people taking lump sum superannuation benefits, and that superannuation will continue to be treated on a concessional basis. The question of a comprehensive retirement income policy, which the honourable member for Bradfield suggests the Government is not interested in, is part of the responsibilities of the social security review. Professor Cass will publish a paper on retirement income policies in the middle of the year.

The difference between the Government and the Opposition is that, in the period that we have been in government, in contrast to the period that those opposite were in government, we have systematically developed economic and social policies that have gone to the heart of the problems which face the Australian community. The record of this Government in terms of income security reform and its overall approach to income distribution stands up very well against the record of any previous government. But it stands up extraordinarily well against the non-policies of the Opposition when it was in government and, still more, when it is in opposition. It is hard to remember an opposition which has devoted so little time to the discussion of any substantive issue. Members of the Opposition attend Question Time day in and day out with a copy of the morning newspaper and the odd clipping, and ask questions that have no substance and nothing undergirding them. The reason for that is that the Opposition is fundamentally shallow. It is interested in smearing the Government and entering into personality politics because it has not been able to develop, on the basis of so-called Liberal or National Party philosophy, any substantial ideas on the fundamentals of either economic or social policy. That is a disgrace for an opposition. It damages this Parliament and, ultimately, the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business explain what research is currently being carried out by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) into superconductivity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the honourable member for Dunkley would never ask. A new high temperature transition or TC-we ought to get used to the abbreviation-superconductor without rare earths has been synthesised and characterised by S. X. Dou and H. K. Liu at the University of New South Wales and by Nick Savvides of the CSIRO Division of Applied Physics. The new material is based on the ceramic system bismuth, calcium, strontium-not strontium 90, I hasten to add-copper and oxygen, and was first reported in January and early February by groups in Japan and the United States of America. Measurements indicate so far two distinct phases, one with a superconducting transition temperature of 90 degrees Kelvin and a second one at 115 degrees Kelvin. Improvements in these temperatures are likely in the near future.

ANSWER.PARA: This discovery may be very significant because the element bismuth is far cheaper than yttrium or the other rare earths. The new material is processed at lower temperatures and appears to be more stable than the rare earth based materials. Higher crucial current densities may be achieved. I point this out because this extraordinarily dramatic change that is going on means that the whole scene in superconductivity is changing month by month. The economic implications are enormous.

Attempts are under way to separate the two phases. CSIRO is also attempting to synthesise systems based on the element niobium which have been reported as possible room temperature superconductors. CSIRO's Division of Applied Physics has devised an ultra-sensitive measuring device called a squid or break junction radio frequency `superconducting quantum interference device'-as we are among friends, I think we will just call it the squid-which operates in liquid nitrogen, which is far cheaper and far more readily available than liquid helium. I now hand descriptive leaflets on the device to the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. The material used in the detector is a disc of yttrium, barium and copper oxide. There is a tiny loop in the middle which is shown in a photograph that I handed to the Leader of the Opposition. There is a superconducting loop in the tiny hole--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we have to sit for an examination?

—The examination will be the judgment of history, as it turns out, as to whether we take up this opportunity or whether we lose it. The hole contains a very tiny Josephson junction. It operates in liquid nitrogen and the transition temperature so far is at 90 degrees Kelvin. This device is capable of measuring magnetic fields as small as one-billionth of the earth's field and has major significance in physics research, materials chemistry and medical diagnosis. Its inventor, Ian Harvey, received international recognition with the Morris E. Leeds Award of the Institute of Electronic and Electrical Engineers.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has an excellent world reputation with its scientific instrumentation, such as Sir Alan Walsh's atomic absorption spectrophotometer, which is the international standard. But the economic implications of superconductivity are infinitely greater. Opportunities like this arise only once or twice in each generation. It is essential that we develop our core capacity and then develop the infrastructure for industrial development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to his remarks in Parliament on Tuesday when he expressed concern about the increasing cost of private health insurance cover to ordinary Australians and those in New South Wales in particular. Is it a fact that on 22 December the Minister wrote to the Hon. David White, the Victorian Minister for Health, approving a staged increase in public hospital charges from the present $121 a day to $155 a day? Is it further a fact that by his own Department's estimates this will increase basic private health cover cost by a national average of approximately $1 per week, with the `highest increase being in New South Wales'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As perhaps the honourable member for Parkes is not aware, the determination of private insurance charges today is essentially decided by the States. It is the States which determine the charges in their private hospitals and it is the private hospitals in the States which determine their own private hospital charges. Therefore, the rate in any State is essentially what is determined by the State Government and the private hospital in that State.

ANSWER.PARA: A proposal was made by the Victorian Government to me to raise its charges on average to $144 at present. I approved that rate, but that is the case with all States which come forward with a rate for their hospitals and that is approved. I am not aware of any claim put forward by the New South Wales public hospital system or, at this moment, from any other State public hospital system that it wishes to raise its charges. I also point out that the new Victorian charge will not be very much above that which already exists in some other States. The expectation of that rise to $144 is approximately 50c a week on average health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to a long running dispute in Newcastle and the Hunter region, where eye specialists are refusing to carry out sight saving operations on age pensioners unless those pensioners agree to pay hundreds of dollars above the schedule fee. Is the Minister aware of the claims of an ophthalmic surgeon, reported in the Newcastle Herald on Tuesday, 15 March, that government bureaucrats and politicians are to blame for the problem? Can the Minister advise the House as to the truth of such claims? Can he further advise whether there is a need to make the public more aware of the charging practices of doctors so that patients can make more informed judgments about medical treatment and the appropriateness of fees charged by individual doctors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The behaviour of the eye surgeons in the Hunter Valley is the kind of behaviour that this Opposition is not prepared to subject to proper public scrutiny and debate, which has been the whole point of the Government's actions in these matters. It is, I am afraid, in the case of the eye surgeons in the Hunter Valley, a classic example of doctors holding patients to ransom for money. Eye surgeons are amongst the highest paid medical specialists in this country.
—How much?

—I will come to that in one moment. The Hunter Valley eye surgeons are refusing to do sight saving cataract operations on pensioners because they claim that they are not being paid enough per operation. It is true that their schedule fee was restructured to take account of the technological changes which have made those operations faster, safer, simpler to perform and requiring reduced after care. Yet, apparently, the eye surgeons believe that the only beneficiaries from technological change should be themselves. This Government's view is that advances in technology should be shared between doctors and patients.

ANSWER.PARA: The schedule fee for this operation, which takes on average less than one hour, is $575 per operation. Yet the surgeons are saying to pensioners, `This is not enough. Pay a lot more of your pension or we will not operate in the Hunter Valley'. There are cases of patients who have been told that they will never be able to have the operation in a public hospital but that if they pay $800 up front they can have the operation in a private hospital. The New South Wales Government has taken action to ensure that those operations can be done elsewhere. It has been transporting patients from the Hunter region to the Sydney Eye Hospital, where they can have their operations immediately. The New South Wales Government has also subcontracted with the NIB day surgery centre at Newcastle to have the operations performed but the eye surgeons in the Hunter Valley have torpedoed that option.

I am glad to say that, increasingly, public anger grows at this kind of behaviour. It is not just this Government which is making these comments about this sort of behaviour. I quote from the Newcastle Herald of Monday, 14 March. It states:
The eye doctors will convince few people that their protest is about anything but cupidity, about people who have a lever in their hands and are using it for all it is worth.
The Opposition should listen to this:
For this short operation and a few consultations the eye doctors are offered five times what their pensioner patients must live on for a week.

I, and this Government, condemn the kind of behaviour by that minority of eye surgeons in the Hunter Valley. Yet it is that kind of behaviour that this Opposition makes every effort to prevent effective public scrutiny and criticism of.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs confirm Press reports that the Government has abandoned its proposal for a preamble to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation that was announced with great fanfare last December?

—I saw one report at the weekend which indicated that. The report was inaccurate, not only in that regard but also in regard to a number of other points it addressed. We are still engaged in consultation with Aboriginal people about the proposals we announced on 10 December. When those consultations have been completed the honourable member, like everybody else, will be told the outcome.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS: ISRAEL AND THE OCCUPIED TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade: Given the Australian Government's general interest in the field of human rights, what action is it and, in particular, the Foreign Minister, taking to ensure that Israel observes the human rights of oppressed Palestinians living in Israel and the occupied territories?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter that the Government is concerned about and has taken the opportunity of raising with Israeli authorities on a number of occasions. About three weeks ago when I was in Israel I raised the matter in a speech at an official dinner hosted by the Foreign Affairs Minister for Israel, Mr Shamon Peres. More importantly, I handed over a letter to Prime Minister Shamir during that visit from the Prime Minister of Australia. In that letter the Prime Minister noted that the deportation of Palestinians to Lebanon was inconsistent with Israel's responsibilities under the Geneva Convention and an infringement of Lebanon's sovereignty. In the same letter the Prime Minister pointed out to Mr Shamir that the extent and nature of some of Israel's responses to the resistance to its presence in the occupied territories, including the deaths and beatings among the civilian population, have damaged Israel's image in Australia and have made even more difficult the task of achieving a just and lasting peace in the region.

ANSWER.PARA: In February of this year at the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva and in December last year at the United Nations General Assembly, Australia voted in favour of resolutions expressing concerns about human rights in the occupied territories. Our ambassador in Tel Aviv has made direct representations. After discussions with the Prime Minister-it was on his proposal-it has been decided that a parliamentary group should visit the front line states of the Middle East, including Israel, and that this should be representative of all the parties in the Parliament. It will represent an extra parliamentary visit on those which will take place under the normal procedures provided this year.

I would like to say one other thing for the record, and it is not without irony. While I was in the Middle East, the shadow spokesman on foreign affairs for the Opposition, the honourable member for North Sydney, made the observation that I was in distant areas peripheral to Australia's interests. I would think the comments I have expressed are very much shared by the Opposition as much as they are expressed by the Government. However, while the honourable member for North Sydney was making a comment that I was in remote areas peripheral to our interests, he took the opportunity of ringing up the Prime Minister and recommending, with others, that this sort of visit should be undertaken by parliamentarians. There does seem to be a double standard in his sense of urgency and priorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Will the Federal Government abide by the recommendations of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government appointed the Helsham inquiry. As the honourable member will appreciate, we appointed it because we were faced with a situation where two basically conflicting positions were being put before us, I think with integrity from both sides. The conservation movement, if I can put it generally, said that there was no need to conduct forestry operations in the areas of concern because there were sufficient alternative resources which would sustain an economic industry. Against that position, which I believe the conservation movement and those supporting it hold with integrity, an equally firm position was put by the industry in Tasmania, supported by the Tasmanian Government, that that was not the case, that without some authority and opportunity to log in what I will broadly call the sensitive areas it would not be possible to sustain a really viable industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, faced with those two diametrically opposed propositions, took what I would hope the honourable member would think would be the sensible course of action and established an independent royal commission of inquiry-the Helsham inquiry. I indicated to the two sets of proponents that this matter had to be resolved, this question of fact, and that we just could not sit back and have one side saying one thing and one side saying the other.

The Helsham inquiry has been established for that purpose. We will study carefully the report when it is received and obviously, given that background which I put in answer to the honourable member's question, there will be a strong disposition on the part of the Government to accept the report. I think the honourable member would also accept the fact that no government can, in advance, give an absolutely blank cheque. But that is our predisposition and we will study the report carefully. I thank the honourable member for his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer inform the House of the effects on the national economy of the State governments undertaking massive new spending programs which would rapidly lift the growth in State spending?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this Government took office in 1983, the former conservative Government bequeathed to us a Budget deficit of just on 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). As well as that, in the two or three years earlier the present Leader of the Opposition, the former Treasurer, let the States out of the Loan Council so that they could borrow willy-nilly, the result being that the public sector borrowing requirement of Australia in 1983-84 in prospect was a little over 8 per cent of GDP.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government has taken that disastrous fiscal legacy and the public sector borrowing requirement down from 8.2 per cent of GDP to 1.8 per cent. In so doing it not only has carried most of the burden of cutting the Federal Government Budget deficit and bringing it to a surplus, but also has re-established what we call global borrowing limits over the States to rein in their expenditures and borrowings. That process is well under way and this year we will make further progress. But now in the State of New South Wales, in the course of an election campaign, we have the Liberal Party of New South Wales promising new spending commitments in the coming financial year of the order of $2 billion which, given the size of New South Wales and our national economy, is the equivalent of $6,000m of Commonwealth Government expenditure. Such a spending spree would do one of two things: firstly, it would simply reverse many of the gains the Commonwealth Government has been able to chalk up in bringing back the public sector borrowing requirement and, hence, lowering our dependency upon overseas savings and overseas debt to bring down our current account deficit. Secondly, such a program would mean that, in the main, Mr Greiner's promises would not be honoured, that he could not pay for them and that he could not deliver on them.

In contrast, the Australian Labor Party Government, under Premier Unsworth in New South Wales, has gone to the election with a modest $260m worth of promises. Members of the Liberal Party have had the temerity to advertise promise after promise on behalf of Labor but have failed to mention that they have promised to outlay about $2 billion, almost 10 times the promises of the Labor Party, in an attempt to buy votes, to cadge votes in marginal seats. One disappointing feature of this campaign has been the unwillingness on the part of the media in New South Wales to expose the Liberal Party for this profligacy, this rerun of the last Federal election when the Leader of the Opposition was promising $8 billion of unfunded tax cuts. Now Mr Greiner is promising $2 billion, or the equivalent of $6 billion in Commonwealth dollars, to try to get himself elected as Premier of New South Wales.

Were New South Wales in the unhappy position of having elected a Greiner government the Commonwealth Government would not bail New South Wales out. We will guarantee that no State dismantles the national Government policy of lowering the public sector borrowing requirement and changing the current account deficit. Let it be made quite clear that this profligacy, this irresponsibility, would not be tolerated by the Federal Government and the result would be that Mr Greiner would drop most of those promises because he could not keep them. He could not fund his commitments because to so fund them would destroy the financial base of New South Wales.

I conclude on this point: such a policy would wreak havoc with the national Government's policy of reducing the public sector borrowing requirement. We would come down very hard upon any conservative government in New South Wales that attempted so to destroy our policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to the question addressed to me today by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, I am informed that the original proposal to import 20 tonnes of gamba grass seed is again being pursued by the importer. The importer's name is Mr G. Beeks of Australian Pasture Seeds Pty Ltd in Nowra, New South Wales. It was the importer who cancelled his earlier attempt to import the seeds in mid-January this year.

ANSWER.PARA: I inform the House that gamba grass seed is not a prohibited species under the Quarantine Act and, consequently, it may be imported without prior permission, but subject to inspection on arrival to ensure it is free from serious exotic pests, diseases, weeds and other prohibited matter, such as soil. Samples will be drawn for inspection using standards of the International Seed Testing Association. These standards are followed for inspection of the wide range of non-prohibited seeds imported into Australia under quarantine control. If there are contaminants in the seed in excess of quarantine tolerances the seed will be refused entry. The risk of introducing foot and mouth disease on grass seed has been considered by Australian animal quarantine authorities and is considered to be virtually non-existent. There is absolutely no evidence of the disease having been spread by this means anywhere in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I ask you a question with respect to your responsibilities. Your attention would have been drawn to an industrial stoppage this morning by the cleaners within Parliament House. I understand that their concern relates to the termination of their employment on 30 June next and the replacement of House cleaning services by contract labour. What attempts have been made by you, Madam Speaker, or by others on your behalf, to provide adequate post-separation arrangements for those cleaners? Have attempts been made to seek employment for them with those who are to be contractors in this place after that date? If you find it difficult to achieve post-separation arrangements that are satisfactory to you and to them, would you call on the services of the Prime Minister, who seems to have pursued, through various telephone calls, adequate post-separation arrangements for the former Leader of the House?

—I have intentions of making a statement concerning both the cleaning and the catering and of tabling papers in connection with both problems we are having at the moment. If having read the tabled statements there is anything further the right honourable gentleman needs to know I would be most happy to show him the entire program. I assure the House that everything that can be done is being done with regard to redeployment-some have moved into the catering area and some into gardening-and we are making every effort to place the cleaners. If that is satisfactory to the right honourable gentleman I will make the statements after the Prime Minister has finished the Irish contribution. If there is anything further he needs to know I will guarantee to let him know later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent notice No. 1, Government Business, being called on forthwith.
Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, on St Patrick's Day 1988-
(1) recognises with thanks the profound contribution made by the Irish over two hundred years to Australian culture, religion, law, politics and the labour movement;
(2) notes that the Irish community in Australia dates from the First Fleet, that one third of Australians are of Irish descent,and that Australia is the most Irish of nations outside Ireland;

(3) affirms that the emergence of an Australian national character was due in large part to the creative presence of the Irish, whose passionate love of freedom prepared the way for a society in which people from many ethnic backgrounds live and flourish as equals;
(4) acknowledges the special, deep and enduring bonds between Australia and Ireland;
(5) in the Bicentenary year of European settlement in Australia, salutes the City of Dublin as she celebrates her millennium; and
(6) resolves to send a delegation from this Parliament, led by the Deputy Speaker, to Ireland to convey the sentiments of this motion to the Irish Parliament and people.

It is very fitting that on St Patrick's Day in our bicentennial year and in the millennial year of the city of Dublin the House adopt the motion I have just read out. In 1988 it is appropriate that we look back over 200 years of Irish involvement in and contribution to every aspect of Australian life-not least, as I look around here, to our political life. Quite simply, without the Irish presence throughout our 200 years of European settlement, this would be a very different society, and a much less tolerant and much less decent one.

As we continue in the creation of a truly multicultural society, let us recall the struggle for equality of opportunity and religious and cultural freedom waged by the Irish, who constituted our first and largest ethnic minority.

Ireland's contribution to our Bicentenary has been an outstanding one. In particular, the gift of microfilm records of the 40,000 Irish men and women transported to Australia from Ireland in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries will become a permanent source of invaluable historical information for our country. The fact of our shared history provides a strong foundation for the friendly relations which Australia and Ireland enjoy today. We are both flourishing parliamentary democracies. We have the same aspirations for peace, arms control, human rights, the principles of national self-determination and the elimination of apartheid. In the light of the tragic events reported from Belfast overnight, I take this opportunity to stress Australia's repudiation-a repudiation which is shared by the Irish Government-of terrorist violence in support of political goals in Northern Ireland.

I made a memorable visit to Ireland last year. That visit confirmed the warmth and special character of the relations between Ireland and Australia and between the Irish and Australian peoples. Our Government looks forward very much to the visit to Australia by the Taoiseach, Charles Haughey, later this year. Meanwhile, Madam Speaker, it is very appropriate that a delegation of this Parliament, led by your Deputy, will visit Ireland next month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I go?

—The honourable member will have to organise the numbers. It is very appropriate that a delegation of this Parliament led by the Deputy Speaker will visit Ireland next month to express the affection which Australians feel for the Irish people and, as my motion puts it, the special, deep and enduring bonds between Australia and Ireland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reflecting on the Irish heritage of Australia it is interesting to remark upon the very distinct contributions that Irish-Australians have made to--
—To the Labor Party.

—Yes, to the Australian Labor Party. I am very happy to say that. Anybody-and I say this very seriously-who understands anything about the political history of Australia will recognise the enormous and unique contribution that Irish-Australians have made to the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: As I look across the chamber I understand something of the British Isles and other ethnic backgrounds of my many friends opposite and I think of the Irish strand in the Australian Labor Party. I recognise that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sees himself as very much a friend of Ireland. He has expressed today, I believe very genuinely, the affection he feels for Ireland, although he himself has correctly identified his ancestors as having belonged to the celtic fringe. It is also interesting that another of his colleagues, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), represents in a sense that more overtly Irish tradition of the Australian Labor Party. Therefore, I think it uniquely appropriate that on St Patrick's Day, the day this motion is moved, the Australian Financial Review should write an editorial saying that the Irish Keating should take over from the non-Irish Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a phoney.
—I know that the Minister does not like it. I am very happy on behalf of all the members of the Opposition to join the Prime Minister in conveying to the people of Ireland--
—You don't join me.

—I know I do not join the Prime Minister He is getting very worked up about this. The Prime Minister would do far better to keep quiet for the duration of this debate and he would lesser proclaim his sensitivity to what was written today in the Australian Financial Review. Through the cackle of the Prime Minister's intervention I say how very happy we are about the many Irish and non-Irish descendants who now strongly support the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia. We look forward with very great interest to the outworking within the Australian Labor Party of that historic struggle between Irish and non-Irish Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Members have been circulated with a note on the withdrawal of cleaning services today. The Secretary to the Joint House Department circularised members today advising:

INTERJECT.PARA: Cleaning in the new Parliament House will be undertaken by contract and tenders are presently being evaluated. Concurrently action is being taken by the Joint House Department to ensure that as far as practicable alternative employment is found for cleaning staff currently employed and that the rights and entitlements of staff are protected. Consultations with staff and the Federated Miscellaneous Workers' Union (FMWU) have been an integral part of this process.

At a meeting this morning between staff and the FMWU they have advised that they have stopped work for the remainder of today. This action has been taken in support of issues arising from the abovementioned action. Consequently there will be no further cleaning undertaken in Parliament House today.
Normal cleaning services will resume tomorrow.

The Department has been engaged in discussions with staff and has taken a number of initiatives to find alternative employment. To date, jobs have been found for eight staff, with 18 yet to find alternative employment.

I table my earlier advice to members on the redeployment of cleaners, for further background on this matter. As I pointed out to the Leader of the National Party of Australia, I am having the matter updated weekly. I would be more than happy to discuss it with him and to give him the other papers in connection with it if he so desires.

TALK.START.PARA: —Staff of the Parliamentary Catering Service held a stop-work meeting today which affected luncheon services. I apologise sincerely. I recognise that it is difficult on a Thursday when the House sits through, but I was not notified until too late. Services resumed at 1.30 p.m. Staff have advised that further rolling strikes may occur. The Joint House Department has requested urgent meetings with staff and union delegates. I table, for the information of members, the letter that the President and I sent to them early in January regarding decisions taken on cleaning and catering in the new Parliament House which is obviously part of the stirring of trouble.
