TALK.START.PARA: —We now come to personal explanations. I call the honourable member for North Sydney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), in the tail end of an answer to a question, said something to the effect that while he was in Israel or the West Bank I indicated that what was then transpiring in that area was peripheral to our interests. I checked back on my statements. On 28 February 1988 I issued a statement which is quite to the contrary effect and which deals with Israel, Gaza and the West Bank. In it I referred to the continuing violence, laid down certain preconditions for the purpose of the peace process and stated that the difficulties posed to the successful conclusion of the settlement are longstanding and formidable, but of course they should be pursued.

SPEECH.PARA: The Press release that I issued on 29 February was about the Foreign Minister's Jakarta visit, and this appears to be the point that he has picked up:

The lesson from Mr Hayden's diplomatic fiasco is how inept the Government has been in improving relations with Indonesia and how unwise it has been to spend so much time and resources on issues and relationships-such as its concern to be a leading voice in Southern Africa-which are peripheral to our main interests.
The Foreign Minister, as you know, Madam Speaker, moves from capital to capital like a magpie moving from bauble to bauble, and it is hard to keep up with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will not debate the issue. He has put his personal explanation before the House.

—On 24 February I reported that a species of legionella bacteria, legionella bozemanii, had been detected in air-conditioning water cooling towers in the provisional Parliament House. I further reported that at the time of its detection the contents of the towers had been dumped, the towers scrubbed and the new water treated with biocides to control bacterial growth. The latest series of tests of the water cooling towers were carried out on 25 February, and the Certificate of Analysis for these tests provided by Maxwell Chemicals Pty Ltd advises that no legionella bacteria were detected during these tests. Weekly dosing of the towers to control any bacterial growth will continue and scientific testing of the water for legionella bacteria will be carried out on a monthly basis.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE: OVERSEAS VISIT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Speaker, during my recent visit overseas I represented the Australian Government in valuable and productive discussions with heads and members of governments and other community leaders in Mauritius, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Kenya, Yemen Arab Republic, Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Israel, Maldives, Singapore and Indonesia. These discussions canvassed a broad range of topics, including international and regional issues, economic and trade matters and official aid activities.

SPEECH.PARA: There were two particular points of significance about my visit. The first is that the issues raised range across all our national interests and obligations: the Commonwealth and the Front Line States, for example; trade and aid; the Middle East dispute; the Gulf War and the arms race; human rights; and our immediate regional preoccupations.

In Lusaka, I attended the first meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers Committee which was set up by the Vancouver Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) in order to bring about Commonwealth action to hasten the end of apartheid. The Lusaka meeting decided on a program of work to achieve two objectives. One was to widen and tighten Commonwealth sanctions against South Africa. Australia made an important contribution to this objective by presenting a report on work done by Australia towards the study-commissioned by the CHOGM-into South Africa's relationship with the international financial system. This study will provide a better understanding of possibilities for financial sanctions against the apartheid regime. Australia will continue to contribute to this study, which will be considered at a future meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers.

The Lusaka meeting was not concerned solely with sanctions, of course. Its second objective was to find ways in which the Commonwealth can play a constructive role in a range of activities: reducing the economic dependence of Front Line States on South Africa; assisting with their security needs; facilitating contact with groups inside and outside South Africa; supporting victims and opponents of apartheid; and counteracting South African propaganda and censorship. The Front Line States opposing the apartheid regime bear a heavy burden, in the sense that their economic condition is in large measure determined by this regime. This was a recurring theme in my discussions with leaders of Zambia, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. We make no bones about our concern for these economies. Apartheid is the most deplorable example possible of infringement of fundamental human rights. Unlike the Opposition, the Government will not tolerate compromise over this great moral imperative.

I should say how disappointed I was during Question Time today that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) did not take the opportunity, as he could have, to associate the Opposition with the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the deplorable situation in South Africa in relation to the Sharpeville six. It was a splendid opportunity to provide a unified voice in this Parliament and to display bipartisanship, a level of moral concern and the sort of leadership that the community is looking towards.

The Commonwealth has focused attention on the plight of Mozambique, a special victim of drought and famine complicated by campaigns of destabilisation by Pretoria. The drought is particularly serious and international awareness of its effects is spreading at last. Senior officials of the International Committee for the Red Cross and of the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees describe the refugee situation in Mozambique as the worst they have ever encountered. The Commonwealth and the wider international community have therefore sought to respond out of humanitarian concern for the predicament in which the ordinary people of Mozambique find themselves. Australia's capacity to help is obviously limited.

Our pledge of $100m in aid over three years to the countries of southern Africa, including Mozambique, is small compared to the commitments of Canada, for example, and of the Europeans. It is nevertheless an earnest of our commitment to a nation bordering on the Indian Ocean, which is a region of significance to Australia. It allows us, moreover, to continue our close involvement in an international issue of fundamental concern and to assist Mozambique to cope with the consequences of South African destabilisation. The Opposition's attitude on this point is churlish and shameful.

Let me make two points about this meanness. One is that-for all the Opposition's indignation about aid to southern Africa-this level of aid will increase by a few cents to about 32c on average per head each year! Compare this to more than $95 per head spent last year in Papua-New Guinea, for example, or more than $100 per head in Vanuatu.

The second point is that most of it is in the form of food aid and at least three-quarters of our food aid over the past four years has been spent on Australian produce. If the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), having heard this, still disagrees with the idea of giving humanitarian aid to the starving and the famished of southern Africa, let him go and explain himself to the high-protein biscuit producers in New South Wales or the sorghum farmers in Queensland or the dried fruit growers in Victoria. I found a clear wish in Mauritius, Kenya and Zimbabwe to develop closer trade and commercial links with Australia, particularly as these countries also strongly desire to reduce their dependence on South African sources. I made it clear that Australian expertise and technology have ready application in a number of product and service areas. In particular, my discussions in these countries identified agricultural development and minerals exploitation and processing as areas of great interest and commercial potential.

A trade mission of Australian business representatives will visit Zimbabwe and Mauritius in May this year to explore at first hand the opportunities for increased commercial contact between these countries and Australia. To succeed in these countries, Australian corporations will need to be competitive and innovative in their approach. The effort is worth making. These are countries with an Indian Ocean focus in their worldview, a novel experience for Australian companies, and they offer long term prospects for Australia. Australia must recognise at the same time that these countries need assistance to develop their own export capabilities. My Department, for instance, will be extending such assistance to exporters in Zimbabwe to help them promote their products in Australia.

The Middle East is an area of primary trading importance to Australia, with two-way trade of almost $3 billion last financial year. During my visit, I signed bilateral trade agreements with Jordan, Egypt and Israel. These agreements will facilitate closer economic and trading relationships, an important aspect being the establishment of joint committees in which business will have a dynamic role. In my trade discussions in the Middle East, I emphasised Australia's wish to strengthen and broaden our commercial relationship with the region beyond the present emphasis on commodity trade. I was able to highlight the suitability of Australian technological expertise in a number of manufacturing and services areas of relevance to the region's development needs.

In addition, I was able to talk directly with customers in the $309.7m a year market for Australian wheat in Egypt and in the $58.4m Yemen Arab Republic market, where our market share is under threat. Moreover, at the meeting of heads of Australian missions in the Middle East-attended for the first time by senior officers of Austrade working in the region-we discussed integrated strategies to pursue Australian economic and political interests in the region.

Australia's influence on regional political events is naturally limited but we do have obligations and interests in these events. One such development is the war between Iran and Iraq. The continuation of this war threatens our important trading links with both countries. It also imposes limits on our capacity to expand these links. It has to be said that the Iran-Iraq conflict is being complicated by the involvement of several nations in the supply of arms to both combatants. This is an obviously important factor militating against solution. It certainly emphasises the urgency and necessity of controls on conventional as well as nuclear weapons.

The conflict between Israelis and Arabs is especially significant to Australia. Nearly half a million Australians of Jewish and Arab origin have a direct and often personal interest in this tragic and complex issue. My visit to the region immediately preceded that of Secretary George Shultz and took place in the atmosphere created by his attempt to bring the disputants together. The issue was accordingly the most significant in the subjects of my discussion with leaders in Syria, Jordan, Egypt and Israel and with Palestinian representatives.

In these discussions, I made clear our realisation that we were marginal participants in events and that we were therefore not in the business of pressing prescriptions on those who were central to the issue. I made clear also Australia's strong view that the Shultz initiative and those of King Hussein and President Mubarak should be taken up as a rare opportunity to begin the process of settlement. I was able to convey directly to Mr Shultz my impressions of the attitudes of leaders centrally involved and, in the light of these attitudes, to offer what I know our American friends appreciated as constructive suggestions. While I was in Israel, I expressed to Prime Minister Shamir and Foreign Minister Peres-through a letter from our Prime Minister and in my own words-the deep concern felt in Australia, as a friend of Israel, about the continuing violence in the occupied territories. I was able to see for myself in Gaza the legacy of hatred being created by the continuing inability of all involved to agree to solve the Palestinian issue through negotiations based on acceptance of the rights of Israel to exist within secure and recognised boundaries and of the Palestinians to self-determination.

During the return leg of my journey, I took the opportunity to visit Singapore and Indonesia and the Maldives, our Indian Ocean neighbour. My visits to Singapore and Indonesia were part of our commitment to maintaining regular contacts with these important regional partners. They were also my first as Minister responsible for trade. I ensured that my program reflected this new responsibility in the fullest measure, in my discussion with ministerial counterparts and business representatives.

My visit in Jakarta, of course, offered the chance of another in the regular exchanges I have maintained with Foreign Minister Mochtar, who is a good friend to Australia. A full agenda of discussion with Dr Mochtar included the issue of Kampuchea-on which Indonesia has continued to play a major role-progress on the Timor Gap question, the illegal entry into Australian waters of Indonesian fishing boats and access to Indonesia by Australian journalists.

In the Maldives, trade matters were an important item of discussion with the emphasis on expanding our existing commercial links. Our aid program was also discussed. It was valuable to gain Maldivian views, particularly on topics bearing on our common interests in the Indian Ocean.

My visits to the Maldives and South East Asia illustrate the extent and diversity of the regional diplomatic agenda for Australia. We must focus simultaneously on both the economic and political level on the Indian Ocean, North Asian, South East Asian and South West Pacific areas. The days are long gone when we could strike political postures against China, for example, while pursuing a trading relationships with China. Striking the right balance, judging the trade-offs costs in competing national priorities, deploying scarce government resources in the maximum national benefit: these are complex, connected strands in our diplomacy which have to be pursued with subtlety as well as energy if we are to protect and preserve Australia's vital interests.

This raised the second point of significance about my visit. This is that the issue with which it dealt exemplifies in many ways the complexities in the conduct of diplomacy nowadays. By this I mean such issues as disarmament and superpower relations, for example; the international economic and trade systems; human rights, the effects of racism and colonialism; and the condition of Australia as a multicultural community.

The recent speech to the Australian Institute of International Affairs in Hobart by the Leader of the Opposition demonstrated significant differences of view on foreign policy between the Government and the Opposition. So have various statements by the newest spokesperson on foreign policy of the Opposition, that frayed intellectual fop, the honourable member for North Sydney. There should be no mistake about this. There is an influential minority in Australia which either does not understand the current complexities in external policy or is frightened and confused by them. Let me discuss a few examples.

One is the Opposition's view that the southern African issue is irrelevant and, to use its word, peripheral to Australian interests. I will not dwell on the Opposition's tacky philosophy-as shown in its statements on the Grey case in Mozambique-that humanitarian aid should be used as a tool of political pressure; as a form of ransom. It is hard to imagine an attitude that could do Mr Grey more harm.

It is unfortunate that it is necessary to point out the seriousness to us of the situation in southern Africa as an irritant in world affairs, as a major concern to the Commonwealth and a cause of growing insecurity in the Indian Ocean region. I regret this because it is a reflection of the Opposition's unacceptably benign view of the doctrine and effects of apartheid. With one or two honourable exceptions, such as the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), the Opposition proclaims its distaste for apartheid but it opposes any Australian attempt to do anything about it.

This hypocrisy does Australia great harm in the Commonwealth and elsewhere. Nothing could be better timed to show the inherent inhumanity of apartheid than the case of the Sharpeville six. This afternoon the Leader of the Opposition missed the opportunity to join with the Government to give a splendid display of unity, of purpose, as I said earlier, between the parties in this Parliament on this issue. Six people not directly involved in a violent incident are about to be hanged as a gesture towards the South African Government's attempts to prop up its apartheid system. I regret also that the Opposition's position on southern Africa shows a dangerous myopia about Indian Ocean affairs. This is a region which is so important to our strategic interests and our trade and communications links that we consult annually with the United States on developments there.

These developments have great significance for us. This is why we have increased our diplomatic and defence presence there since 1983. It is why we have such an active interest in encouraging the work of the Indian Ocean Commission and the concept of the Indian Ocean zone of peace. One searches in vain through Opposition pronouncements for some recognition of this. The point, however, will not be lost on Western Australians.

Another point of significance about the Opposition's reaction to the issues raised by my visit is the degree of misunderstanding, indeed, ignorance, about the conduct of policy towards the Asia-Pacific region. The Opposition makes typically vague and unsubstantiated allegations that the Government has dissipated its resources and energies in the region. I think my friends opposite should be introduced to a few facts on this point. Apart from my Department's specialist resources at home, almost half of all its policy staff overseas are working in this region. There are, in addition, officers working in the region from departments and organisations such as the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau; Australian Federal Police; Customs; Industry; Local Government and Ethnic Affairs; Defence and armed services; Department of Primary Industries and Energy; Special Minister of State; Austrade; Treasury; and Education.

Since this Government came to office, there have been 192 ministerial visits to countries in the region and 144 visits to Australia by Ministers of Asian and Pacific governments. In the first half of this year alone, continuous, active contact with the region has taken place or is planned. I instance visits to China by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), and the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) on the occasion of the Joint Ministerial Economic Commission. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has also visited Hong Kong and Thailand. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) visited Hong Kong and Korea. Other activities include: trade discussions with China, Japan and Korea; further development of bilateral strategies for Japan and Korea; development of concessional financial arrangements with China to promote Australian commercial participation in Chinese economic development; and development of beef strategies for Japan and Korea.

I plan to visit Japan, Korea, Hong Kong and the Philippines next month and Japan again and China later in the year. Later in the year, apart from visits to South East Asia by other Ministers, I plan to continue the Australian presence at the annual meeting of Foreign Ministers of Association of South East Asian Nations dialogue partners with their ASEAN colleagues-an activity to which the Government attaches the highest priority. Australia has consistently supported the efforts of those Governments which are trying to find a practical and lasting solution to the Kampuchean problem, which is a major source of tension in the region. The Opposition continues to express fear about the relationship with Indonesia, especially since the reaction by the Indonesian Government to Australian media criticism in 1986. Despite this reaction, there has been continuous and productive engagement between the two countries since then at all levels.

There have been six visits to Indonesia by Australian Ministers, including two by me. Defence contacts have continued; so have negotiations over the Timor Gap, which after my last visit are making very encouraging progress. Australian investment in Indonesia has increased. Indonesia will be represented at World Expo 88. Access to Indonesia has now been granted to Australian Associated Press and there is a reasonable prospect of access being given also to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I plan to make a comprehensive visit to the South Pacific again this year. This will repeat my visit to the area in 1986, when I visited all eight independent island states plus New Caledonia-the first ever such action by any Australian Foreign Minister. I have made subsequent visits to this area.

Australia will continue to take part in the South Pacific Forum meeting at the highest level. We continue to play a full role within the Forum in developing regional institutions on security and other strategic interests in South Pacific countries. We continue to cooperate with other Forum members on rationalising and strengthening regional organisations. We have enhanced the trading prospects of South pacific island nations by our comprehensive liberalisation of the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Cooperation Agreement and we are exploring areas of possible broader trade and economic cooperation. We have significantly increased our aid to South Pacific island nations.

Papua New Guinea continues to be a principal focus for the Government. The Prime Minister and Papua New Guinea Prime Minister Wingti signed a Joint Declaration of Principles late last year which will guide the conduct of the bilateral relationship into the future. Trade will be an increasingly important element in relations and the Government is actively engaged in a review of our trade agreement with Papua New Guinea. Despite problems induced by New Zealand's policy on United States ship visits, ANZUS, which is such a significant factor in regional security, continues to be fully in force between Australia and the United States and, separately, Australia and New Zealand. We played an active role in creating the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone.

The honourable member for North Sydney has described this development as `a nonsense'. It shows how little he understands the region and how greatly he patronises it. The treaty is the result not just of the policy of the Australian Government but also the strongly, and widely, held views and desires of members of the South Pacific Forum. Finally, the Australian Government has actively promoted constructive relationships between Western governments and the island states. We strongly encouraged the United States, for instance, to enter a treaty with the island governments to redress the problems of United States tuna fishing in the area. We have encouraged Japan to develop its relations-especially its economic cooperation-with the island states. We have encouraged France to develop its relations in the area in a manner consistent with the interests of the people of the South Pacific as expressed through the Forum. The Leader of the Opposition, in his Hobart speech, said:
Mr Hawke announced in Singapore that he would welcome `constructive' Soviet political involvement in the Asia/Pacific region.

The Prime Minister did say in Singapore that he would welcome a constructive involvement by the Soviets in the region, but he went on to say that they would be judged in this not by their words but by their actions in, for example, Indo-China and Afghanistan. There is a world of difference in meaning and emphasis between the two. There ought to be some kind of limit to the degree of liberty to distort allowed to the Leader of the Opposition who, after all, purports to be the alternative Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister put his foot in it.

—The honourable member for Maranoa interrupts. How is that copper's black eye in Brisbane? Has it healed up yet? We have embarked on policies to increase the competitiveness and productivity of Australian industry. We have set in train programs of structural reform in industry and greater flexibility in the economy. These activities are designed to reverse Australia's traditional low export orientation so as to take advantage of the economic development taking place in this region. The Government of which the Leader of the Opposition was a senior member saw the necessity for this but never had the courage to attempt it. The point is important because one of the results of this activity has been continued export growth in a difficult trading environment. Between 1983-84 and 1986-87, the rate of growth in exports-that is, export receipts adjusted for inflation-to China, for instance, was nearly 30 per cent, more than triple the rate of growth over the period 1975-76 to 1982-83. To Japan, the growth rate from 1983-84 to 1986-87 was nearly 5 per cent per annum, a significant improvement on the negative real growth rate of the 1975-76 to 1982-83 period, and to Hong Kong exports grew by nearly 14 per cent over the period 1983-84 to 1986-87, well up on the 6 per cent per annum growth rate over the 1975-76 to 1982-1983 period. Exports to other countries have also grown strongly in real terms in recent years: to South Korea by nearly 9 per cent per annum and to the South Pacific, excluding New Zealand, by 3 per cent per annum. Average annual exports to members of the Association of South East Asian Nations have grown by nearly 6 per cent, despite the problems experienced by those economies during this period.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition charges that all this activity constitutes neglect. The kindest explanation for this is that its advisers have not kept it abreast of developments which are having such an influence on our developments as a force for economic and strategic progress and stability in our region. While all this progress has been taking place, we have heard nothing but negativism from the Opposition. It is constantly trying to denigrate the country and its economic performance-in the process, trying to instil uncertainty in quarters overseas which are involved in our more open economy. I am reminded of the Leader of the Opposition's speech in the United States in July 1986 where he spent fully 20 minutes criticising his own country before an audience of foreigners. It may be permissible, but I hardly think it advisable, constantly to denigrate one's own country at home. But to do so while overseas is a shameful and unpatriotic act. The Leader of the Opposition should still be embarrassed about what he did then.

Another regrettable Opposition misconception is that this Government has damaged the relationship with the United States with `gratuitous criticism'. The fact is that certain aspects of United States economic and trade policy directly affect and even jeopardise our industry, especially agriculture. This was recognised by the all-party delegations sent to the United States by this Parliament in 1986 and 1987. It is certainly in line with comments by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. If the Government had not pointed this out to our American friends in a forceful but constructive way, it would have failed in its duty. If the Government had not made the point-and lobbied energetically for it with both the Congress and the Administration-some elements of the United States trade Bills with particular impact on Australia would not have been dropped or modified. For example, I refer, to the failure of proposals which would have affected our exports of sugar. In the meantime, we continue to be concerned with the protectionist tone of the proposed United States trade legislation which could increase the power of the United States aggressively to pursue bilateral solutions to trade problems. I repeat: failure to continue vigorously placing our concerns before the United States Congress and Administration would be to neglect our primary obligation to protect Australian interests.

The Opposition it seems, prefers passive surrender in a situation for which it obviously has no stomach. Well, let Opposition members go and explain this to the farmers and others whose interests were and are under attack. We make no apology for fighting for Australia's interests. Failure to do so would be to neglect inexcusably a primary obligation to protect Australian interests. The United States accepts this, even if the Opposition in this Parliament does not. Admiral Hayes, United States Commander-in-Chief in the Pacific, understands it. Only three weeks ago, he gave an enthusiastic account of the state of the United States-Australian relationship to the National Defence University. He said:
Security co-operation between the United States and Australia has never been better. It is heartening to see the extent of mutual benefits that accrue from the alliance relationship.

Mr Shultz himself has pointed out that the relationship is `as strong and vigorous as ever, if not more so'. The Government is working energetically to support efforts to improve the framework of world trade through the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will be interested to know that the Round has a very broad agenda, which Australia supports: market access across all sectors, for example removal of non-tariff barriers and subsidies; trade in natural resource products; dispute settlement; rules for new areas such as trade in services and intellectual property rights. The Government is also intent on ensuring that the Uruguay Round comprehensively addresses Australia's concerns for reform of agricultural trade. This form of trade has never effectively come under General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade rules. It represents one of the most distorted sectors of world trade. Australia's active role in the Cairns group is intended to ensure that our interests will be effectively represented in trade negotiations.

The final difference on foreign policy between the Government and the Opposition which I wish to discuss today is probably the most important. It concerns the timid, derivative and dependent outlook permeating the Opposition's policy, as displayed in its Leader's Hobart speech. This is an attitude which the electorate quite properly rejected in 1983, 1984 and again in 1987. Taken to its logical conclusion, it would oppose, rather than encourage, moves by the superpowers to develop greater accord on crucial strategic issues, especially disarmament and arms control. The Australian Government has done all it can to facilitate this process in multilateral forums such as the United Nations General Assembly, the Security Council and the Conference on Disarmament. We have actively encouraged the process which has produced the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty, the first treaty actually to reduce the number of nuclear weapons. We welcome the treaty also because it sets important precedents for other arms control measures. It applies asymmetrical force reductions, for example, and its verification arrangements are uniquely intrusive and co-operative. Eliminating medium range missiles in Asia as well as Europe, it has particular relevance to us in that it reduces the threat to Asian targets which are significant to us-for example, in China, Japan and the Philippines. Moreover, it represents a significant improvement in superpower relations which only ideologues and the most reactionary Cold War warriors would deplore.

Mr Shultz has welcomed the constructive dialogue now taking place between the superpowers. The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation communique earlier this month hailed what it called `welcome signs of change' in Soviet policies which created `the prospect for greater openness in (Soviet) relations with their own people and with other nations'. A summit meeting will be held in Moscow between President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev, probably in May, at which arms control and disarmament issues will be prominent. Mr Shultz and Foreign Minister Shevardnadze are meeting on a monthly basis in the meantime.

In the face of all this exciting progress, these encouraging and constructive developments, what is the Opposition's position? The Opposition's reaction to these positive developments has been moans and cries of alarm and suspicion. The Australian Government does not hold these current signs of change with fear and loathing, as the Opposition does. It welcomes the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty as an example of these changes. It will cooperate actively with those nations which are trying to utilise the treaty in the cause of further arms control. Australia will, for example, continue to work actively for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, an agreement to eliminate chemical weapons, and an agreement to prevent an arms race in space and to control and reduce the use of conventional weapons.

There is an important point here. The superpower relationship is not the only area of change in international affairs. The whole field of international affairs is becoming rapidly more complex; its limits and its definitions are becoming ever more elusive. Global power has become more diffuse; the loci of power have multiplied. Issues have created themselves: human rights, for example, and its impact on the doctrine of national sovereignty and the domestic affairs of multicultural countries such as Australia. There is not a conflict between states or an infringement of human rights anywhere in the world that does not resonate in some ethnic community in Australia.

There are many other complexities with which we must learn to cope. We have at the same time the characteristics of a developing and a developed economy, dealing with a fusion of economic and political pressures. We are a pluralist democracy in a region in which plurality and democracy can be alien and even dangerous concepts. Such a time and such an environment call for creative response. The Government and people of Australia are fortunate that they are served by professional officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade who understand and demonstrate the necessary flexibility and adaptability to allow such policy responses to be developed. I would like to place on record here the Government's appreciation of this.

The Opposition reacts to the complexity and change facing us by diving into a funkhole hoping that great friends come to the rescue. Its Leader's Hobart speech is redolent of this abject and lickspittle mindset, unchanged from the 1960s. All his attempts in Hobart to bluster and fulminate cannot hide it. The Opposition clearly has no pride in this country, its capacities and the respect it has earned overseas for its actions. This is why its Leader travels around, putting his country down here and overseas. Australians as a whole, on the other hand, are showing that they are prepared to accept the change confronting them as an opportunity for progress and development. In this, they will receive the fullest possible encouragement and assistance from the Australian Government. Mr Deputy Speaker, I present the following paper:
Visit to Africa and the Middle East-Ministerial Statement, 17 March 1988.
and move:
That the House take note of the paper.
Motion (by Mr Hayden)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for North Sydney speaking for a period not exceeding 39 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a trivial, disordered and confused speech from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), laced with deliberate misrepresentations, bald inaccuracies and cheap gibes. It was a vintage effort by this Thomas Cook of Foreign Ministers, back here after his thirty-eighth overseas visit to speak to us briefly before he goes off on his next one. The bile, bitterness and mediocrity bubbled to the surface. About that I can do nothing but advise him to take a good rest.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go to two or three of the grossest misrepresentations and inaccuracies. Time does not permit me to go through them all but I shall take two or three. First of all I want to say something about the Sharpeville six. Yesterday I received a communication regarding the Sharpeville six. It concerned me greatly because it appeared that people who had nothing to do with the death of a man were going to be hanged. The person killed was a town councillor. He was killed in a particularly brutal manner. I will take some of the facts from the judgment of the South African court. In doing so, let me first say this: because I was concerned to get the facts of the matter, I spoke to the Minister's Department. I also spoke to the South African Embassy. I wanted to see the judgment of the appeal court. The Minister's Department has not been able to provide me with the judgment but the South African Embassy has provided me with considerable extracts from that judgment. As to the circumstances of the death of the person whose murder led to the trial of the Sharpeville six-there were originally eight-I quote this from the judgment:

As he was lying on the ground stones thrown by the mob rained down on him. Some members of the mob went up to him and struck his head with stones. When he was lying quite motionless, he was dragged into the street. Attempts were made to place him on his burning motor car, but each time he slid off it. Petrol was poured over him and he was set alight.

A human being was set alight. I now go to excerpts from the appeal court decision dealing with some of the accused. Eight were tried, six were convicted of murder. Two were originally convicted of public violence, but on appeal their conviction was overturned. Let me just take from that judgment three extracts, and as I do so let us keep in mind very clearly what the Minister said about the Sharpeville six. That was, I remind honourable members:
Six people not directly involved in a violent incident are about to be hanged as a gesture towards the South African Government's attempts to prop up its apartheid system.
Had that been so, it would have been a terrible miscarriage of justice. Let me quote:
Accused No. 1.

He was one of the persons who grabbed hold of the deceased near the fence between the house of the deceased and Maile, and who wrestled with the deceased for the possession of his pistol. He was also the person who threw the first stone at the deceased as he was crossing the fence, which struck him on the head and felled him.

I remind honourable members that the deceased was burnt to death. Does that seem to be, as the Minister would have us believe, a violent incident in which these people were not directly involved? Next I go to what is said by the court about accused No. 3:

He was one of the small group of men who caught hold of the deceased as he was running in the direction of Maile's house, and who wrestled with him for possession of his pistol. He was the man who in fact succeeded in taking the deceased's pistol away from him.
I remind honourable members again what the Foreign Minister, with all the support of his Department, has said to us:
Six people not directly involved in a violent incident-
I repeat: not directly involved in a violent incident-
are about to be hanged as a gesture towards the South African Government's attempts to prop up its apartheid system.

I ask the Minister: Does he really believe and assert that a person-to take accused No. 1-who wrestled with the deceased for possession of his pistol and who threw the stone which felled the deceased is not directly involved? Does he assert that accused No. 3, who wrestled with the deceased for possession of his pistol and who succeeded in taking the deceased's pistol away from him, was not directly involved in a violent incident? We are talking about murder. We are talking about a man being stoned and burnt to death. I cannot understand how the Foreign Minister of this country, with the great resources of the Department available to him, can make the statement in the House that he has made.

I am reading from a document provided to me by the South African Embassy. I say again that I sought the judgment from the Department. Since I am a lawyer of many years experience and I understand judgments, I understand that sometimes little bits of judgments are quoted out of context, which can lead to a misunderstanding of events. Either what I am reading is totally wrong or the Minister, with those resources of the Department behind him, has directly misled this House. That misleading of the House was also made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) because he said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A member cannot assert that another member has deliberately misled the House, except by substantive motion, so the honourable member for North Sydney needs to withdraw the allegation.
—Shall I say that he has misled the House and misrepresented the facts. Does that satisfy you?
—Order! I need the honourable member to withdraw the allegation that the Minister misled the House.

—If you require me to do that, Mr Deputy Speaker, to accord with Standing Orders, I will certainly do so. Let me make it perfectly plain that this amounts-and I am not saying that the Minister lied to the House-to a direct misrepresentation, unless the facts that have been given to me are wrong. Let me move on to the next misrepresentation which has been made by the Minister. I quote something the Minister said on the subject of the Indian Ocean, when he moved on to address, in his haphazard manner, some of the great issues of the day:

SPEECH.PARA: I regret also that the Opposition's position on southern Africa shows a dangerous myopia about Indian Ocean affairs. This is a region which is so important to our strategic interests and our trade and communications links that we consult annually with the United States on developments there.
That sounds very strong. He goes on:
These developments have great significance for us. This is why we have increased our diplomatic and defence presence there since 1983.

I confess that that puzzled me because he was talking about the Indian Ocean region. Let me remind honourable members that in November 1987 this Government closed two embassies-the Ethiopian Embassy, which is not a littoral state to the Indian Ocean but which is to the Red Sea, and the Tanzanian Embassy, which is a littoral state to the Indian Ocean. Does that amount to increasing diplomatic and defence presence? I point out that we have withdrawn defence attaches from Pakistan and India under this Government. Does that amount to increasing diplomatic and defence presence in the Indian Ocean area? These are the two largest states in the Indian Ocean area in terms of population-India, of course, being far and away the greatest in importance, one might think, to our interests. Moreover, we are no longer funding Indian and Pakistani military participants at the Joint Services Staff College. Does that sound like an increase in diplomatic and defence presence? Of course, it does not. How can the Minister say these things? Next, he made a misrepresentation concerning myself. I will put to one side the cheap jibes with which the Minister seems to preoccupy himself and pick up what he said about me. He talked about problems in the southern African area regarding humanitarian issues, and said:

If the honourable member for North Sydney, having heard this, still disagrees with the idea of giving humanitarian aid to the starving and the famished of southern Africa, let him go and explain himself to the high protein biscuit producers . . .
Note the central part of that statement:
If the honourable member for North Sydney . . . still disagrees with the idea of giving humanitarian aid to the starving and famished of southern Africa . . .

I have made a number of statements about this foolish Minister and the unwise way in which this Government has dealt with aid issues. I shall come back to that question in a few minutes. I have not said that we should terminate or not give any humanitarian aid to the famished and starving in southern Africa as the Minister's statement most clearly states. Once again that is a direct misrepresentation. In this case it is a direct misrepresentation of what I have said. I have said two things. First, priorities need to be reconsidered. I have issued a number of statements on this subject. In a statement that I made on 22 February 1988 I said:

Would it not have been a much more sensible use of Australia's humanitarian aid to Africa to concentrate it in one area of great need and supervision by Australian aid personnel to make sure that aid gets to the people who need it and that it is not politically or corruptly misused.

I would have thought that there was a great deal of sense in that kind of approach to aid problems. Let me now turn to some other and broader issues and leave to one side the Minister's misrepresentations because, as I have said, time will not permit me to correct them all. The Minister has now held his position for five years. He has been, I would think, the most travelled of all Foreign Ministers and he has spoken copiously on subjects of foreign affairs. I suppose that it is worth while trying to make an assessment of what he has done and what he represents. Is he serious and constructive? Is he a person who pursues long-term objectives and policies and does so steadfastly? Or does he have an obsession with illusions, symbols, words, initiatives begun and abandoned and policies adopted and compromised? Certainly, he cannot get facts right.
Let us judge him by some of the issues which he has raised. Some of them are touched on centrally in what he has said today. I refer to the issues of peace, aid, southern Africa and human rights.

Let us take, first of all, the issue of peace and two particular concerns of the Minister-first, the Ambassador for Disarmament and, secondly, the Indian Ocean zone of peace, to which he referred today. The position of the Ambassador for Disarmament was an initiative of this Minister. On 20 October 1983 he said:
To make Australia's voice heard in the councils of the world in a way unparalleled in the past-
which was a Government aim-
an important part of that decision was the appointment of the first Australian Ambassador for Disarmament.

What was the Ambassador for Disarmament to do? What more could he do than could be done by our diplomatic representation overseas in the United Nations? What special qualities would he have? Of course, that question has never been answered. What has happened? The position of the Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Richard Butler, whose time in that office cost us $3m-and were it well spent, I would not be the least concerned about it-has been scrapped. I do not believe that any statement has been made by the Minister as to the reasons why his position has been scrapped, but it has been. The job that he was doing has gone back to being done by the United Nations representation. Is that not sensible? Is that not where it should have been all the time? What did we have? We had, with the Ambassador for Disarmament and, as well, we have with the Peace Research Institute which has been set up, merely empty posturing, the kind of warm and meaningless banality that so appeals to some members of the Australian Labor Party. The bauble has been taken from him by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh).

Let us next go to the Indian Ocean zone of peace proposal. This is another proposal dear to the Minister's heart. He referred to it again today. In the Evatt Memorial Lecture, which he gave on 7 July 1983, he said this of the Indian Ocean:

Our position is different from that of the previous Government: we will not oppose the development of a consensus in support of a conference on an Indian Ocean zone of peace. This we believe to be a thoroughly desirable ideal.

We all support peace but let us support peace in a way which has meaning. What is this Indian Ocean zone of peace proposal? The United States is not in favour of the zone of peace proposals, which would keep naval forces out of international waters. The Indian Ocean zone of peace is not supported by the Reagan Administration. The Indian Ocean zone of peace would cut across current United States strategy. I believe that it is very necessary for Australia, in its own self-interest, to support United States strategy in the region as United States strategy recognises naval deployment as an essential element in the defence of United States and, therefore, Western security interests. An Indian Ocean zone of peace would eliminate all bases, military installations and logistical supply facilities, according to the United Nations General Assembly resolution 2832 of 16 December 1971. This would directly affect the United States Indian Ocean naval presence which, at present, amounts to one battle group and would also affect the very important United States facility at Diego Garcia.

In short, we have a proposal which is, in a very real sense, meaningless. To say that one has a zone of peace means nothing. One is not going to prevent Soviet ships from traversing one's zone of peace. It has about as much realism going for it as some of the council signs one sees in Sydney and other places saying, `This is a nuclear free council' or `You are in a nuclear free zone'. Yet if one reads some of the other things this Minister has said one finds that he has made it perfectly plain that he believes, as I think most of us do, that in the dreadful eventuality of a nuclear war we would all suffer. One does not make zones of peace by agreeing upon words. I must ask this question: Where, incidentally, would that leave the interests of India? India has taken delivery of a Soviet nuclear-powered submarine. Reportedly, she is to take delivery of two or three more.

I turn to the subject of aid, as it is another matter which the Minister has given great prominence to, although he gave much greater prominence to it in opposition than he does now. There is, as is known, a United Nations target of 0.7 per cent of national income of the wealthy industrialised countries which should be applied for the purposes of aid to the poorer countries. Australia has never met this target, but in the last year of the Fraser Government foreign aid amounted to 0.47 per cent of gross national product (GNP). Labor came to power with a commitment by this Minister to apply 0.7 per cent of GNP for foreign aid with a further commitment to apply foreign aid equal to one per cent of GNP by at least 1990. That latter figure looks merely fanciful.

In fact, foreign aid under this Government has sunk to 0.36 per cent of GNP, the lowest level of support provided by any Australian government in the last 25 years. That has been one of the outstanding contributions that this Minister and this Government have made in the foreign aid area. Nevertheless, the Minister speaks of our foreign aid obligations. Let us look to some of the things that we should be doing. The Minister accepted the recommendations of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program. In the Jackson Committee Review and in the Minister's own speeches, humanitarian, strategic and economic purposes are laid down as the criteria for foreign aid. One of the other criteria for the giving of foreign aid should be consistency and predictability, as well as getting one's priorities right. What is one of the most important countries in terms of foreign aid and closeness to Australia? It is Papua New Guinea. What did this Government do? It cut foreign aid in a way which damaged our standing with that country, without warning to that country and which could only leave other island countries in our region pondering about our commitment to giving foreign aid. I refer to the Age of 18 September 1986, which states:
The Papua New Guinea Government has reacted fiercely to the new Australian aid cuts and accused the Hawke Government of discourtesy and paternalism.
This was said, incidentally, about a government which is constantly accusing us of both those things. It goes on:

The Deputy Prime Minister, Sir Julius Chan, said the proposed cuts of up to $45 million a year would seriously weaken the relationship with Australia and open the way for Soviet manipulation of PNG. Sir Julius said PNG had never enjoyed good relations with Labor governments and the aid decision confirmed a deterioration since `the best years' during the Fraser Government.
The Prime Minister, Mr Wingti, accused Australia of a lack of courtesy in announcing the aid cuts and said they could `defeat' his Government's strategy to make PNG more self-reliant.

These were aid cuts of $10m in each of the next two financial years. That is the way in which we dealt with aid-no warning, no priorities, no consideration and no understanding that we had made a huge long term investment in aid to Papua New Guinea. There was no understanding of the strength of the relationship and how it was influenced by the view Papua New Guinea had that we were reliable people to do business with. What happened? We have aid cuts brought about in a way calculated to damage our interests with Papua New Guinea and in the South Pacific region.

On his recent trip, however, the Foreign Minister went to southern Africa. He went with an original grant of $55m which was topped up by another $45m-incidentally, equal, I believe, to the previous cuts in aid to Papua New Guinea-which was to go to the Southern African Development Coordination Conference which was made up of nine nations. The question that must be raised is whether the aid that the Foreign Minister took with him satisfied the criteria that this Government had laid down, which I think are sensible criteria. Those criteria have been followed by other governments, namely, humanitarian, strategic or economic interests. Certainly, we are not talking about the advancement of Australia's economic interests. Certainly, the states of southern Africa bordering on or adjacent to the states bordering on South Africa are not central or even marginally close to our strategic interests. Nor was the aid given for humanitarian purposes. I say that because the problems of the area were long known before the Minister went there. He went there to take an aid package with him. If this Government had been deeply concerned about the needs of the area, this $45m would have been applied well before the Minister went. But he went taking it with him and giving it for what purpose? It was for the furtherance of a political objective which was to justify the high profile that we had taken over the apartheid issue and the high profile that we had taken more particularly over the issue of sanctions to try to give some sort of a buttress to our claim to be a leader in this area. It was not given as humanitarian aid because one of the countries it was to go to was Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe is a country with a highly efficient farming industry. The Minister will know that; he has been there. I know that; I have been there.

So let us understand that this cynical little exercise was an exercise in attempted political manipulation-no more and no less than that-in an area which has incidentally seen such things as the closure of the Ethiopian Embassy, an embassy that we should arguably have kept open because of the aid commitments that we have to that country and the very great problems that country has. I think it is the home of the Organisation of African States.

I want to say something about South Africa and southern Africa. The Minister in his speech has repeated the canard that Labor constantly puts around, the old misrepresentation that Opposition members really do not care about apartheid, that they will not do anything. Apartheid is a system which we find repugnant because it is based on race. It is wrong because it is based on race. What, therefore, should be the policy of the Australian Government? It should be a policy to secure peaceful transition from what we now have to a peaceful, power sharing situation in which all South Africans can participate in the democratic process. God knows that is hard. There is little on the South African scene that gives one very much heart. This was the view that I expressed to my colleagues on 5 August 1985. I will read it to make two points: first of all, to point to what the Opposition policy is and, secondly, to point to the illusion that is perpetrated by those who take the soft option which is to impose sanctions. I stated:

Opposition policy on South Africa seeks fundamental changes in South Africa's internal policies. These changes can occur peacefully, or at least with a minimum of bloodshed, or as a result of a prolonged and bloody process of internal conflict. Change through violence (aside altogether from the carnage and destruction it would involve) poses incalculable risks, and is likely to lead to a very much worse regime, and one with a pronounced anti-Western bias. A takeover from the extreme Left would be a distinct possibility. South Africa is a very rich prize.
I went on to say this about the sanctions argument:

Of cardinal importance is the consideration that sanctions can have precisely the opposite effect on the target government and its supporters to that which it is hoped they will achieve. The current moves by different countries to impose sanctions could well lead white South Africans to think their very existence is threatened. The more conservative elements will be reinforced in their opposition to change and the position of those urging reforms will be undermined. Sanctions are all too likely to become an external enemy against which the South African Government, and the whites, feeling increasingly isolated will unite. Their concern for the future can only be sharpened by events in Zimbabwe and Uganda, and by Mr Hayden's statement that the government's objective is a `multi-racial society based on a single vote franchise'. There is no prospect that a majority of white South Africans will agree to a simple one man one vote franchise without safeguards. It would amount to agreeing to their own disappearance.

Furthermore, if only minor or petty sanctions are imposed, they are very likely to produce the reverse political effect on the South African Government and its supporters to that which is desired without exerting any real pressure. On the other hand, if sanctions with teeth are imposed, and the South African economy damaged, the direct consequence (as well as having the reverse political effect) will be to harm those we are trying to help, the black South Africans, particularly those at the lower end of the income scale. A damaged economy will produce unemployment; unemployment will tend to raise the level of social unrest, and hence the level of violence. A stagnant economy, with high levels of unemployment and social unrest, is not a good prospect for peaceful change.
To sum up, the probable effect of sanctions will be to stiffen resistance to change-precisely the opposite to what is intended.

Is that not exactly what has happened in South Africa? Change has come to an end. It came to an end in about 1985. Reforms have been made which, in our context, are small; in the South African context they are large. Just as changes which are taking place in the Soviet Union are, in Soviet eyes large, in our eyes they are small when we gauge the Soviet system against our system. We have had Mr Botha winning an election on the basis of Western sanctions. I will quote very briefly from an article in the American Spectator by a former associate editor of the Johannesburg Sunday Times who stated:
But just how effective has the whole sanctions package been-disinvestment included? How have the promises survived more than a year of practice?

The first answer is not long in coming. President Botha cashed in quickly, using this unexpected American bonus to call and win an election in early May, calculating correctly that external threat would induce the white electorate to rally round the flag.
I quote again:
. . . that external threat would induce the white electorate to rally round the flag.

That is what has happened. Political and social reform has halted. Disinvestment by overseas companies, especially American companies, has seen the end to many social responsibility programs and integrationist work practices. Black unemployment, and with it black suffering, has increased. The perception of isolation from the world has strengthened the views and positions of the extremists with sanctions seen as the external enemy. Support for the extremist conservative party has grown and, with it, the reform minded progressive Federal Party has suffered a wounding loss of support and has been unseated as the official opposition. Sanctions are opposed by many moderate reformists in South Africa-by Chief Buthelezi, Helen Suzman and Alan Paton.

Let me come to the question of damage to the blacks. It is very easy standing here or sitting here to say, `Well, it doesn't really matter. What matters is that we should apply sanctions and forget about the consequences'. One reason why we reject sanctions is the damage sanctions do to the people at the lowest end of the pile-the poor black workers. This is precisely the reason why the front line states have refused to apply sanctions. I was clearly reminded when I went to Zimbabwe in 1986 that it will not apply sanctions because it understands that if sanctions are applied and the border closed its economy will suffer very greatly. Suffering in its economy will cause unemployment. Unemployment will cause further suffering. Zimbabwe does not want that and that is exactly the reason why it says, `Impose sanctions upon South Africa. Let the suffering take place there, but we will not be involved in the imposition of sanctions because we do not want our own people to suffer and, indeed, that would be politically dangerous'. It is a very cynical exercise.

I think we have to understand that there are some very bad governments in Africa and some gross violations of rights there. Let us remember that in terms of every day living there have been far worse countries for blacks to live in than South Africa. Take Uganda, for example. What is our aim? Our aim is to achieve peaceful transition. I believe that a far more thoughtful approach to this problem is needed. The situation is tragic. It involves all South Africans: the Cape coloureds, the whites, the blacks and the Asians. Unless a peaceful solution can be found, the consequences for the people of South Africa could be perfectly dreadful in a very brutal way. The isolation of South Africa and the imposition of sanctions will not induce peaceful transition. Indeed, as I have said, they have stalled the process of reform, tentative although at times that has certainly been.
Let me say, lastly, something about the subject of human rights. The Foreign Minister has extolled human rights policy. On 9 December 1983 he said:
As an effective policy this will require us to exercise skill in choosing our moment knowing whom to contact and which levers to pull.

What about Mr Grey's position? He has been in Mozambique for four months-he is only charged in the last two or three days. When the Minister went to Mozambique he knew about Mr Grey's situation-he would have been briefed on the matter-and he got, he tells us, assurances. This is a pitiful exercise in diplomacy. These assurances were given to him by the Government and were not kept. The Minister was asked a question from his own side as to the reasons why the assurances were not kept. The answer was, he said:

When I was there I took the opportunity of making inquiries in Mr Grey's interests and in particular to see what processes were in place to have his trial brought forward. It was my understanding that there was an undertaking to bring the trial forward within a relatively short time. It has been asserted by the Mozambiquans that they only undertook to bring the papers in relation to Mr Grey's case before the court. That could easily have been so in that translation may have been a problem.

The translators are not translating, the assurances are not understood, undertakings are broken. The position we took upon this was a very direct one-that no aid should be given unless and until Mr Grey got a fair trial, one that was demonstrably fair, or was released. If the Australian Government does not come to the assistance of an Australian citizen in that kind of situation, who will protect his interests? It is wrong to use, it is said, aid to protect the rights of an Australian. That was put in the course of an interview I conducted on radio with a foreign service representative speaking for the Minister. He said, `You cannot link the two'. Let us remember this: it is wrong, according to this view of things, to use aid to protect the rights of an Australian. You cannot have linkage. Yet it is right to use aid for the political objective of seeking to justify and maintain a high profile on the South African issues, a profile, incidentally, which the Government of Mozambique and similar governments obviously treated with contempt, knowing as they do that an attempt is being made to buy a position through aid.

Let us look at where the Minister stands: on aid, promises are not kept; Papua New Guinea is affronted and used as a political weapon to further political interests; but aid is not used as a defence of the rights of an Australian to a fair trial. The man will be tried by the revolutionary military tribunal, on last notice. On peace, the Ambassador for Disarmament has been dropped. The Indian Ocean zone of peace is still being talked about. Effectively it is stalled and would be against the interests of our closest ally and against our own security interests. On the subject of South Africa, sanctions have played into the hands of extremists and attitudes have hardened. That is a summary in those areas of the stewardship of this erratic Foreign Minister.
Debate (on motion by Mr Charles) adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tim Fischer

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order with regard to the report which has just been tabled. I do so on a constructive basis. My point of order relates in part to the new procedures obtaining for the first time in the history of this Parliament. I am minded to do so also because private member's Bills are precious commodities. There have been fewer than 90 Bills introduced since 1901 and only nine of those have ever made it into law.

INTERJECT.PARA: Madam Speaker, I want to draw your attention to the Sessional Orders adopted on 9 December 1987 operative from the ides of March. I refer you particularly to page 14, which states:

The Bill shall then be read a first time and notwithstanding the provisions of standing order 218 the next sitting Thursday shall be appointed for the member to move that this Bill be now read a second time.

The private member's Bill introduced this morning very capably by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Flags Amendment Bill. I fully support that Bill. What needs clarification is that I received an intimation after that Bill was presented to the House that in fact the second reading would come on next Thursday. We have now had the Chairman of the Selection Committee in a most proper manner bring down his report. Whilst we will not know until the Notice Paper is printed in the formal sense, I am led to believe that the very important Flags Amendment Bill will not now come on for second reading debate next Thursday. I submit to the House that that is in part possibly in contravention of that sessional order. That sessional order says:
Notwithstanding the provisions of standing order 218 . . .
Standing order 218 says:
Notwithstanding the provisions of standing order 217 . . .

So, in effect, the sessional order knocks out both standing order 218 and standing order 217. I submit that in that circumstance, notwithstanding convention and commonly used phraseology, the second reading of this Bill should not only be listed as an order of the day associated with that part of the Notice Paper but in fact the Leader of the Opposition should have the right to move that the Bill be now read a second time in a private member's role, as it is denoted private members' legislation so that the House could consider the Flags Amendment Bill. I raise this in a constructive way in view of the new Standing Orders and I invite your ruling and determination in respect of this matter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The new procedures adopted by the House for the ordering and consideration of private members' business provide for certain precedence to private members' Bills. First, priority is given to notices by private members to present Bills. Upon presentation the sponsor may speak for a short period prior to the Bill being read a first time. The first example of the operation of this procedure was this morning, with the Leader of the Opposition introducing his Flags Amendment Bill. The rationale behind this provision as suggested by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure is that it gives all members a chance to peruse a Bill as early as possible and gives the Selection Committee the opportunity to examine the Bill in assessing its claims for later precedence against other Bills and motions.

INTERJECT.PARA: Second, the sessional order provides that once a Bill has passed the second reading, further consideration is accorded precedence over other private members' business. Sessional orders do not provide that, once introduced, a private member's Bill must be considered on the next sitting Thursday. It is up to the Selection Committee to determine, in accordance with the general principles agreed to by the House, on which sitting Thursday the sponsor may move `That this Bill be now read a second time'. The words in sessional order 104A that `the next sitting Thursday shall be appointed for a Member to move ``That this Bill be now read a second time'' ', insofar as they relate to Thursdays, are no different in effect to the commonly used words `resumption of debate be made an order of the day for the next sitting'. That is, any future priority on `the next sitting Thursday' or `the next sitting' is determined by the provisions of the standing and sessional orders. In the case of private members' Bills it is determined by the Selection Committee subject to the provisions outlined above, and I rule accordingly.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The abuse of position and power causing a decline in the standards of Government under the Hawke administration.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are going to debate a political scam that went horribly wrong. We are going to debate the involvement of a Minister who was too clever by half and who had this political stunt blow up in his face, and we are going to debate the failure of a Prime Minister who is hamstrung by fear over his own political position and scared to take the action that is required of someone who holds that high office.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are going to debate is the involvement of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in the release of confidential Health Insurance Commission (HIC) records. So that everybody who is listening to this debate today will understand what we are talking about, I propose to go through it step by step in great detail. I note at the outset that since this issue first came up the Minister has not issued one word in his defence. He has not come into this chamber and been prepared to debate this issue with anyone on this side of the House.

What happened was that the Australian Labor Party, for its own political gains and motives, decided that it would score points off the doctors in Australia. Its members thought, `How can we do it? We will establish a political vehicle'. They called it the national price watch network, and they found the pawn who would be part of this stunt, and he was the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear). He got together with the Minister for Community Services and Health and said, `What I really need, Minister, is some information that will let me score points off the doctors, something that will let us argue our point of view in this medical debate'. So the Minister said, `Right, we will get it for you'. So the Minister or his office got on the phone, or wrote a letter or somehow conveyed their desire to the Health Insurance Commission to have certain information. That information came to the Minister's office and from there it was conveyed to the honourable member for Canning.

The Minister knew from the outset what was going on. He knew what the information would be used for and he knew exactly the type of information the honourable member was seeking. This is the point of the entire argument. The Minister knew the character of that information. He said in statements in various places that it was statistics, but later I will explain exactly why he is wrong.

The important point is that the Minister was in complete agreement with the honourable member for Canning and was prepared to cooperate in the obtaining of this information. This information, of course, was specific case information relating to the affairs of people. We have subsequently learnt that in addition-and that is what the Minister authorised to be provided, and it is very important that it be noted that he did authorise its provision-there was identifying information provided also. There were doctors' provider numbers attached to that specific case information.

The Minister has said, `I did not know'. That is not accurate; he did know. He authorised the obtaining of the information. He then said, `I did not do it; my staff did it'. That does not matter. As the Minister, he is responsible. He is the officer as defined under the Health Insurance Commission Act and he has to wear the responsibility. He said, `Anyway, even if the other two defences don't stand up, they were statistics and we are allowed to publish that sort of information'. The fact is that they were not statistics, and I will demonstrate that later, and in no way could they be described as statistics.

It is interesting that the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in this issue so far has been to the extent of obtaining a quick opinion from the Solicitor-General. He has said, `The Solicitor-General has said the Minister has got nothing to worry about, so I am not going to worry about it. We have got one opinion that says that'. There is now another opinion that has been presented to the Prime Minister. He has had it for 48 hours and he has had time to peruse it. He told us today that it has gone to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) but that it is not going to go to the Director of Public Prosecutions. Where is the logic in his approach? If there is one opinion that says the Minister is free and clear and the Prime Minister is not going to do anything else, and if there is a second opinion, an authoritative opinion, an opinion well regarded in the profession, which says that the Minister has got a case to answer, why is the Prime Minister not prepared to act?
I would like to quote the Prime Minister at a different time and in a different context, because his attitude changes depending upon the context. He said:
If a man . . . shouts from the roof tops that those in high office should be subject to scrutiny he should have exactly those standards applied to itself.

The Minister is in high office. He should have the opportunity to be examined publicly; there should be scrutiny. Even the Director of Public Prosecutions, I believe, in the past has said that those in high office should have the opportunity to prove their innocence in public. Well, it is about time that this whole issue was referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions.
Let me go to the Minister's defence. Section 130 (1) of the Health Insurance Act makes it very clear indeed that the Minister has a case to answer. That section states that a person shall not:

. . . after he ceases to be, an officer, make a record of, or divulge or communicate to any person, any information with respect to the affairs of another person acquired by him in the performance of his duties, or in the exercise of his powers or functions . . .

That provision relates to information about another person. It does not say that it has to specifically identify that other person. It simply says that he shall not make available information that relates to another person. As I said, the information given to the honourable member for Canning was a computer printout of cases-not statistics, but cases, information, relating to specific professional medical treatment of individuals by specific doctors. One could not get a more clear cut case of information relating to another person. Section 130 of the Act is a large section. Subsection (14) of that section makes it clear that the Minister is an officer. Subsection (14) says:
In this section, ``officer'' means a person performing the duties, or exercising powers of functions, under, or in relation to this Act.

What clearer definition of an officer, as it applies to a Minister, could one have than that? The Minister's defence that he provided statistics just does not hold water because subsection (5) of section 130 says:

Nothing in the preceding provisions of this section prohibits the publication of statistics by the Commonwealth, by the Commission or the Commonwealth Statistician but such statistics shall not be published in a manner that enables the identification of any individual patient or an individual practitioner.
