It is obvious that the material provided was not statistics, and, because the provider numbers were attached, it did provide for the identification of doctors, and perhaps even the patients.

I think it is also illustrative to look at the definition of statistics. As I said, computer print-outs were given to the honourable member for Canning. The definition of `statistics' in The Macquarie Dictionary-since there is no definition of statistics in the legislation-talks about the use of numerical facts or data bearing on a subject or matter, their collection and classification. The computer print-out was just a crude statement of information; there was no attempt to classify it.

The publication of this material is an interesting question. There was no attempt by the Minister to actually publish it. If it was published, it was published by the honourable member for Canning. The Minister authorised the release of information from the Health Insurance Commission to one person, the honourable member for Canning-not to the public. For the benefit of those listening, let me read the definition of `publish', again from The Macquarie Dictionary. One of the definitions is `to make publicly or generally known'. Did the Minister do that? No. He sought the information from the Health Insurance Commission, authorised its distribution to the honourable member for Canning-one person, hardly generally known-and the honourable member for Canning took it upon himself to publish this material. There is a strong prima facie case, without referring to the opinion of which the Prime Minister now has the benefit, to indicate that the Minister got involved in a political stunt that has gone seriously wrong because he did not bother to honour his obligations as set down in the statutes under which he operates in relation to the HIC.

The Minister has said, `We may have been in breach of the Act but it is not my fault; my staff did it, so I am free and clear'. Let me say that there is an absolute liability upon the Minister. There is no option under section 130 (1) for him to say that he did not know. That is not a defence. An honest and reasonable belief that the information was not going to identify a person is not available to him because the intent of the section is very clear: it is to preserve the confidentiality of individual government records, and there is no indication in the words used in that subsection that there should be any defence of ignorance. It is about time the Minister recognised that and shouldered the responsibility himself rather than trying to fob it off onto his staff.

In addition to that, the Minister took no actual or specific steps to ensure that the material did not provide specific identification of any individual. He knew the type of material, he knew it was not statistics, he knew it was case by case material, but he did not bother to ensure there were no provider numbers. He referred to some vague office practice. We still have not seen a definition of what that office practice was. No specific inquiries were made by the Minister of his staff about the nature of the material or its format and there was no specific reminder to his staff to ensure there was no identification of doctors or specific patients in that material. That just compounds the transgression that the Minister made when he first authorised the supply of material-that he knew that it referred to actual cases and he knew he was going to supply to a third party, namely, the honourable member for Canning. What really makes it worse is that he knew the political purpose for which that material would be used. It is an abuse of his office to provide political material to a third party for blatant party political purposes and the Minister should pay the price. If he had one ounce of honour, he would resign.

Of course, the Minister is aware of the consequences of not guarding the confidentiality of HIC information. This is not the first time we have seen this Minister in trouble over the release of information. In the middle of the doctors' dispute in New South Wales-a very political dispute-confidential information about doctors' incomes, available to the Government only through the HIC, suddenly became the property of the Press and was published in the Sydney Morning Herald. The Minister knew that sort of thing had happened in the past and he knew the sensitivity of it. We also saw what happened in the Dr Parker case in Newcastle, when it took the Minister six weeks to get the Australian Federal Police involved in the case to find out how the information provided to Dr Parker became generally known. Of course, there is the McGoldrick case in Victoria where a magistrate strongly suggested that confidential Medicare information had been made available privately to the Victorian police. So, the Minister has a record of being quite slack in the protection and safeguarding of the confidentiality of this information.

This is compounded by the track record of the HIC itself. It is a suspect organisation. It spent millions of dollars developing the ID card without parliamentary authority. The Auditor-General has said of the HIC that it deliberately understated the cost of developing the ID card. This is the nature of the organisation. This is the quality of the management that the Minister is used to dealing with. When he sought this information for the honourable member for Canning he still did not take any specific action to make sure he fulfilled his obligations under the legislation. There is a prima facie case that the Minister has to answer, and in the light of the ongoing Australian Federal Police investigation it would be desirable and honourable for the Minister voluntarily to stand down. If this is not going to happen, the Prime Minister should act, but the Prime Minister's position is so weakened by recent events that began with a by-election in Adelaide and progressed through a whole series of seedy and unseemly incidents over the past couple of weeks that his political position is so tenuous that he cannot risk the jettisoning of another Minister for any reason, no matter how strong the case. It is an indictment not only of the Minister but also of the Prime Minister and of the attitude of the Australian Labor Party to the government of this country.

Let me recount exactly what we are talking about today. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is standing in as surrogate defender for the Minister for Community Services and Health-without much enthusiasm, I should say-will try to obscure the whole issue. We have a political stunt, with a Minister who was a willing accomplice, that blew up in his face. He released private and confidential information that identified doctors and possibly patients-the information of another person. He is classically in breach of section 130 of his own legislation. Ignorance is no defence; he cannot blame his staff. There is a conflict of legal opinion. It is not good enough to refer it to the Attorney-General. The matter should be dealt with by the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is improper for the Minister to remain in office while an Australian Federal Police investigation is going on into this incident, and the Prime Minister should stand the Minister down, if he is not prepared to stand himself down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two things can be said in favour of the Opposition's matter of public importance today. The first is that it constitutes an appropriate apology from the tactics committee of the Opposition for its unsuccessful efforts to fling mud yesterday on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with respect to the pathetic little report on gambling activities. The Opposition's mea culpa is to introduce tedium into the House today. If this is put by way of apology to the Government for the Opposition's extraordinarily unsuccessful tactic of yesterday, and if the Opposition is prepared to prolong or accommodate us in our efforts to have a totally tedious House-and any government of the day always finds tedium in the House useful-then we as a government ought to be grateful for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing that we ought to be grateful for concerning the Opposition's matter of public importance today is that whilst Opposition members chose to focus on the now thoroughly dead issue with regard to the handling of this question by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) it has, by the breadth of the coverage of its matter of public importance, given us an opportunity to debate generally the question of the standards of government and requirements upon government and, by implication, requirements upon oppositions.

Both in the issue that has been raised in this matter and, more generally, by the Opposition's conduct on policy matters overall, we are confronted with a situation where we have an Opposition that has been in opposition for five years and an Opposition Leader who has been the Opposition Leader for three years. In that time we have yet to see, on the major issues of the day, a single policy emanating from the Opposition about anything-not one thing. The Opposition in its five years in opposition and the three-year term of the Opposition Leader has not conformed to the fundamental obligation of an Opposition to oppose, to present alternatives, and to bring forward policies to enable those policies to be debated in the general community. That is the nub of parliamentary democratic practice. In regard to the performance of the Opposition, its members have been and continue to be abject failures. They could not form an alternative government. They can be simply parties of snipers. They hide in the bush, ambush us and sling mud, but at the end of the day they cannot offer an alternative to the people of this nation.

This week the Opposition's tactics have been manifest by that type of mud slinging, ambushing tactic normally performed by backbenchers. But because there are no alternative activities available the Leader of the Opposition without policies has, in this case, unprecedentedly performed these tactics himself. The only reason the the Opposition has pursued these tactics this week, so far as we on this side of the House can see, is that it does not want policy issues debated while the campaigning proceeds for the New South Wales State election. It realises that if policy issues are debated while the New South Wales State election proceeds, Mr Greiner's case will be manifestly damaged, despite the fact that Mr Greiner attempts to distance himself massively from John Howard's type of Opposition Leader performance, by virtue of the sorts of comments Mr Greiner has been making all through his campaign, `I do not have a John Howard problem'.

Let me just completely dismiss the substance of what was raised by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). I point out to the honourable member that the debate has moved on somewhat to an attempt by both journalists and ourselves to get some understanding of what the health policies of the Opposition are. First, the Solicitor-General gave an opinion based on the available facts. If there is anything further to be done about the matter, there is a federal police investigation proceeding and that investigation is properly before them at the moment. In terms of whether this matter has been adequately covered, I think the Government can safely stand by the opinion of the Solicitor-General.

What is posed as the alternative to the opinion of the Solicitor-General is the opinion of a former Liberal Minister on behalf of orthopaedic surgeons. We know what the hidden agenda of the orthopaedic surgeons is. We have that hidden agenda of the orthopaedic surgeons here in a document apparently leaked to the President of the Doctors Reform Society New South Wales. That leaked document from a New South Wales public hospital reveals a list of demands from orthopaedic specialists, which was a blueprint for exorbitant fees and the end of the public hospital system, according to the President of the Doctors Reform Society of New South Wales, Dr Robert Marr. The document was a proposal from orthopaedic surgeons addressed to the Department of Health, leaked from a public hospital. It suggested that all patients, except for pensioners, be classified as private patients in public hospitals, and that patients be billed at the discretion of orthopaedic surgeons. Dr Marr claimed that the leaked document revealed a scheme where surgeons could make hundreds of thousands of dollars a year from public hospital work.

When are we going to hear from the Opposition a position on doctors' overcharging; that minority of doctors who seek to exploit the system by overcharging, and that group of doctors who are the instigators of legal opinion that they want us to take seriously, but who are quite clearly attempting, in New South Wales and other places, to manoeuvre into a situation where they can charge the public purse and individual members of the public massively. It has to be understood that so far as this whole issue is concerned there has been so much persiflage in this place by members of the Opposition on the question of privacy and the question of public interest. It has to be understood also where the Minister for Community Services and Health and the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) were coming from. They are not trying to make a quid for themselves. What they are trying to do is to expose a minority practice of overcharging the Australian public, sometimes to the extent of sixfold.

We have heard from the Opposition repeated criticism in this place that somehow the Labor Party is losing touch with its base. I suggest that Opposition members have a chat to the base, which happens to be the general electorate of Australia, about how they would feel about being charged sixfold above the schedule fee. I suggest that Opposition members have a chat to the base about how they would feel about being ripped off in a public hospital in the manner that is suggested in what apparently is a leaked document picked up by the Doctors Reform Society of New South Wales. I suggest that Opposition members rock on down to the western suburbs of Sydney and have a chat to the people in that area who are trying to keep a family together on $15,000 and $16,000 a year, and suggest to them that a point of high principle is involved here-the opportunity to rip them off mercilessly. That is what the Opposition stands for here.

The Opposition should not think that over the next two years the Government is not going to take full advantage of the opportunity to get across to the general public that what we stand for is the protection of their interests against this sort of rubbish. I cannot believe that members of the Opposition would come into this place and again run the nonsense that they have been running for the past couple of weeks. What a position of a tactics committee. At the end of a great week in which the Labor Party was going to be fought on all fronts, when we could see the panzers rolling over the hills headed towards our firmly entrenched positions-we could see all that coming-what happened? The Opposition brings out a board and a game of Trivial Pursuit and says, `Here you are boys. The panzers have all been recalled. Have a set of dice and we are off with Trivial Pursuit'. That has been the Opposition's position all through this week. What a joke!

It has been a week also in which we have seen the Leader of the Opposition in this place, and on the doorstep of Parliament House raise himself up to his full height and puff out his great stance of principle. On Monday we heard him say, `The Liberal Party would never give an apparatchik a government position'. When we sit down and have a look at the record we find that apparatchiks are put straight into government positions so far as the Liberal Party is concerned when it is in office. That was one piece of misleading from the Leader of the Opposition. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition wandered out onto the steps of Parliament House and said, `Of course, never under me would we consider this jobs-for-the-boys type environment that the Australian Labor Party introduces'. When we go back to the record we find that in his later years as Treasurer he appointed two former Liberal Cabinet Ministers to the Reserve Bank of Australia Board, one of the most prominent bodies in our community. I do not quarrel with the two people he appointed to that Reserve Bank Board; they were distinguished Ministers and they served this country well. But what we on this side of the House will not tolerate is receiving moral lectures from people who are clearly in this place operating on a double standard.

Then we saw the Leader of the Opposition on a spit this morning after his great effort to embarrass the Prime Minister yesterday on his alleged efforts, in the Opposition's view, to fix a gambling game. Let us look at him backing and filling. He was asked:
Mr Howard, do you think that Mr Hawke is cleared of any impropriety in the matter?
He replied:
I think that people will have different views. Look as far as I, look, I don't know because I wasn't there and I don't have personal knowledge of the circumstances.
He went on:

Well, it's not a question of running strongly, it's a question of if you have material which can properly be raised in the public interest, it is raised, the Prime Minister gives a reply which appears to be at variance with some of what is contained in the material originally raised, people will be unsure as to the true circumstances.
That was the John Howard on the steps of Parliament. The well-prepared John Howard, the well prepared mud-slinger, yesterday in Parliament said:
It is not surprising that the Prime Minister, this great sportsman, should want to increase his odds, particularly at present.
He went on:
Perhaps the answer to this will be that it is of no great account that the rules of the game have been bent at the Prime Minister's request.

That was John Howard totally certain yesterday in Parliament. That is the lesson as to why a Leader of the Opposition should not be used to sling mud because leaders of opposition always muck it up. One can guarantee that mud sticks to those who fling it. That will be the epitaph of John Howard's period as Leader of the Opposition when Liberal members finally get around to doing something about him some time before the next election.

Before the next election Opposition members will also have to confront, since they seek to censure us on the handling of government, the document that was prepared by the Opposition's finance spokesman Senator Stone to advise John Howard as Treasurer if Howard had been returned to government back in 1983. Let me read selections from this document, and I shall do so quite frequently in this House over the next couple of years because it is a wonderful indictment of a would-be alternative government. Senator Stone said this about the $9.6 billion:

The magnitude of the fiscal imbalance is unprecedented in Australia during peace time, as is the level of Government spending. Secondly, the speed of deterioration is remarkable. The underlying fiscal situation is projected to deteriorate from near balance to more than 5 per cent of GDP in an eighteen month period, beginning, for the most part, from November 1982 . . . Thirdly, there are the ongoing implications of the spending increases. The sharp expenditure increases are coming on top of a series of years of continuing record levels of government spending and in the wake of an increasingly serious budget `lock-in' problem.

This is the collection of geniuses who wish to lecture us on whether we can form a government. We have been struggling for the last five years to deal with the product of that incompetence. The reason that we occasionally have to do things that are found offensive by some Labor voters is that we have to struggle with those matters or the country will go down the tube. That is what Ministers confront daily. It would have been nice to hear from the Opposition in the five years we have been in government, as a form of mea culpa, a sensible policy suggestion, a real alternative presented to us so that we could give it some form of consideration. We have got none of it. What we get is mud-slinging from the highest level of the Opposition benches. It is failed mud-slinging based on a complete misunderstanding on its part of the principal role of an Opposition and the principal way in which an Opposition should be conducted. Dr Blewett stands readily acquitted. The Opposition has introduced nothing, except an opinion by a group that stands for overcharging and ripping off the Australian patient. That is contemptible, it should be rejected, and it is rejected by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of those people who are listening to the broadcast today, I begin by outlining what the House is debating. Certainly one would get no idea from listening to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). This debate is about the abuse of position and power causing a decline in the standards of government under the Hawke Administration. We started this debate with a compelling contribution by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) against the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). If that Minister had any respect whatsoever for the Westminster tradition, he would be in this House this afternoon putting up some sort of response to the matters which we have raised today and which we will continue to raise. The one outstanding fact which was not addressed by the Minister for Defence was that what we have clearly and blatantly is a breach of the law of the Commonwealth. No sort of haranguing, no going back to 1983, will get this Government away from that fact-an allegation of a breach of Commonwealth law.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that on ministerial propriety for this Government the only question that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) asks himself-whether it is a jobs for the boys situation or an issue about cheating at the Perth casino-is `Can I get away with it?'. No principle stands in the way of the Prime Minister in considering these issues. If an official report says that the Prime Minister has asked to bend the rules, the Government gets some bunny to stand up and deny it. If it is Mum's shares in the Bell group, the Government changes the rules-it is all very easy. If it is one's family home in Sydney that is a problem when one lives in Canberra, the Government changes the travel allowance rules. If it is a breach of the law, as we have before us today, the Government toughs it out and hopes that it will go away. The Government drags the Solicitor-General out of bed at 11.30 at night and flourishes his advice as evidence that the Minister is not guilty.

My contribution to this debate is about the legal issues. As I said in opening, it is the legal issues which, in the end, will bring this Minister down. The Opposition is not attacking the Solicitor-General in any way. He was asked to give an opinion and, as would a solicitor in private practice in respect of any client, he simply provided that opinion as requested. Our criticism of this Government is the way it briefed the Solicitor-General. If one asks a question in the right sort of way, one will get the answer one is looking for. We asked Senator Tate how it was that the Government briefed the Solicitor-General. We had a revealing-in fact honest-answer from Senator Tate, compared with the evasive answer from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) at Question Time at the same time. It was after 11 p.m. and Senator Tate concluded his description of this late night phone call rush to find Dr Griffith with, `We need an opinion for the morning to clear Dr Blewett'. In the end Senator Tate said:
No written request by me or brief in that sense was provided to the Solicitor-General.

All the Solicitor-General got was what Dr Blewett said in the House that night. He got a minute from the Department and, I suppose, he was lucky to get a copy of the Act on which he was asked to advise. The next morning the Government was out pronouncing Dr Blewett innocent. What a contrast that makes to the statement today when the Prime Minister was asked, `Will you give that opinion which we have from Mr Ellicott, QC, to the Director of Public Prosecutions?' His answer was, `Oh no, we do not want to debate legal opinions in here'. Yet two weeks ago he was in here saying, `Dr Blewett is innocent, off scot-free-nothing to worry about'. Again, the Minister of Defence has said that it is a dead issue. The only thing that will be dead on this issue is the dead political body of Dr Blewett. The Government got the headlines it wanted. I quote the Age: `Blewett in clear, says chief lawyer'. That was made to measure-thank you, Dr Griffith, it was a job well done. What next transpires? Ah, they are off asking the police to go and collect the facts. That is interesting timing-they get the legal opinion, but they get the facts after they have that legal opinion. There was no explanation from the Minister for Defence on that matter.

We have approached this issue with a very simple, straightforward proposition. On the facts as they have come out into the public arena in the few weeks since this matter became public, and given a legal opinion I will talk more about in a moment which raises certain matters of a legal nature in regard to the Minister for Community Services and Health, our simple proposition is this: there is a clear prima facie case against the Minister that he has broken the law of the land. On that basis, and on the basis of most minimum ministerial standards, this Minister ought to stand aside. If he will not stand aside, the Prime Minister ought to exhibit some sort of leadership, step in and have him stand aside. Unless that action is taken there is no ministerial standard, there is no leadership from the Government whatsoever.

We base our opinion not just on the views we have formed ourselves as a matter of commonsense but on the basis of views put to us in a legal opinion-a very carefully considered opinion produced with the benefit of the facts in the public arena by Mr Ellicott, QC. Mr Ellicott is a former Solicitor-General and a former Attorney-General, a first law officer of the land, and a person with experience in dealing with and assessing the opinions of others, including the opinions of the Solicitor-General of the day. He is also a former Federal Court judge. In layman's terms, this man has been there, done that. He has come up with a conclusive opinion as to how this matter ought to be looked at from a legal point of view. The reality is that the Government is so worried about this matter that it does not even want the Director of Public Prosecutions to see the opinion. It has put up the shutters left, right and centre, absolutely, because that is the bottom line.

I turn briefly to the legal opinion. Anybody who knows anything about the law will note when he reads it that it follows a logical sequence. It sets out the facts that have been made available-I inform the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) that there is no question about that-and it then goes through them in a logical sequence. The first point made in the opinion is that the Minister is an officer and bound by the confidentiality provisions of section 130 of the Health Insurance Act. The second point in the sequence of advice is that the provision of any information with respect to the affairs of another person is an offence. That is a very clear statement. In fact, to quote from the opinion:

. . . even if the Minister only authorised communication to Mr Gear of information which did not contain provider numbers, it is our opinion that this constituted a breach of s.130 (1) of the Health Insurance Act. Section 130 (1) prohibits the communication of any information `with respect to the affairs of another person'. The words `with respect to' and `affairs' have a very wide connotation.
The Government is not going to get past even that hurdle. The third point made is that, even if the provider numbers were provided-and we have that admission from the Minister-the opinion says:
. . . it must be clear beyond argument that the inclusion of the provider numbers constituted a contravention of the legislation.

The fourth point relates to an offence of absolute liability. Mr Ellicott's opinion states that keeping information confidential is so important that there can be no excuse and therefore the interpretation is that it is an offence of absolute liability. The opinion goes on; it is very conclusive. Let me finish with the remarks of the Minister for Community Services and Health, who said in the Age of 25 February:
I think I have the same confidence as Mick Young that the kind of charges, the quite outlandish charges, that were being made against me had no basis in fact.

If he puts himself in the company of Mick Young, all I say to him is that he will soon be with Mr Young out there in the employment agency, ringing the Prime Minister to see whether he can fix up a job for one of his mates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again this afternoon we have witnessed an absolute load of drivel and an attempt to protect absolutely a small group of unscrupulous doctors who have been endeavouring to rip off the system for a long time. We have seen feigned indignation from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith); we have seen an attempted reasoned case from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt)-neither of which stacks up in fact. Those honourable members are quite prepared to turn their backs, as is the rest of the Opposition, on the problem that exists in some sections of society today. I refer to attempts by an unscrupulous group of doctors to rip off the poor, those people who cannot afford to pay the fees the doctors would like them to pay. I will demonstrate later on in my contribution the sorts of antics we have seen mirrored in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the statements made so far in this debate have been absolutely contemptible. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), said much the same thing in his concluding remarks. I do disagree, though, with one thing he said. I know that the Opposition does have one policy, and it is in the health area. I am sorry to tell the Minister this, but it does. That policy is to smash Medicare, to take it away from all the poor unfortunates-the pensioners, the low income earners, the $15,000 a year earners in the western suburbs of Sydney, and those in the Illawarra who fit into those categories. They are the sorts of people that some members on the other side would throw on the scrap heap once again. I hark back to the situation before this Government came into office. How many people were not then covered by any form of medical insurance? There were two million of them. I remind honourable members that that figure has now changed.

The Opposition spokesman on health and other matters has come in here and said, `Dr Blewett had done wrong. He has provided information which suggests that there are doctors ripping off the system'. Why does he not put the same amount of investigative journalism into coming up with the facts surrounding what the doctors in New South Wales, the orthopaedic surgeons, have tried to do? The Minister referred to that. Let me just give the House one little story to illustrate that point. Last week I was at a meeting of a pensioner group in Wollongong, in my electorate. That was a group of 300 very good people who believe that this Government is doing the right thing by them. One of them came up to me and said, `I need some advice, Mr Martin, can you give me that advice? I have a very bad problem with my feet and I have been to my orthopaedic specialist'. I asked when she first went to her doctor, and she said it was two years ago. I said, `But you are shuffling around. Why hasn't it been fixed?' She said, `Because the orthopaedic specialist said, ``Get private health cover and then I will fix you up'' '. So this poor woman, this pensioner, is expected to shuffle around for the rest of her life because on principle she says that she is a pensioner who is paying under Medicare, why will the doctor not go back into the public system and fix her up?

I will tell the House why: it is because the orthopaedics and a number of their mates-the Opposition talks about mates!-have stitched up a deal with Nick in New South Wales. They have stitched up a deal with Nick Greiner and his hidden agenda that has been mouthed off by our good mate Mr Collins, the Opposition spokesman on health in New South Wales, and they have come up with this deal to smash Medicare. The Minister referred to a particular leaked document. I would like to put that matter on the record once again. This leaked document from the New South Wales public hospitals has revealed a list of the doctors' demands. They do not even have the courtesy to say they will negotiate; they say they have a list of demands that will get them back into the public hospital system. The first demand, of course, is that we get rid of Medicare. They are saying, `Goodbye Medicare; all you battling pensioners need not worry, all of you low income earners from Sydney's western suburbs, from the Illawarra and from the Hunter have no need to worry because we will take care of you all right'. But they will have to pay six times what it costs now to have an operation, if they can get in, and if the orthopods are prepared to go into the public health system.

What about people in the Hunter? We heard in Question Time today about the eye specialists there. Under Medicare, they are getting $500 to $600 for an operation-not bad for an hour's work, I would have thought. But that is not good enough for some of these people in the Hunter; they say they want a little more. Multiply it by six and that will tell honourable members how much more they want. It is absolutely outrageous. Yet the two Opposition speakers on this matter of public importance so far today have the gall to come in here and say, `We will stick up for them, that is all right'. They are also sticking up for their little mate Nick, who is clawing desperately to get up that greasy pole of success and take over the running of the State of New South Wales. He is running on this absolute nonsense, on the sleazy deal outlined in this particular leaked document that has been stitched up with the orthopods in New South Wales. He will take care of his mates when it is all over. They have the unmitigated gall to lecture this Government about propriety. They say, `Deals for mates'. They keep talking about Mick Young and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). What absolute garbage! There has been talk about standards of government. The honourable member for Flinders referred to the text of the proposal for the matter of public importance, which reads:
The abuse of position and power causing a decline in the standards of Government under the Hawke administration.

The honourable member should talk to all of those people who have benefited from five years of stable government under the Hawke Government, such as those people in the western suburbs. He should tell them about the increased opportunities for housing loans. He should tell them about the increased opportunities for health care cover. He should tell them about how the unemployment rate is being lowered. He should tell them about the child care facilities that have been provided. But he says, `The Hawke Government is pretty hopeless-there's no administration'. What absolute garbage!

On top of that, the honourable member for Flinders said, `Mind you, with respect to Dr Blewett and the opinion of the Solicitor-General, we're not attacking him. He was not given enough information, but we're not attacking him'. Like hell they are not! Members of the Opposition want an umpire sitting in the box next to them in the grandstand. They see the game going on below and say, `Hang on, we'll have the umpire here so that we can whisper in his ear, ``Mate, this is what the decision has to be on that particular play'' '. They say, `Dr Griffith doesn't have all the information, he hasn't got it right, but we have. We have the Acts and we have Ellicott'. The honourable member for Flinders ran past us the tremendous credentials that this bloke has, but he left one out. I think he said that he was an Attorney-General, but he did not say what party he was from. What party was it? It was the Liberal Party-fair dinkum.

My mind was immediately taken back to the last few hours of the good old days of the Whitlam Administration. There was some thought at the time that the Governor-General was receiving some advice as to what he should do. Once again a fairly senior legal person was involved. Some people said that it was a gentleman by the name of Barwick and that he had some connections with a party. I do not think that that was a reference to a 1970s party; I think it was actually a reference to the Liberal Party! So now we have these guys saying, `Ellicott's got all the credentials. He is a member of the Liberal Party. He has produced an opinion which contradicts what Dr Griffith said, so it is right'. Members of the Opposition are unbelievable. They sit back and let the poor little old lady in my electorate shuffle around because she cannot afford private health care so that she can get her feet operated on. That is a story that, I am sad to say, is in existence in a number of parts of Australia because of a small group of doctors who are unwilling and unprepared to get back into the hospital service.

My electorate secretary is a member of the Area Health Service Board in the Illawarra region. He tells me appalling tales about the orthopaedic specialists. My friend the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) has told me about the eye specialists in his electorate and why they will not go back into the public health system. Old Nick in New South Wales and his mate Colin have said, `Surgeons, charge what you like. Scrap Medicare and charge what you like. We will get rid of all that. Beds will be there. We will build you a couple of extra hospitals'. One forgets who owns the private hospitals. Who has shares in the private hospitals? It is not the pensioners and the $15,000-a-year earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —The doctors--

—Well, I would not go quite that far. Certainly, many of the specialists are not prepared to do what the Government has paid them to do. Who foots the bill for their training? The Government and the taxpayers of Australia foot the bill for their training. There are no university fees; the Government pays for the lot. We are the people who are paying for it, and it is no good.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday next at 2 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (MAINTENANCE INCOME TEST) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is complementary to the Child Support Act 1988 and together they constitute the major elements of the Government's child support scheme. Many Australian families over the last 10 years have experienced the pain of marriage breakdown. That is something governments can do little to help-but government can take action to alleviate dramatic and sustained drops in living standards for children in those families. For too long poverty has been the traumatic result of marriage breakdown for children in sole-parent families. This Government is committed to ensuring that by 1990 no child need live in poverty. The child support scheme is a central part of our program to achieve that objective.

The centrepiece of the child support scheme is the Child Support Act, which will ensure that parents who have the capacity to pay do not abandon the financial responsibility of supporting their children to the social security system. The Child Support Act establishes an agency which will ensure that maintenance is efficiently collected from those liable to pay it and that maintenance is distributed to the families entitled to receive it. The Family Law Amendment Act, which passed through both Houses late in 1987, encourages more substantial awards of maintenance than had been customary previously. This scheme overall will increase the number of families receiving maintenance, increase the level of that maintenance and ensure that it is received on a regular basis. This Bill will amend the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to provide for changes in the way maintenance income is treated in the social security and veterans' benefits systems.

I turn now to outline the features of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill. The Bill will bring into account a wide range of maintenance income received by social security and veteran pensioners and beneficiaries. The most straightforward of these is cash maintenance paid on a regular basis. At present this is taken into account as income for only some pensions and benefits. In addition, the Bill will provide for the assessment of in-kind maintenance income. Maintenance in kind may take many forms. For example, it may be food provided, household items supplied, payments of medical benefits insurance, the provision of housing or payment of rent, payments of household accounts or educational or child care expenses. It could come in the form of payment of motor vehicle registration and running costs. Another type of maintenance payment which has not traditionally been assessed by the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs as income is the transfer of a substantial lump sum of capital, perhaps in the context of distribution of property following a divorce. The Bill will include such capital transfers as maintenance income in so far as they are completed for the purposes of providing maintenance to the pensioner or beneficiary, or his or her dependent children. The Bill will provide in most cases for the assessment of capital maintenance amounts by their imputation over a number of years. This imputed income will be taken to be received fortnightly.

The Bill seeks to encourage sole parents in receipt of maintenance income to increase total income by seeking other forms of income, especially income from remunerative employment. This will arise through two income test free areas in the Act. One affects maintenance income and the other applies to all other types of income. The advantage which flows from the receipt of both general and maintenance income is a total income test free area considerably more generous than where only one type of income is received. It is expected that additional non-maintenance income will generally be in the form of casual or part-time earnings.

The cornerstone of the scheme is to ensure as far as possible that, where maintenance is payable to a pensioner or beneficiary, it is in fact paid. This will shift some of the burden for the maintenance of Australian children and their parents from the social security and veterans' benefits systems to those who are liable to pay maintenance. The Bill will further advance this intention by emphasising the requirement that sole parents, in order to qualify for pension, must take reasonable action to obtain available maintenance. Similar provisions have existed for a long time in the Social Security Act.

This Bill will rationalise the requirement and will be supported by departmental guidelines which will balance the public interest in encouraging maintenance action with the factors in particular cases which might render the wisdom of such action questionable. I assure the House that action will not be required where there are genuine fears of violence to the custodian or children or where there may be a threat to the security of the custodian or her children.

There are in the Bill special rules which apply to certain types of in-kind and cash maintenance income so as to reduce their effect on the resulting rate of pension, benefit or allowance. The first of these is all in-kind maintenance income provided by the pensioner's, beneficiary's, or allowee's spouse, or ex-spouse in the first six months following separation. The purpose of reducing the impact of such maintenance income is to facilitate the adaptation by the pensioner, beneficiary or allowee to his or her new situation. The second is maintenance in cash and in kind provided in respect of expenses arising directly from any of various disabilities of a dependent child of the person in receipt of pension or other social welfare benefit. This rule will assist in limiting the adverse effect that the receipt of such necessary maintenance might otherwise have on the rate of pension, benefit or allowance.

The final special maintenance category will be in-kind housing maintenance in respect of the home which is the actual residence of the pensioner, beneficiary or allowee. This reflects the importance of secure housing for the children and the difficulties that separated couples often face in providing adequate housing for their children.

In recognition of the disruption that could be caused to some existing pensioners and beneficiaries as a result of these reforms, the Bill will provide transitional provisions for the preservation of the total income of a pensioner or other beneficiary so that maintenance income would not apply to reduce total income. The provisions will benefit the person until he or she no longer needs them because total income has risen above that which applied at the date of commencement of the maintenance income test.

The child support scheme involves major reforms to Australia's family law and social security systems. It will involve the Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security collecting and paying out child support. It will achieve more adequate income support for more custodial families in a way which closely links the levels of private and public income support. This Bill is a key element in that scheme. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr West, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Section 66 of the Constitution prescribes, subject to the Parliament otherwise providing, a maximum annual sum for the payment of salaries of Ministers. Amendments to the Ministers of State Act which sets this sum are from time to time thus required to cover changes to ministerial salaries. The Remuneration Tribunal in its 1987 review recommended that ministerial salaries be increased by 3.8 per cent with effect from 1 July 1987 as the first step towards resolution of the agreed anomaly which the Tribunal found has existed since 1984. The Tribunal has also recommended that parliamentary salaries be increased by a further 2.2 per cent from 1 July 1988. The anomaly arose as a result of the Government's consistent demonstration of wage restraint. The percentage increases awarded to Ministers are the same as those awarded by the Tribunal to parliamentary office holders and other parliamentarians. In addition, the maximum number of Ministers of State has been increased from 27 to 30.

It is therefore necessary to raise the upper limit on the amount appropriated for ministerial salaries to accommodate the 3.8 per cent increase of 1 July 1987 and the expansion of the Ministry. The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Ministers of State Act to increase the maximum annual sum to $680,000 from $475,000. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE: OVERSEAS VISIT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —A comprehensive statement was presented to the House this afternoon by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), a statement that canvassed many important issues for Australia and our region, in particular, and other important issues such as disarmament and peace. Peace is probably the most important and complex issue in our time. The Foreign Minister also canvassed the Opposition's policies, or lack of them, throughout his statement. I was interested to hear the reply of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) earlier this afternoon. The first point I would like to take up is the South African question. The honourable member for North Sydney talked about the Sharpeville six and proposed hanging or execution of those people within the next 24 hours. He proceeded to place before the Parliament a document that he had received from the South African Embassy which, in his great legal mind, meant that they obviously should be executed.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think anyone in this chamber would decry a hearing of the honourable member for North Sydney or anyone else. But it starts to get a little galling when one continues to hear the same theme, when there is absolutely no balance in the comments or statements made about South Africa. I have never heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) or the honourable member for North Sydney say a bad thing about the South African Government. If there were any balanced statements one could say, `He might have something here today'. But, once again, out we come with a statement produced from the South African Embassy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are apologists.

—They are apologists for the South African Government, again having a go at the black South Africans. Apparently, we cannot bring in sanctions because that will hit the little people. What absolute nonsense. After a person has had his head kicked in every day, day in and day out, there does come a time, not only in South Africa, but also in other parts of the world on many human rights issues when he says, `Enough is enough. I really don't care what sanctions or people from outside do because I really cannot suffer much more than I am now'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get back to the honourable member for North Sydney and his incredible statement this afternoon. It is interesting that the Government received a cablegram today from Pretoria. It states:

An urgent application was brought today (16/3), before the Pretoria Supreme Court, seeking a stay of execution in the case of the Sharpeville six, scheduled to hang on Friday 18 March. The application was based on an eleventh hour admission by a key state witness that he had perjured himself at the behest of police.

The cablegram goes on for another page and a half stating the facts of the person who was at that hearing. Ironically-I find this incredible-that was before the trial judge. Notwithstanding the fact that the person said he had perjured himself, the trial judge thought that this raised an element of doubt that should at least be investigated, but it was thrown out. The appeal was not upheld and the execution will go ahead. So much for civil and human rights in South Africa. It is a disgrace. It is a disgrace that members of the Opposition continually, via the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, and the honourable member for North Sydney, come into this House and in one way or another continue to support the South African Government or find an excuse not to denigrate it on every conceivable issue that comes up regarding that Government. There must be a balance. If there were a balance we on this side of the House might take a little more notice of the things those opposite say. But there is an extraordinary imbalance in the comments that are made on South Africa. My colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said before that Opposition members are apologists for the South African Government.

The Foreign Minister raised a very important point. He said that it is becoming an increasingly complex world-dare I say a smaller world-with many issues that can touch us in an instant. No longer do we have to travel for weeks to get to a particular point; nowadays it takes virtually a few hours. Today nuclear weapons and even conventional weapons that are absolutely catastrophic can destroy other continents within a matter of hours. Subsequently, we do not have many peripheral matters in regard to foreign relations or defence concerns. Of course, one should try to keep to one's own region where it is more important. We have done that, albeit through a whole range of measures. The Foreign Minister again talked about the Pacific region and how we have upgraded our visits and the quality of our diplomatic representation to that region, just to mention a couple of points. He mentioned that he will, once again, be going on a comprehensive tour of the South Pacific this year.

It is interesting to note that we have the bleating again from the honourable member for North Sydney about Papua New Guinea (PNG). It may interest the House that since the election of the Hawke Government the honourable member for North Sydney, in an official capacity at least, has not been to PNG. Guess how many official visits the Opposition has made to PNG in the last five years? We have had three-one from the former member for Denison, Mr Hodgman, for two days and one by the Leader of the Opposition and the former spokesman for foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong, (Mr Peacock). They went together to represent the Opposition at the tenth anniversary of Papua New Guinea's independence. They were there for only two days in an official capacity at the celebrations. There was one other visit from Mr Hodgman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there last October.

—I refer to official visits from the Opposition front bench. In contrast, Mr Hayden has been there on five occasions. There have been 20 ministerial visits by this Government to the South Pacific, with the visit by the Foreign Minister, as I have mentioned, later this year. It is extraordinary that the honourable member for North Sydney comes in here and bleats about our relationship with PNG, which is as good as, and I would say much better than, it has ever been because of the continued communication between the two governments and members of parliament of the two countries in the last couple of years. That culminated with the signing of the declaration of principles in December last year between the two respective Prime Ministers. As I have said in this House before, for the first time defence was mentioned in that declaration which never occurred under the conservative Government. It is an interesting point that the honourable member for North Sydney can bleat about PNG and not go there, but he can whiz off to Yugoslavia and try to do a bit of grandstanding, albeit a complete failure, to try to score a few political points for the Opposition as he did a few months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: On disarmament and arms control, peace is probably the most important issue we have before us today. I was fortunate enough to chair the subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on disarmament and arms control. The report was very comprehensive and well received. It is interesting that the Foreign Minister again raises the question in his statement today. He stated:

Australia will, for example, continue to work actively for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, an agreement to eliminate chemical weapons, an agreement to prevent an arms race in space and to control and reduce the use of conventional weapons.

They are all matters, but for a few, arising from the recommendations that came from the subcommittee that I chaired. They have been pursued by this Government ever since its election in 1983. All we have heard is bleating from the Opposition about how we are trying to go soft on the Soviet Union. We have heard from the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), as to how we should look at obtaining nuclear weapons for ourselves. There has been no positive output from the people responsible regarding Australia's participation in the many forums in the United Nations, such as the participation in the United Nations Conference on Disarmament in Geneva by Australia's Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr Butler, on these important issues over the last three or four years. It has been comprehensive. We now have many countries asking Australia to keep up the good work because the comprehensive and detailed work we are doing, even though it is long and laborious-it is a long and slow process-is working. The drip theory is working. We are now seeing the two superpowers getting together and reducing their nuclear weapons and their throw weight. Again, that is another recommendation of my subcommittee's report. The interesting thing is that we are starting to see some action in this very important area. As the Foreign Minister has pointed out today, there is still much to be done. A lot of work can be done by us. We can be putting our viewpoint forcefully in the various conferences and forums around the world. Countries such as Sweden, Norway and others have combined with Australia to put a forceful viewpoint on behalf of the peaceful people in the world.

It is also interesting to note that Opposition members talk about the alliance and comments made lately by a few very important people in the United States. It is worth reiterating a couple of quotes given by the Minister this afternoon. One was from Admiral Hayes, the Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific-in fact, his area of responsibility stretches from the Pacific right across to the African coast. Admiral Hayes said recently, and it is worth repeating:
Security co-operation between the United States and Australia has never been better. It is heartening to see the extent of mutual benefits that accrue from the alliance relationship.

The Secretary of State, Mr Shultz, pointed out that the relationship with the United States is `as strong and vigorous as ever, if not more so'. So on all sides we have a more vigorous debate and a more vigorous relationship because this country, under the stewardship of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Foreign Minister and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), is continuing to put its view. If we do not agree with a viewpoint put forward by our allies we will say so. It is no good kowtowing to the viewpoints of our allies merely to forsake them in their operations. It will not work. It has never worked before. We have shown that with a more forceful relationship, putting our viewpoint forward, there is a much stronger relationship between us.

I congratulate the Foreign Minister on the many issues he has raised. It is important that Australia has enhanced its alliance and its relationship with our neighbours in the Pacific and Asian area. Our trade has increased in Asia quite dramatically. I congratulate the Minister on the work he has done through the Government on the peace and disarmament issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement we heard today from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) comes after his first visit to the Middle East since he assumed his dual responsibilities for foreign affairs and trade. There are many in this Parliament who are watching with a great deal of interest to see how those dual responsibilities interact and the impact of this new arrangement on the effectiveness of each of these areas of critical importance to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: That it is a demanding responsibility to add such an important portfolio as overseas trade to the Minister's existing foreign affairs responsibilities is absolutely indisputable. The recent media publicity as to the tensions within the Minister's Department in the absorption and integration of these two portfolios is obviously a matter of great disquiet. In any such administrative change, the primary objective must be to not lose sight of our national goals and their effective achievement. If administrative difficulties interfere in any way with those objectives I would assume that the Government would be alert and willing to review those arrangements as a matter of priority.

Unfortunately, actions may already have occurred which have taken the administration of our foreign affairs in a direction from which it might be impossible to retrieve the diplomatic skills developed over so many years. There is some evidence that we are in the process of diluting those skills into a broad public service morass of generalist administration. If that is so, we are witnessing the death of the professional foreign affairs officer and his replacement by a generalist public servant. That, of course, will reflect very quickly in the standards and achievements of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. This is a very high price to pay for the experimentation by Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with the Australian Public Service. I make these comments because of the stories we hear and because of the emphasis we have seen on trade matters in the Minister's statement today, which cause me some concern.

With this in mind, I now want to address myself to the Middle East. There can be no denying that the Middle East is assuming considerable importance for Australia on the trade front. In recent times we have seen a broadening of our previous narrow trade base, away from commodities and towards more sophisticated commercial ties. The potential is great, and it is important that Australia's Trade Minister have first-hand knowledge of the area and its senior representatives. I have no argument with that. The Minister's visit came at a time of unprecedented difficulties for Israel in the occupied territories on the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. I am disappointed to see how little of the Minister's statement has been devoted to this matter of vital importance to the Middle East and to Australia. Here we have civilian unrest in the occupied territories of a magnitude and nature as to cause serious embarrassment to the Israeli Government and to strain its relationship with the world community in a way we have not seen before.

Yet in reporting to Parliament about the Middle East, what do we hear from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade? The very first words by the Minister tell us that the Middle East is an area of primary trading importance to Australia, with two-way trade of almost $3 billion last financial year. This is dwelt on for paragraph after paragraph and concludes with a comment that the continuation of the Iran-Iraq war threatens our important trading links with both countries. There is no mention of Australia's critical interest in having stability and peace in the Gulf, or the role we might play in helping to bring this horrendous and needless war to an end-none at all. Rather, what we have from our Foreign Minister is a talking down of our possible role. He talks of obligations and interests in the events of the region as though it is something far removed from our sphere of involvement and beyond our ability to assist in any effective way.

I remind the Minister and the people of Australia that it was the Hawke Government which cut back and restricted the role of Australia's peacekeeping force in the Sinai. That decision did not endear us to the many countries so vitally seeking a peaceful solution to the Middle East problem, and must cause many of them to believe that, if Australia has, as the Minister claims, only a marginal role to play in that region, it does so by choice. Surprisingly, while the Minister sees the Iran-Iraq war as being very limited, the conflict between Israel and the Arab nations is not treated with the same casualness. There the Minister tells us that the conflict is especially significant to Australia, but he then goes on to admit that in his discussions with Middle East leaders he made it clear that Australia was only a marginal participant in these events. If it is of such significance to us, then Australia must be more than a marginal participant. It should be in there seeking to assist in achieving solutions to problems that have, or seem to have, the potential to seriously disrupt the economic well-being not only of the Middle Eastern countries but also of our nation.

I would have expected Australia's Foreign Minister to take the opportunity offered by his visits to reinforce Australia's thinking and concern on the matter of the occupied territories and the self-determination of the Palestinians, and to seek detailed discussions on what the future holds. The Minister's speech, in this respect, was meagre in the extreme, and I am left to wonder, as we all are, at the extent to which the Minister did concern himself with these important issues during his visit, or whether there might be some substance to our fears that Australia's foreign policies and objectives are being relegated to a secondary place below those of exploring for increased trade opportunities.

I recall that Australia's Prime Minister visited some countries in the Middle East during a visit in January and February of 1987 and that in his subsequent ministerial statement to this House on 19 February 1987 he identified Australia's basic policy attitude to the Arab-Israeli dispute and informed us in some detail of the thorough, detailed and friendly discussions he had on those principles. There is no such detail from the Foreign Minister in his statement today. What have we been told about any movement towards a lasting settlement to the Middle East dispute, to our commitment to the security of Israel, to the importance of the Palestinian issue, their right to self-determination, and the dangers for those objectives in the current events in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank? We have been told nothing, except a brief reference to his having expressed Australia's concern about the continuing violence in the occupied territories.

The Prime Minister told us over 12 months ago that Australia did not see itself seeking a mediating or other direct role in settling the Middle East dispute but that Australia was firmly committed and willing, if requested, to do all it could to bring peace to that region. Did the Foreign Minister reiterate that willingness? If he did, what response did he receive? How strongly did he express Australia's concern at the undeniable evidence of excessive force and brutality being used by the Israeli Army in putting down the stonethrowing by Palestinians in the occupied areas; or, as I have already noted, did he merely express Australia's concern?

The Middle East is a region of critical importance to Australia when one considers its significant oil resources, its straddling of important shipping routes, its potential to destabilise the northern Indian Ocean region, and the large number of immigrants in this country from countries in that area. I see nothing in the Minister's statement today to reassure me that this Government has a real appreciation of that significance. The Minister's somewhat feeble expressions of concern about the occupied territories and his perception of Australia having merely a marginal role in events in the region are totally inadequate and inappropriate. If this is what our foreign affairs have come to, I suggest that Foreign Affairs is a ship already ponderously slow in international waters and is in no shape to take on the added tonnage of Australia's overseas trade responsibilities.

Having said that, I turn to the African section of the safari. Africa, particularly southern Africa, is unquestionably of great importance to Australia, and I reject completely the Minister's suggestion that the Opposition considers the events in that region to be irrelevant. Frankly, I am disappointed that Australia's Foreign Minister has used such cheap political point scoring in an important ministerial document which purports to report to this Parliament on a four-week visit to 13 countries in regions of great global interest to Australia. That he is bereft of worthwhile comment on what he achieved in real terms is indicated by the fact that his 20-page speech devotes almost five pages to an attack on the Opposition's foreign policies. That is hardly the action of a Minister who, one imagines, should have been able to present 20 pages of detail as to the discussions he held overseas, our objectives in those discussions and the successes he had in offering an Australian contribution to the resolution of international conflict and disagreement in the countries he visited.

South Africa is a particularly pertinent example. The Minister castigates us for what he claims is a failure to do anything to alter the South African Government's appalling attitude to apartheid. I reiterate and underline my disgust with the attitude, the example and the actions of the South African Government, particularly in its continuing efforts to subjugate the black peoples there.

But what does the Minister offer? He tells us of $100m in aid to several countries of southern Africa, but he makes no mention of the necessity of making such a pledge before one of those countries would agree to a visit by an Australian Foreign Minister. He had to put the $100m up front before one particular country would even consider a visit by an Australian Minister.

He also tells us that he attended a meeting in Lusaka to widen and tighten Commonwealth sanctions against South Africa. There are many on this side of the House, and I suspect that there are some on his own benches, who have a firm conviction that sanctions will add to the problems of South Africa and even contribute, in the longer term, to the very breakdown in law and justice that so many predict. It is quite wrong, as some on the Government side would suggest, to say that to argue against sanctions is a way of supporting apartheid. There is a legitimate discussion as to the best means of eliminating apartheid, and the question of sanctions is one of those areas of argument. People forget that South Africa, like the rest of Africa, is a country with an exploding population, and the particular focus of that explosion is the black population.

Those people, particularly those black people, will need jobs, goods and services on an increasing scale, and if economic sanctions have the effect of stopping or slowing that flow it will be the black men and women who will increasingly feel the hardship. They will need education, technical training and management expertise if they are to survive in the modern world. If economic sanctions have the effect of blowing those things out of the water, who will suffer? The majority of the people of southern Africa will suffer, and of course the majority of the people of southern Africa are black people.

Furthermore, sanctions are the very action that will give the white South Africans the conviction to dig in and defend their principles. They feel threatened in the face of sanctions, and there is already strong evidence in South Africa that the international attack on the beliefs of white South Africans has caused a disturbing move to the right in local elections. And who would want that? There are radical elements within the Right, and I genuinely fear that the wider and tighter the sanctions imposed by such misplaced policies as those of the Australian Government, the greater will be the resistance from a threatened and frightened white minority in South Africa. As their actions become more and more menacing, the black man will be encouraged to defend his few remaining rights and possessions with increasing ferocity. Such a situation lends itself to confrontation and revolution, and, regrettably, the very circumstances where the ultimate collapse of the radical Right leaves wide open the opportunity for equally radical attitudes of the Left. What better evidence is needed that events are spiralling into this vortex of tragedy than the South African Government's recent decision to ban a number of black non-political organisations and its callous and inhumane decision to make an example of six black people by hanging them for being somewhere nearby when a black mayor was shot dead some four years ago?

Desperate people take desperate decisions, and our Foreign Minister would have impressed many of us far more if his statement had properly addressed the problem of worthwhile and workable solutions for South Africa rather than his lampooning of the Opposition and his ill-considered clinging to internationally discredited action through economic sanctions. I would have been more impressed if we had had some discussion about events in the Indian Ocean, which is an area of enormous and increasing concern to Australia. But what did we have in his statement about that? We had very little indeed about recent events in the Indian Ocean-just a marginal reference here or there. It simply is not good enough. It is something he should turn his mind to and it is obviously something that this Parliament should have an opportunity to debate.

In conclusion, I believed and hoped that the Foreign Minister would use this opportunity to tell the people of Australia and this Parliament something of Australia's foreign policy needs in the areas he visited and to discuss some of the fundamental aims of the Hawke Government in its relationships with these countries. That this has not occurred will add further to the very real concern felt by many people about the direction in which the Hawke Government is taking this country, about the denigration and downgrading of the Department of Foreign Affairs, and about the escalation in the lack of expertise and the administrative turmoil which is becoming characteristic of that Department. Foreign affairs and trade are two very important areas. The Minister with those two important responsibilities has done nothing in this statement to dispel the fears and the doubts that many people have that the amalgamation will do nothing to assist in either of those areas of responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow my colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) in this debate. Much of what he said in his intervention I found to be a genuine contribution to a reasonable dialogue on foreign policy within this Parliament. Unfortunately, a good deal of what he had to say was not; but I felt that he had to make those ritual statements to support the rather unsupportable positions that the Opposition has got itself into. Its lack of positions came through clearly in the remarks made earlier by the Opposition's official foreign affairs spokesman. Nonetheless, I thought that what the honourable member for Warringah had to say was sufficiently to the point that it is a pity that he is not on the front bench speaking for the Opposition on these matters rather than somebody so bereft of ideas as the official spokesman.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) on the statement that he put down and on the visit to which his statement mainly refers. I begin by mentioning the countries he visited and the leaders with whom he had discussions on this most recent visit, simply to indicate the breadth of the concerns with which he dealt. The countries that he went to are not the watering holes of western Europe or North America. They are countries which many Australians would never visit as a matter of wish; they are not tourist capitals. They are: Mauritius, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Kenya, the Yemen Arab Republic, Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Israel, the Maldives, Singapore and Indonesia. I might say that these places are, more or less, casino-free. They are certainly not the kinds of places that a person who is not a hardworking, conscientious Foreign Minister would go to. Many discussions that the Foreign Minister referred to in his remarks were thankless. They involved vital interests for Australia, just as vital, say, as the interests in Kampuchea which the Foreign Minister has been so assiduous in pursuing, but they are not something for which he is likely to get congratulations or plaudits. They were necessary jobs, and I congratulate the Minister for having done them.

I congratulate the Minister also for the emphasis he placed on Australia's trade interests. These are exceedingly important interests. In saying so, I want to rebut what the honourable member for Warringah said about the amalgamation of the Foreign Affairs and Trade departments. It seems to me absolutely crucial these days, when easily the most significant problem facing Australia is the difficulties of our current account, that one must amalgamate one's resources of diplomacy and trade promotion in such a way as to maximise the return from both of them. If anything was liable to tempt me to return to my previous profession as a diplomat, it would be that this amalgamation has now taken place and that undeniably the biggest game in town is being played by that amalgamated department and, in my opinion, being played very well indeed.

I want to comment on several issues, but the most important is the one to which the honourable member for Warringah devoted a good deal of his time, namely, the Middle East. Recent events in Gaza and on the West Bank have brought that matter into very sharp focus. A number of international efforts have been directed at attempting to obtain a solution to those seemingly intractable, intransigent problems that exist there. Mr Shamir, the Prime Minister of Israel, is presently in the United States in close discussions with Mr Shultz and members of the United States Administration. A great deal is focused on the potential for harm and damage to the interests of Israel by the tactics of some untrained and ill-disciplined Israeli troops in suppressing the riots in Gaza and on the West Bank. What is not focused on too much is the potential of those events to spark a genuine dialogue directed at a genuine settlement. The United States Administration is to be congratulated for the way in which it has exerted itself into this process, much as it did at an earlier time with the Camp David process, in an attempt to suggest a solution.

Tragically, one main barrier to that solution is the paralysis-which is the best term one could use for it-and intransigence of the present Israeli Government towards the prospect of advancing a settlement. This country has been a firm friend of Israel from the time of the creation of that state, and, indeed, before that. Australia played an important role in the creation of Israel. I share that friendship with Israel and it will take a great deal to shake me from it.
