What will shake moderate and reasonable opinion in this country, what has already shaken moderate and reasonable opinion in this country, is the perception that the ingenuity of Israel, the genius of Israel, the capacity for inventiveness of its people, is being directed nowadays not so much towards looking at the possibilities for a solution but to emphasising the difficulties in the way of finding such a solution. It seems to me to be a great tragedy that these extraordinary people, many of whom have made a life in this country, should now be squandering the goodwill they have built up by the intransigence not of themselves but of a government which simply does not seem to be responding to the wishes of a very great number of people in Israel.

I was encouraged recently to read an article by the former Israeli Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, which argued extremely powerfully that Israel, if only for its own sake, had to begin a process of negotiation for withdrawal from the occupied territories. I want to read from that article, which appeared originally in the Observer. Abba Eban said:

Israel, after 40 years of independent nationhood, can justly present itself to the world as an unusual celebration of resilience and vitality but it enters its fifth decade in deep reflection about its own structure and values. Recently Israel's leading academic figures, including those who have never before uttered a controversial political word, joined together in their hundreds to urge an early end to the occupation regime. Nothing like this has ever happened in our-
that is, Israel's-
intellectual community before.
He goes on:
In the area in which its legal system applies, Israel is an exemplary democracy.
I interpolate that that is one of the reasons for the friendship that has always existed between Israel and the democratic countries of the West. He goes on:

But in Gaza the right to vote, to be elected, to express grievance and protest, to have recourse to serious legal process, to be protected from punishment without trial or proof of guilt, to hold a passport, to revere a flag, to enjoy social benefits, to have a decent non-menial economic future, above all to walk the streets with dignity, are beyond the reach of the 650,000 Palestine Arabs.
He goes on:

I came away from my last visit to Gaza with the feeling that it would take a Dante to give adequate literary expression to the intense concentration of dejection, bitterness and despair crowded into the small squalid enclave of gloom.
Later in his article Abba Eban goes on to recall that Golda Meir, in her last words to the nation, had written:
No sane Israeli ever believed that we could permanently rule all the territories and populations in the West bank and Gaza. New borders would have to be fixed with Jordan.

Of course, that is a position which the Australian Government ascribes to through its support of Resolution 242 in the United Nations and which most countries of the world also adopt. Something has to be done about the Palestinians and to me it is a tragedy that the wit of the Israeli people cannot be harnessed towards finding out, finding the compromise, finding the way to bring that solution about.

Recently I signed an advertisement in the Adelaide Advertiser calling for just this. I notice that in the most recent edition of the Australia-Israel Review it is called `an anti-Israel advertisement signed by the Chairman of the joint parliamentary Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee', which is me. It goes on later to say what the advertisement actually said. The Australia-Israeli Review said:

An advertisement authorised by the Palestinian Human Rights Campaign Committee of South Australia called for condemnation of Israeli troop behaviour in the territories and for an international forum to discuss the creation of a Palestinian State.

I make no apology whatever for the action I took. I believe it is supported by the very great majority of opinion in Australia, by the very great majority of opinion in the rest of the Western world, including the United States. It is a matter of sadness to me that, through intransigence or paralysis, more is not being done to address this urgent problem.

It is not a problem in which time is on Israel's side. At the moment there are living in Israel about 750,000 Arabs. A further 1.3 million Arabs live in the territories of the West Bank and Gaza, which has been occupied by Israel since 1967. With a birthrate that is considerably higher than that of the Israeli population it is estimated that eventually, within 20 years, there will be an Arab majority in the territory now controlled by Israel.

What is Israel to do? Is it to formally annex the territories and deny the Arab population a vote, in which case it denies one of its most precious possessions, namely its existence as a democracy? Or, is it to annex its territories and allow the Arab population a vote, in which case it will no longer be a Jewish State? It is something that has to be addressed by any Israeli government. It is a tragedy that the present Israeli Government finds itself unable to address the particular problem. It will disappoint me greatly if the reaction of Friends of Israel and the Israeli Government is confined simply to expressions of shock and dismay at statements such as I made, and many other people have made, without asking why it is that moderate and knowledgeable people-as I am described by the same writer-are saying such things now, here and elsewhere in the western world.

I now wish to take up the point made by the honourable member for Warringah that there is not much about that in the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. There is a very good reason why there is not much about this in the statement. The reason precisely for that is that the Minister was considerably involved in negotiations and remains under an obligation not to convey too widely some of what he was informed. Some of it he has passed on to be fed into a central process which is an attempt at peacemaking which is proceeding at the moment. I congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on the emphasis in his statement, not only about the matters I have mentioned but also about the issue of food aid to southern Africa, and his efforts directly to bring about some sort of settlement in South Africa. I congratulate the Minister also on his continuing efforts to develop an independent foreign policy directed towards the abiding interests of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today for 39 minutes we heard from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) a statement in which he set out to acquaint the House with the results of his activities in recent weeks, of a substantial excursion he undertook overseas in the course of his duties. Unquestionably the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is a most industrious Minister; that must be conceded. It must also be acknowledged, however, that his dilemma is that which often confronts this House: that this House is seen to be quite industrious but some doubt remains as to whether it produces anything. I should have thought that a 39-minute speech would have contained substantial detail to better acquaint this House about critical matters concerning our country and countries with which Australia has substantial relationships, and about matters of joint concern. But that the Minister should have used so much of that time to address himself to real and imagined deficiencies in the Opposition's position rather suggests that he himself was conscious that he was going to fall short of the expectation of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that those outside this place who may look to the submissions and presentations of members for their own guidance in coming to conclusions, should be so denied in this case. We were subjected to a dot-point speech from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In relation to matters that he might have expanded, we were left somewhat disappointed. However, of course, Foreign Ministers from the beginning of time have probably been subjected to extraordinary frustrations simply because of the nature of our foreign affairs-the ebb and flow, the continuing state of flux. Within recent years we have seen a substantial change in relationships; for example, between China and Russia. Israel, which matter the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) just addressed, is at risk of facing significant change in attitudes from other nations. That state was once the champion of the world, since it established itself after the World War II holocaust. However, now because of the circumstances in which it is placed, it is becoming subject to criticism because of what is perceived by others to be reprehensible acts in which it is involved whilst it tries to engage simply in the act of survival.

So we have a continuing change. Foreign Ministers, of course, are left in this inglorious state of flux where one has to not only deal with today but also try to read tomorrow. In particular what saddens me is that in a number of instances there is something that is a little short of misrepresentation possibly from both sides of the House. I am concerned essentially with the comment of the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), who handles himself extremely well in this place. He misinterpreted the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), who I thought made an excellent contribution when he addressed the statements of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I say that with total sincerity because I reserve the right to be critical of members of this side of the House, just as I am of Government members when occasion invites.

The honourable member for Macarthur charged the honourable member for North Sydney with having stated that the six condemned people in South Africa should hang. The honourable member for North Sydney said nothing of the sort. He dealt with what in turn he alleged was a misrepresentation by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, who said:
Six people not directly involved in a violent incident are about to be hanged.

Quite properly the honourable member for North Sydney took up the words, `not directly involved'. His argument, from an extract of the transcript of evidence in the trial, pointed out clearly that the six people were involved. The honourable member for North Sydney said not a word about whether they should hang or what fate should be meted out to them. He challenged the probity of the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade that the six people were not directly involved.

Unless we discount totally the evidence found in the transcript provided by the South African Embassy, we must accept its veracity. If we dismiss it as being without veracity, we will have somewhat of a dilemma in explaining why two of those initially charged had their cases dismissed. This rather suggests to me that there is a system of justice within that country, albeit within narrow parameters. The statement made by the honourable member for North Sydney proves beyond question of doubt that the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, that the six people were not directly involved, was a misrepresentation of the facts. It was said that subsequently the honourable member for Macarthur charged the honourable member for North Sydney with having asserted that the six people in question should hang. One can if one wishes, on an inferential basis, say that that was the intention. That was unfortunate for this Parliament and for the honourable member concerned because I trust he guards his own integrity as jealously as most of us do, which often, unhappily, results in singular failure in that endeavour. It was however, a laudable ambition.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was addressing the statement which the Minister for Foreign Affairs put before the House earlier today. In the minutes remaining to me in this debate, I wish to touch on a few random matters. It is sufficient to say at this stage that Australia's concern with the state of world affairs is justifiably one of major proportion. Rarely have we seen a world in such disarray; there are festering sores virtually wherever one looks and certainly we must maintain our presence in foreign affairs. One recalls the days when a glance at the atlas would have revealed substantial areas of the world coloured pink or red. `Red' became almost a dirty word, but when one saw areas marked in brilliant pink one knew that that was the extent of the British Empire. It must be acknowledged that in those days, for better or for worse, many of the problems that confront our globe today would have been promptly resolved by sending out a couple of battleships to a particular area. Yet, paradoxically, history rather proves that in those circumstances, although people may have been oppressed, generally they were well fed and there was a tranquility about the place.

SPEECH.PARA: Today sadly, particularly in Africa-a continent in which the Minister for Foreign Affairs spent a considerable portion of his time-we have the paradox of independence being a concomitant of empty bellies; not only empty bellies, but also genocidal characteristics with countries which had looked forward to independence but which now for a number of reasons demonstrate a lack of ability to handle their new freedom. The man in the street is perplexed by these things. He reads in the newspapers about the situation in Ethiopia, where aid trucks carrying food have been destroyed by insurgents or elements within the country, but where people are dying in their thousands. It is almost genocide. The man or woman in the street says, `Why are we sending money there when it does not get through to the people who need it, and why do we send out money when there are clear instances of poverty in our own country?'. That is a simplistic view.

Naturally, we have to maintain a presence. It does not take a great deal of imagination to appreciate that in the case of some of our primary exports and the competition or threat emanating from the United States of America in trade arrangements, if there were not an Australian presence there, certainly the natural tendency of United States congressmen and senators to succumb to the blandishments or insistence of their constituents would involve the United States of America in arrangements that would be counterproductive to Australia's proper involvement in global trade and its quite proper ambitions. Therefore, we must have a presence.

I mentioned earlier the gunboat strategy. The extraordinary paradox in today's world is that whilst we have all the elements predisposing such an event with the intrusion of a major force to restore some order or, to put the matter in uglier terms, to ensure that its own best interests are preserved, there is an avoidance of such action-a restraint-because, believe it or not, the horrendous nuclear deterrent has worked and is working. It is a frightful thing to have hanging over our heads but unquestionably it has preserved--

TALK.START.PARA: —For 43 years.

—For 43 years, as the honourable member for Mallee points out-his skill at mathematics and calculation is renowned in this place-we have been free from global encounters. There would have been at least two over that period in my estimation and there are all the elements in the world now which in older times would have precipitated a crisis.
—There were 100-year wars.

—Indeed, there were 100-year wars. There was a continuation of hostility, alienation and, by and large, a failure by man to come to terms with reality. Apparently, we cannot contain our ambition, and if it is not one country that has ambitions it is another. I am reminded of that delightful anecdote of the old, bent lady sitting in the village square while everybody else was rejoicing because of the passing of a tyrant. Somebody said to her, `Why aren't you rejoicing too?'. She said, `Why should I rejoice? I have seen four tyrants deposed'. It seems that a succession of tyrants come to power. It is the nuclear deterrent which has curbed the ambitions of some of the major countries when, in earlier years, undoubtedly there would have been a major confrontation.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether we look at South Africa, the Israelis, the Palestinians, at countries anywhere in the world we see people striving for survival. Often they are used by those with a lust for power who seek to divert that honest, instinctive motivation to achieve unto themselves a power that is totally inconsistent with their entitlement. But one cannot lose sight of the fact that basically we are all simple human beings and we pursue that which we see as being consistent with our own measured entitlement, which often, unhappily, proves to be no more than expectation. Invariably there is a substantial gulf between the two.

We are encouraged to believe that arms limitation will enhance the prospect of peace. I have reservations about it, even though I am not displeased with what is happening. If we were disarmed totally the resolution of disputations would simply become a matter of numerical strength. If we were reduced to fighting with spears, it stands to reason that Australia would have little prospect of defending itself if marched upon by a country with a population 10 times Australia's size.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who could strangle the most.

—As the honourable member says, it would depend on who could strangle the most. I do not know whether the honourable member is obliquely suggesting that my speech is making him choke, but he did use the word `strangle'. As I mentioned earlier, there was an expectation that the Minister for Foreign Affairs would be bringing to the House a more detailed statement than in fact he presented. He covered a lot of ground. There are a host of situations of more than ordinary importance to Australia, and he rather skipped through his speech on a dot-point basis and left the House with a considerable curiosity as to where Australia's foreign affairs might be best secured. I also mentioned the fact that the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs made an excellent speech in response and he gave a greater balance to matters advanced by the Minister. It is a sad reflection perhaps on this House that honourable members seem possessed of a compulsion to exploit the political opportunities, without letting the facts stand for themselves and be judged accordingly. I fancy that the Minister for Foreign Affairs would have been surprised at how well his statement might have been received if he had dealt exclusively with the positive points emanating from his own activities, rather than wasting a considerable portion of his 39 minutes to concentrate on alleged Opposition aberrations. They impress nobody and invariably in the end prove to have little substance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) on his whimsical contribution to this debate.
—It was serious.

—It was serious and whimsical. I am complimenting the honourable member on his contribution to the debate. It is nice for young, pragmatic, new members of this House, such as the member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) and, to know that there are people like the honourable member for Wide Bay who can take a broad historical perspective. It is a pleasure for me to have the opportunity to respond to the report by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) on his recent trip overseas. It would seem that his talks and activities in Africa, the Middle East and South East Asia were cordial and productive. I add my congratulations on the success of his endeavours.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian foreign policy has broadly two aims which operate at different levels but frequently converge. One is a relatively self-centred focus on geographical areas which are of direct political and economic significance to this country. Contrary to what the Opposition has said, no-one in this Government resiles from that approach nor plays down its importance. The Minister's recent activities aimed at forging bilateral trade agreements and the considerable resources which this Government devotes to the Asia-Pacific region attest to this. However, this Government's foreign policy rests also on a broader aim-to protect and promote wherever possible democratic and human ideals, which the Australian Labor Party, at least, holds dear. Our platform pledges us to support human rights and economic equality, and to oppose oppression and racism. It is this aspect of our policy which has been behind this Government's support, both moral and financial, for the African front line states, and Mozambique in particular, in their struggle to overcome South African oppression and destabilisation and the tragic economic and human devastation which prevails in these countries.

The Opposition, of course, is very good at making motherhood statements about human rights and freedom. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in his speech to the Australian Institute of International Affairs in Hobart earlier this month, criticised this Government's stand on South Africa, and then said:

This is not to deny that the situation in South Africa and any solutions to its problems is of immense complexity, nor should it prevent the strongest possible condemnation of the latest restrictions on political expression in South Africa.

So the Leader of the Opposition condemns the situation in South Africa. The Leader of the Opposition can verbally condemn until the proverbial cows come home, but what would he or his Party actually do to promote freedom and justice in South Africa? He has not let us into that secret. All he has done is criticise in the most destructive and mean spirited way positive actions which this Government has taken to further the cause of equality and freedom in that region. He and the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), have condemned-there is that word again-Australia's $6m emergency aid grant to Mozambique, purportedly because an Australian missionary is being detained there. First of all, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade made it quite clear in answer to a question in this House on Tuesday that all that can possibly be done is being done to secure an early and fair trial for Mr Ian Grey. Australian consular authorities and the Minister himself while he was there have made representations on Mr Grey's behalf in relation to his legal representation, the bringing forward of the trial and support during the trial.

Also, it would be a dereliction of our moral duty to ignore the plight of the Mozambican people. After years of civil strife the city of Maputo and the countryside are devastated. Shops are empty, the people totally demoralised. With a devaluation of 1,000 per cent in little more than a year, the currency is almost worthless. Inflation is conservatively estimated at 120 per cent. But worst of all, of a population of 15 million people five million are reported to be suffering from acute starvation, and the average life expectancy is 46 years. Yet when this Government gives a modest $6m to help alleviate this tragic situation, the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for North Sydney jump up and down and say that that is not in Australia's national interest. I suggest to those honourable gentlemen opposite that it is not, in the short term at least, Australia's national interest which is at stake here. What is at stake are the lives of 15 million largely innocent and powerless men, women and children. I also suggest that in the longer term it is very much in Australia's national and international interest to share and to be seen to be sharing in the aid effort for that region which is currently being carried largely by other Western nations such as Canada and western European countries.

Aid figures indicate that the $6m we are giving to Mozambique is modest not only in absolute terms but also in relative terms. If we look at Australian food aid to Ethiopia, another African country stricken by famine, we find that in the three years from 1984-85 to 1986-87 Australia gave $34.4m worth of food aid to that country and $6.76m to Mozambique. On a per capita basis, all forms of Australian aid to these two nations work out over the three years to $1.23 per Ethiopian and $1.25 per Mozambiquan. I do not recall the Opposition ever claiming that we should not be sending aid to Ethiopian famine victims because it is not in our national interest, as they are now saying about our aid to Mozambique. Perhaps members of the Opposition actually have to see a nation's people dying on their television screens or wait until someone organises a pop concert or a cause becomes popular before they consider taking action. Perhaps the Opposition considers that there are more or less deserving classes of famine victim.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they are just playing politics.

—Exactly. If we compare overall aid to Mozambique over those three years with our aid to Fiji, which the Leader of the Opposition claims is a nation we are neglecting, we find that the $1.25 per capita expenditure in Mozambique pales in comparison with the $76.76 per capita grant we have given to Fiji. In the last three years we have given more than 50 times the aid to Fiji on a per capita basis as we have to Mozambique. So let us not have any more false claims from the Opposition that we are favouring African nations at the expense of the nations of our region and therefore supposedly are not pursuing our national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not also in Australia's national interest that we be taken at our word when we express revulsion at what is happening in South Africa and what the South African regime is doing to the economies and the people of the front line states? It is not enough to do as the Leader of the Opposition has done and stand up at yet another meeting in Australia mouthing pious platitudes condemning the South African regime. If Australia is to be taken seriously in this regard it must put its money where its mouth is, and that is quite literally what our Foreign Minister has done in the course of his visit to that region. Relations with these African states should go beyond the provision of aid. This region offers new frontiers of commercial enterprise to Australian companies and, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade pointed out, a trade mission of Australian business representatives will visit Zimbabwe and Mauritius this year to explore those opportunities. The Opposition forgets that Australia and these African countries form the eastern and western perimeters of the same ocean, albeit a large ocean. It is sensible that Australian companies, particularly Western Australian companies, should turn their attention westward to capitalise on the trade opportunities that present themselves there.

I now turn my attention to the Middle East, which I must say is more than the Leader of the Opposition did in his address to the Australian Institute of International Affairs two weeks ago. I was surprised when earlier in the debate the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) spent five of his 15 allotted minutes criticising our Foreign Minister because he allegedly did not address the Middle Eastern question and give it the due consideration that the honourable member thought he should. I have here the address of the Leader of the Opposition to the Institute of International Affairs-and I have read it, which obviously is more than the honourable member for Warringah has done-and there is not one reference to the Middle Eastern problem, despite the fact that this speech was supposed to reflect the Opposition's world view. The half million Australians of Jewish and Arab origin might well ask themselves what importance the Opposition places on events in their countries of origin and on the welfare of their compatriots when the region does not rate even the most scant mention in an Opposition speech on broad foreign policy.

For almost four years, from 1981 to 1984, I had the pleasure-and it was a pleasure-to live and work in Jordan and to travel extensively throughout that country, the occupied territories and Israel. I was able to see at first hand and from both sides the conditions which prevailed and still prevail in that region. Through my family's involvement in an Australian agricultural aid program I came to appreciate the inestimable importance of our involvement in constructive aid and trade programs to the economic development of the region and for Australia's own commercial and political interests. The conflict for sovereignty over the occupied territories is not simply one of self-aggrandisement or expansion for militarily strategic reasons. It is also a desperate struggle for access to physical resources-agricultural, mineral and water resources-which are vital for the survival of the people of the region. Relevant, well targeted and even-handed Australian aid programs aimed at developing, maximising and rationalising these resources can go a long way in expediting the resolution of political conflict. In addition, offsetting opportunities for trade in Australian foodstuffs, equipment, technology and expertise make these initiatives a wise economic move for Australia

The events of recent weeks in the occupied territories, tragic and destructive as they have been, may constitute some sort of flashpoint-a catalyst for new and, hopefully, more successful negotiations towards peace. There is evidence that a growing number of Israelis in the Government, the army and the community are leaning more favourably towards the idea of some sort of withdrawal from the occupied territories and that a growing number of moderate Arabs are perhaps willing to bend a little to bring about a solution. But the possibility of withdrawal at this time has been made much more difficult by actions of the Israeli Government back in the days when the idea of withdrawal was unthinkable to most Israelis. I am referring here to the Israeli decisions, first, to transfer the Israeli Parliament-the Knesset-from Tel Aviv to occupied Jerusalem and to declare that city the capital of Israel; and, secondly, to establish new and permanent exclusively Jewish settlements on the West Bank. These acts were provocative and based on that primitive and crude precept that possession is nine points of the law.

The establishment of the Israeli seat of government in a city which is held purely by military force, a city which is sacred to Moslem, Christian and Jew and which is the repository of the historical lifeblood of the people of Palestine, was an act of overweening presumption. In addition, incursions into Arab East Jerusalem and, in recent days, the storming by Israeli troops of the Dome of the Rock-one of the two most sacred site in Islam-were unwise and untenable. The Jewish settlements which have proliferated on the West Bank in particular are an Israeli attempt to establish a concrete-and I use that term literally-presence in that area. But the settlements have no place there. Apart from being physically offensive, they accommodate Israelis who merely reside there and who commute to Tel Aviv or Jerusalem to work. They form no organic part of the landscape or of the local economy or community. Their residents sit behind their bunkers and barbed wire in a self-imposed state of siege while around them thousand-year-old communities slowly die of economic and cultural starvation.

It is the location of the Israeli Parliament in the occupied city of Jerusalem and the presence of permanent Jewish settlements on the occupied West Bank which will make the achievement of a significant Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories a formidable task. But I wish both parties, Israeli and Arab, good luck and fortitude in any future negotiations.

The policy of this Government towards the Middle East, one which I personally endorse, is one of an even-handed but consistent effort to contribute to the achievement of a just peace which upholds the sovereignty of the state of Israel, self-determination for the Palestinians and the maintenance of security, freedom and human rights for all people of the region. This most recent visit of our Foreign Minister has furthered the respect and regard in which Australia is held by governments and authorities in that area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 March, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue my remarks in relation to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 1988. I was referring to some clauses of the Bill. I will now refer to another clause. In relation to that, if there is one group of business people who benefit from elections, that group is the printers. They certainly have real pickings at election time, as we in this House all know. That is fair enough; generally they do a good job, and I have no problem with that. Certainly in my own case I have been well satisfied with the end product of their labours. So I have no argument with the amendment which will repeal the requirement that printers furnish returns on referendum printing. Both the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and the Australian Electoral Commission agree that printers' returns related to elections and referendums are of limited value for the purpose of crackdowns and cross-checks. The requirement for the making of a return should therefore be removed.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill also removes the obligation on broadcasters and publishers to furnish returns for a referendum where it is held in conjunction with an election. It is very difficult to distinguish between election and referendum expenditure in returns furnished by broadcasters and publishers. I am also pleased to see that clause 6 amends section 11 of the principal Act to allow for the official preparation and distribution of arguments for and against any referendum proposed in forms which are suitable for the visually impaired. At present the Act provides for the presentation of materials only in the form of a written pamphlet. This change will be welcomed by the visually impaired in the community. Last Sunday I attended the opening of the National Championships for the Blind, which were held in Perth, when I presented a flag. There is no doubt that people who have a visual handicap want to be seen as normal people. They want to participate in normal community activities. Participation in future referenda is another step in that direction which should be encouraged. I am pleased to see that we are encouraging it in this Bill.

In conclusion, I again emphasise that the proposed amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act are based on recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. As I said earlier in my remarks, this was a most excellent document and one that deserves praise from both sides of the House. In fairness to Opposition members, they have indeed praised that report. I certainly support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in the debate on the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 1988, at the outset I commend the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) for the amendments which he proposes to move to this legislation on behalf of the Opposition. They are section specific amendments which make a lot of sense. I hope that the Government, between now and when the legislation goes to the Senate, will consider whether those amendments might be agreed to. They are not extraordinarily controversial amendments. Indeed, they are practical, legitimate amendments, with no major cost implications, and ones that we commend to the House and to the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps it is time to think a little more broadly about the question of referendums. I noted previous speakers' comments with interest. It is always edifying to look at the record of referendum results since the very first referendum was held in Australia at the Federal level on 12 December 1906. Ironically, that first referendum concerned Senate elections. An extraordinarily high 82.65 per cent of voters-a majority in all States-were in favour of the proposal. I do not think that that record has been bettered on too many occasions since then, except in the referendum relating to Aboriginals and the Constitution, held on 27 May 1967. That proposal also attracted a majority in all States, with 90.77 per cent voting in favour of it. If that question were to be asked in a modified form today, perhaps that vote would be slightly different. But when one looks at the number of referenda that have been held since 1900, one is looking at a total of 38. Only eight out of 38 proposals have been passed in the history of the Federation of Australia-since 1901. So the Constitution and questions referred to the people by way of referenda have not been considered lightly by the people. They have been considered cautiously by the people of many generations. This reflects not so much an innate conservative approach to tampering with the Constitution but the very practical consideration that one does not lightly tamper with the Australian Constitution document which was drawn up at the turn of the century to bring the six State colonies and the nation together as a whole. It should be respected. I commend the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for his comments in that regard.

One of the key meetings associated with forming the Constitution and bringing about the Federation of Australia took place in my electorate at Corowa in 1893. That meeting led to subsequent meetings which, in turn, led to the adoption of our Federal Constitution. Tonight the House is considering machinery provisions for the conduct of referenda in the light of the fact that just eight out of 38 referenda have ever fulfilled both requirements, that is, a majority of States and a majority of votes overall. It is important to consider that historical context before moving on to discuss some aspects which arise from it.

One might ask why the Government is bedding down these referendum voting provisions now. The Government says, and we accept this, that it is to adopt similar provisions which have already been adopted for the conduct of elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate for the conduct of referenda as well as to add three other concepts in accordance with the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. But let us get down to the truth. It is to clear the decks for a series of national referenda which the Deputy Prime Minister, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), has indicated he would like put to the people in July of this year, our bicentennial year. It is relevant to allow me to continue to make these comments within the context of the Bill. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said that these requirements were essential before the conduct of any future referendum.

Let me explain to the House some of the proposals which are in the pipeline for future referendum questions. They are very worrying proposals which have caused enormous concern across Australia. I signal here and now that they will be the subject of a vigorous debate in the community and will probably add to the graveyard of previous referendum questions which have been defeated by vote of the people. The first proposal, and the biggest worry, relates to circumscribing the powers of the Senate, the House of review, the upper House of our Federal Parliament, in a most horrific way, a way which will significantly alter the balance of power in our parliamentary institution and our Constitution. It will pave the way for the possible destruction of the Senate at a future date in accordance with the secret agenda of the Australian Labor Party. It will pave the way for shackling the Senate and removing its independence. This first question is in the Constitutional Commission pipeline. Both the Liberal and National parties are totally opposed to destroying in any way the independence of the Senate or introducing artificial shackles on its powers which do not stand up to proper scrutiny.

The role of the Senate has at times annoyed members of the lower House, on both sides. But that is as it is. Overall, the contribution of the Senate to the good governance of this country has been tremendous. If we are annoyed on both sides of the House from time to time by the handling of legislation in the Senate, by the motions and behaviour of the Senate, so be it. On balance, the contribution the Senate makes to the good governance of this country has been such over decades that one does not tamper with its powers. One does not destroy the independence of the Senate. I signal to the House and to the nation that that proposal is step one in the constitutional pipeline for referendum questions later this year.

The second possibility requiring the passage of this Bill, in accordance with the Minister's second reading speech, is to limit the powers of the Governor-General. The Governor-General is an integral part of the Constitution of Australia. Again, it is something which should not be lightly tampered with. If I might say so, although I know Standing Orders restrict my reference severely, one could have nothing but praise for the manner in which the current occupant provides service to this nation as Governor-General. I add to that my praise for the role played by his wife. This House, this Parliament and this nation cannot embark on the path of reducing the powers of the Governor-General which is, once again, part of the secret agenda of the Labor Party to have a Constitution which suits it and which suits its endgame, which is, as several honourable members have said, part of paving the way of the abolition of the Senate.

The third proposal relates to the Federal Government's powers in the management of the national economy. It will be interesting to see how the details of this question are framed when eventually the public is allowed to see the details of the referendum questions later this year.

The fourth proposal is patterned on the Bill of Rights. The people have already, through a grand grass roots revolution, expressed their total opposition to all that was involved in the Bill of Rights. The people, I dare to say, will once again argue and campaign heavily against a Bill of Rights and throw it out as they did with the ID card. If the Government wants to put up a referendum question enshrining aspects of the Bill of Rights in the Constitution it can expect the same fate.

The fifth proposal in the pipeline from the Constitutional Commission relates to the abolition of the Queen's residual powers. Once again, it is all in one direction. It is all part of the secret agenda of the Labor Government which we should reject. The sixth proposal tampers with the preamble written into the Constitution with regard to Aboriginal people. The seventh proposal regards the implementation of one vote one value. The eighth proposal, behind which all else will shelter, is the four-year term for the Federal Parliament with a government having to run a minimum of three years.

On the face of it, a four-year term has a great deal to commend it. New South Wales moved to a four-year term at the last election. Next Saturday will see the general election for the Legislative Assembly in New South Wales and one-third of the Legislative Council, coming more or less four years after the March 1984 election in that State. It is argued that four years is sufficient time for governments to make the hard decisions they have to make and not have to go to the people with the cost burden and so forth associated with general elections. If that is all this proposal does, and if it does it in a legitimate and proper way, perhaps the four-year term will be looked upon favourably. However, I suspect that the Government will shelter behind the attractive four-year term proposition and sneak into the Constitution the seven other unattractive propositions it is going to draft into these questions by way of referenda to the Australian people later this year.

There will be a very careful and difficult decision for all major political parties to take with regard to the forthcoming constitutional referenda. There will be a very difficult decision to take with regard to the four-year term. I for one am not prepared to sacrifice the sanctity and strength of our Federal Constitution for the right to sit for one extra year on these benches in Parliament without facing the people. I actually do not mind the people having a right to pass judgment on the Government. I think that is central and integral to our democratic process and I suspect the real motives of the Government in paving the way for these constitutional questions to come forward as part of and flowing from the legislation which is before the House at this time.

I say to the House and to the nation, `Beware of the forthcoming constitutional referenda questions because there is a lot more in them than meets the eye'. It is not a case of burying one's head in the sand. It is not a case of denying that there are justifications for updating a constitutional document which was, in the main, drawn up at the turn of the century. As I have pointed out to the House, on eight occasions people have adopted referendum questions and that is quite acceptable. But on this occasion we have a series of Ministers, including the Deputy Prime Ministers and Attorney-General, who have signalled that they are on the verge of retirement. They are anxious to get in place their particular monuments to their careers and the Deputy Prime Minister, for whom I have some respect, is angling to get his constitutional referendum questions up. For that he needs this Bill, an attractive proposition for the electorate and a strong campaign. He would argue that hopefully people will adopt it. Again, I say to the people of Australia, `Be very wary of what the Government is proposing later this year, or whenever it brings forward constitutional questions, because there is an enormous amount of danger associated with them'. I serve notice that the Liberal and National parties will be watching extremely closely and reaching proper and responsible decisions with regard to their attitude to those specific referendum questions.

Earlier today, for the first time, the House witnessed a new procedure which saw a Bill known as the Flags Amendment Bill come forward. It is relevant in passing to mention the Flags Amendment Bill. This Bill proposes that our national flag cannot be changed unless it is submitted to a national referendum which has the normal requirements associated with a national referendum. I want, firstly, to indicate as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs and as the Federal member for Farrer, my total support for the Flags Amendment Bill and my total support for bringing our national flag within the scope of referendum questions rather than exposing it to the danger of an unholy alliance between someone like the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and someone like future His Excellency, Mr Bill Hayden, should the honourable member for Oxley make it to Government House, as was discussed in the media two weeks ago. As the law now stands, the Prime Minister of this nation can go to Government House on a Sunday night and put a piece of paper in front of the Governor-General. The Governor-General can sign that piece of paper and by Monday morning this nation could have administratively, overnight, a new national flag. That right should be denied any Prime Minister of any political persuasion.

I believe that the Flags Amendment Bill does just that by providing that our national flag can be changed only by way of a referendum which would be conducted under the procedures laid down by the legislation before the House. I know that many Returned Services League sub-branches, many veterans and the majority of supporters of all major parties, as the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), pointed out this morning-the vast majority of all Australians-support the retention of our national flag and support the right for it to be changed only by way of referendum. They would be furious if the Prime Minister were to take the administrative option without reference to the Parliament or the people. I hope that the two Flags Amendment Bills, the one introduced to the Senate by Senator Short and the one introduced to this House by the Leader of the Opposition, will be favourably dealt with. I challenge the Government to declare its attitude to the legislation before much longer so that hopefully it can be dealt with in the autumn session of Parliament.

The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill in many of its provisions has the support of the Opposition in the modernisation of some of the procedures laid down. One issue which is not dealt with by this Bill is the now accepted polling hours of 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. across the nation. Not so long ago that in itself was quite a controversial issue, but it has now been generally accepted that it is in the right direction. The fact that two hours have been taken off the hours of polling day I do not believe has altered the result even in country seats, even during the middle of harvesting, although it has created some difficulties. But there is universal acceptance of the 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. polling hours. That is not at issue. A number of other measures are at issue, particularly with regard to the yes and no questions which have been adequately covered by other speakers. In commending to the House the amendments which deal with those questions I conclude by reiterating my strong concerns over any moves to sabotage our great Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in rising in support of the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill. I join with my fellow colleagues who have indicated their thanks and appreciation of the work that has been done by previous joint select committees on electoral matters. They indicated a number of suggestions for amendment to our electoral laws. The purpose of this Bill is to bring the principal Act, that is, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act, into line with the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I think that the sorts of things that the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) wanted to read into this Act are nothing but nonsense and whims of fancy.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is an attempt to bring the two Acts into line. Basically the major provisions are designed to ensure, amongst other things, that overseas polling officials are subject to the same penalties for neglect of duties as those officials in Australia; to remove existing time limits on the ability to alter polling day or the return of writs; and to allow the preparation and distribution of arguments for and against proposed referendum proposals in a form suitable for the visually impaired. I think the latter is very important because it enables the access of people with that sort of handicap to information that forms the basis of referenda proposals.

Other provisions in the Bill are the consolidation of requirements relating to the forwarding and declaration of votes; the provision that only those votes that are unequivocally yes or no should be regarded as formal; and the provision that there be no obligation on broadcasters and publishers to furnish returns for a referendum where it is held in conjunction with an election. Whilst this is machinery-type legislation, it gives us an opportunity to discuss a wide range of matters about referenda and about Australia's ability to alter its Constitution.

The honourable member for Farrer made reference to the fact that out of 38 proposals that have been put forward to the Australian people to alter the Constitution, only eight have been successful. I think in some cases the alterations proposed were so straightforward that their success was never in doubt. I instance the Constitution Alteration (Aboriginals) Bill of 1967 in respect of Aborigines. Which sought to remove any ground for the belief that the Constitution discriminated against people of the Aboriginal race. As the honourable member for Farrer indicated, that was given overwhelming support by Australia. It obtained a majority in all six States and an overall majority of some 4.6 million votes out of a total of 6.1 million possible votes. That was perhaps one of the most outstanding referenda successes, and justifiably so.

Perhaps we should ponder why, when popularly elected governments put forward proposals to the Australian people, it is so difficult to achieve success in amending the Constitution. One of the issues that I think is worth canvassing is a proposal that has been put before the Australian people-I acknowledge that it has been rejected-and my colleague the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) touched upon it in his contribution to this debate. I refer to the provision that not only do we need a majority of those who cast votes to support the proposition but we also need a majority in a majority of the States. So in four of the six States we need to get a majority plus the majority of overall voters. The substance of the contention of my colleague the honourable member for Calwell was that perhaps it was sufficient that we look at requiring only a majority of voters for a proposition to be successful. May I suggest that even the proposal that was rejected is again worthy of reconsideration. That simply stated that not only would we require a majority of those voting, but also that we would alter the number of States required back to three. As I said, that proposition was rejected.

In talking about the Constitution it is appropriate to note that our founding fathers were not as enlightened as we are in matters of gender. Perhaps that is something we should think about. There has been a great deal of change in the basis for a number of the matters that were put into the Constitution in 1901. We had six colonies with conflicting interests who were trying to come together to form a nation. Obviously, there was a great deal of suspicion of the denial of those colonies' rights, and therefore a great deal of compromise in protecting any perceived deficiencies in the formation of the Federation.

That brings me to the next point I wish to raise. We already have evidence of the difficulties apparent in making meaningful amendments to the Constitution. The honourable member for Farrer tonight took part in a campaign-a campaign in which some of his colleagues have also been involved-pandering to that natural suspicion about changes to the Constitution and running a whole series of red herrings about what may or may not be proposed later this year for constitutional change. The basis of the contribution by the honourable member for Farrer was that the Government would naively put forward propositions which, because of this natural suspicion, would have little chance of success. History has shown that governments must not merely put forward constitutional changes at their whim and fancy; they must give the proposals careful consideration.

I contrast the contribution of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who chastised the Government because it has not yet made clear which proposals will be put forward. The honourable member for Farrer and his colleagues in the Senate, Senator Chaney and Senator Short, have already commenced a campaign in which they are asking for some form of action. The honourable member for Farrer talked about some hidden agenda. Senator Chaney earlier this year said, `Opponents must mobilise now. Labor's plans to nobble the Senate and change the Constitution to its own political advantage can be thwarted without resort to an expensive referendum campaign'. He used the lowest commonest denominator and played on people's natural suspicions.

In the best traditions of bipartisanship, we should be looking at some of the things that have been proposed because. I believe that some of them are worthwhile. Some of them reflect contemporary attitudes. In proposing that we should look at and discuss change to the Constitution there is no suggestion that the present Constitution is bad. It is simply suggested that perhaps the Constitution could be made better. It is about time we took a mature approach and looked at some of those questions. Many honourable members opposite have decried the efforts of the Constitutional Commission, a Commission that has given us an ability to seek community input and to have community discussion about proposals. The honourable member for Curtin suggested that in some way the Commission was an abrogation of the Government's and the Parliament's responsibilities. I see it as a good way of getting some input from the community, some reflection of community attitudes on a number of the questions that have been raised.

I now turn to some of the proposals mentioned in this legislation. Of the amendments for the committee stage that have been foreshadowed, the coalition has chosen to highlight-it believes that in some way this opens the Commonwealth Electoral Act to widescale rorting-the change to the residential qualifications for enrolment with the deletion of the need to have lived within the division for three months prior to polling day in order to vote. Senator Short, who I understand is the spokesman for home affairs, was quoted in the Age yesterday under the heading `Law change led to increased claims of multiple voting . . .' The article suggested that a number of voting irregularities arose because of this change, that there were allegations of phantom and multiple voting. In some way it is suggested that if this were done on a wide enough scale there could be rorting of the electoral system that would be crucial to the result in certain marginal seats. I believe that that would have to be on the very widest of scales to have any effect.

The important thing is that these matters will be looked at by the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform. The Committee, under the chairmanship of my colleague the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), will be looking at the conduct of the 1987 election. Given the way that members from both sides of politics have worked on that Committee in the past, these allegations will be thoroughly investigated and the internal investigation being conducted by the Commonwealth Electoral Commissioner can also be reviewed. I do not see the necessity for the proposed amendment to withdraw this amendment from the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill. If we accept the Opposition's amendment and this amendment does not go through there will be confusion and the need for two different roles.

As my colleague the honourable member for Calwell indicated, why should we be looking at this point in relation to referendums when, as he put it, it does not really matter whether somebody is enrolled for the division of Calwell or the division of Burke, because if we are to suggest that there is some form of rorting going on, in order for it to be effective the transport of votes across State boundaries would have to occur? I think the suggestion that in some way this provision has led to multiple enrolments can easily be looked into by the processes that are used by the Commonwealth Electoral Commission.

I do not deny that the Electoral Commission should perhaps be looking at some system to tighten up its inspection of people's qualifications to enrol, but I am not suggesting, and I do not agree with the contention of people such as Senator Short, that there is wholesale rorting going on. I believe there are minor instances where people unwittingly do the wrong thing. As an example, I instance the case of somebody who genuinely thought that he had taken out Australian citizenship. He had an invitation to attend a ceremony but, due to illness or some other reason, he could not attend the ceremony. At some later stage he filled out an electoral card and got his name on the electoral roll. Subsequently, when trying to get a passport, he could not prove that he was actually an Australian citizen.

So there are isolated cases. I acknowledge that perhaps there is a need to tighten up some of the procedures. But let us not get hysterical; let us not come to these conclusions that there is wholesale use of phantom and multiple voting as a result of some rorting of the residential qualifications for voting. As with a whole range of matters, the Opposition has recently reached record heights of hysteria about popular matters. One of those in regard to electoral matters of course was the way that the Opposition, with some assistance from parts of the media, was able to beat up the comments of the Electoral Commissioner, Dr Hughes, about the need to investigate some inconsistencies in the way that the results had been reported. There was never any suggestion that those inconsistencies in any way altered the results of any seats, but the Opposition chose to portray these inconsistencies as being of the gravest and most dastardly consequence.

I think a more considered debate and discussion of matters that are raised would be best, especially when we have a very good organisation in the Australian Electoral Commission, an independent organisation which is in charge of and which conducts elections. I think that by proper cooperation, especially through the efforts of the Committee on Electoral Reform, a number of these matters can be canvassed.

Perhaps we should still be looking at a number of matters in relation to constitutional change. Time precludes my canvassing a number of those, so I shall mention but a few. Last year I made a comment in an adjournment speech on the failure of one of the few constitutional alteration amendment Bills which were successful to really specify the proper action, and that was the constitutional alteration legislation regarding casual Senate vacancies. This proposal sought to ensure as far as practicable that a casual vacancy in the Senate was filled by a person of the same political party as the senator chosen by the people, and that the person should hold the seat for the balance of the term. As I mentioned in my adjournment speech last year, apparently-and pardon the pun-this is a grey area because of the actions of the Tasmanian Premier at the time of the resignation of the then Senator Grimes. Perhaps it is something we, on both sides of politics, should be looking at, because the apparent intention of the referendum was not clear enough, and people such as Premier Gray were almost able to get away with what he attempted in the middle of last year. That is one of the changes we have to look at to tighten up that area.

I do not suggest that, when we talk about the Senate, we do so loosely, because people think that in some way we are trying to undermine its role. But I take it that at the time of Federation it was considered that the Senate would truly be a States House. I think, in the fairest consideration of its 87-year history, that is not entirely the case. It is a very political chamber of this Parliament. I understand that many people see its House of review role as worth while, and I do not contemplate canvassing some sort of ultimate demise of that chamber. But if we accept it as a House of review perhaps we should be looking at the basis of that review. I think that is a fair enough proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to change the rules.

—It is something we should do in a mature way and without the emotion that that interjection indicates. All I ask is for fair consideration to make the Senate's role contemporary, of relevance and not merely just a continuation of some perceived role of the Senate as at 1901. I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of this Bill, and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Government for providing me with an opportunity to make a few remarks in regard to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill. I wish to give the Australian public two short, sharp warnings about the referendum debates that we are likely to have this year. Whilst there is some back-pedalling on referendum proposals this year, I expect that the present Government in New South Wales will be back-pedalling a lot more when it loses on Saturday. However, I say to the Australian public: be warned, because this Government has very particular views about the Constitution. The Opposition is not idle and is preparing itself for the debates that will come later this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The last time we had a major debate in this Parliament about similar legislation was when the Government wanted to stack the odds in its favour and spend more money on the Yes case than on the No case. That was in 1983 and 1984. It ended up backing off on that referendum proposal, but it never backed off on the idea that, because it had access to taxpayers' money, somehow it was justified in spending taxpayers' money to a greater extent on one side than the other. The matter went to the Senate, and there was an amendment which attempted to preclude the Government from using its financial muscle to spend moneys on propaganda pushing Labor's agenda for the Constitution.

So the Government devised this rather clever mechanism to be known as the Constitutional Commission. It scrapped the conventions which we had had for a number of years and which had been quite successful by any reasonable measure, and introduced the Constitutional Commission. Whilst I make no comments about the personalities-and some very fine Australians have been associated with the Commission-the reality is that, when it came down with its first set of recommendations, lo and behold what did we find but good old Australian Labor Party policy. What was that Labor Party policy? Nothing but to undermine the powers of the Senate, a cherished ideal of the Labor Party for many years.

The fact is that this Constitutional Commission has had $6m of our money to push a particular line. I say to the Australian public: beware of the recommendations coming from the Constitutional Commission, because it is our belief that some views coming out of that Commission would be of no advantage and in fact would be to the detriment of all Australians.

The second point I want to make again relates to the sorts of proposals coming from the Constitutional Commission and Government members. Government members say that it is all sweetness and light and that they have nothing but the best of intentions. Let me quote something said by Senator Gareth Evans when he first went into the Senate. He was reported in the Canberra Times on 2 July 1987 as saying:
The way to abolish the Senate, or at least muzzle it, is to white ant from within.

That is the policy-get in and plug away, take away a brick here and a brick there, until the whole foundation of the Senate's powers falls down to Labor's ideological views about the Parliament and how the Parliament should submit to Labor's philosophy.
Senator Evans is not on his own. In 1980, when Mr Hayden was leading the Labor Party, he also had something to say on this issue. The Sydney Morning Herald reported:

Mr Hayden urged Party members to work as hard for Senate candidates as for House of Representatives hopefuls . . . He said there was a tendency for the Party to undercommit itself to the Senate campaign.
``Because we are committed to its eventual elimination, we must take it seriously,'' he said.

That is the true voice of Labor: get in there and white ant it from within. So, I say to the people of Australia, `Be warned, be careful, be cautious'. I say to those who opposed Labor's ID card, `You have a vital stake in the future independence of the Senate'. To those people who supported coalition moves in the Senate to oppose Labor's retrospective taxation legislation, I say, `You have an interest in the independence of the Senate'. To those people who supported the coalition when we attacked Labor's Bill of Rights-otherwise known as the Bill of wrongs-I say: `You have a stake in the independence and strength of the Senate'. To those people who supported the coalition when we threatened to use the powers of the Senate to stop Labor's Industrial Relations Bill to put unions above the law, I say: `You have a stake in a strong and independent Senate'. The coalition parties are not silent on this issue. We have mounted a campaign across Australia, a campaign honourable members will hear much more of as thousands of Australians look to the coalition parties properly to ensure a strong fight to maintain the powers of the Senate.

I conclude by saying to those listening that we are taking a lead on this matter, on the powers of the Senate. This week we have released, and I formally launch in the House tonight, a very telling pamphlet entitled Australia has a strong constitution? Why weaken it?. I say to those who share our concerns about the Senate and our great constitution: `If you are interested in this campaign, contact your local Liberal Party or National Party member, get a copy of the pamphlet and join the community committees that will spring up during the year as we prepare for the referendum campaign in 1988'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one who is a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and who was previously a member of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, I have found the debate very interesting. Not all of it has been relevant, of course. Opposition members have been ranging far and wide with their hysterical references to possible questions in the possible referendum. Of course, these changes have to come in because we cannot have election eligibility criteria different from that which relates to a referendum. Only people as inconsistent as members of the Opposition would have the hide to suggest that we should do such a thing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the Liberal Party's position on this matter has changed. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) spent a great deal of time speaking about the possible referendum, and so did the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I am amazed at the Opposition's cavalier and cynical approach to this matter and its lack of consistency. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) pointed this out in his speech on Tuesday when he mentioned that those opposite opposed the changes now, but they supported the same initiatives in the Electoral Act last year. I am also amazed and disappointed at the Opposition's attempt to classify these changes as somehow partisan and favouring one political party over another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The honourable member should listen to his own speeches. The truth is that both the changes to the referendum provisions and the changes to the Electoral Act from which they are derived improve the opportunity for Australians to participate in the democratic process of elections and referenda without being hindered by artificially contrived restrictions.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the change to the residency status of an elector requiring an absent vote is an important improvement in ensuring that franchise can be extended to people who have moved away from their enrolled address more than three months prior to the election or referendum for which they are seeking franchise. From now on, because of recent changes to the Electoral Act, at Federal elections an elector will no longer be asked whether he or she has lived some time in the past three months at the address for which he or she is enrolled. Under the previous legislation a negative response to this question would have rendered the would-be voter ineligible to vote even though that voter had taken the trouble to come to the polling booth.

In a speech in this House some months ago-obviously on the electoral Act changes-I pointed out that the three months residency provision for absent voters served only to deprive honest or ignorant people of a vote as it could be sidestepped in a number of ways by people who knew the system or were prepared to lie in order to obtain a vote. I know it happens, and I am sure all honourable members know it happens. For the purpose of this debate, given the claims that have been made by some honourable members opposite, it is obviously necessary to repeat that information. For instance, people who realise that their enrolment has not been updated may simply return to the area in which they are enrolled and attend a local polling booth where they can be almost certain that no-one will challenge their residency qualification. The Committee discussed this and none of the members present could recall being asked that residency question when they attended their local polling booth-generally because the polling booth clerks are too busy to ask. So it is totally unfair to require the same question to be asked of people lodging an absent vote request when it is not asked of people turning up at their own polling booth.

Alternatively, those people who are incorrectly enrolled can ask for a postal vote and give their current address as the address to which their ballot-papers should be directed. There is very little to stop people doing this. All they have to say is that they will be more than 10 kilometres from a polling booth on election day-no-one will check that they were-and they just fill in their postal ballot application and have their ballot-papers sent to the address at which they currently reside as if it was a temporary address.

Although I accept the claims of the honourable member for Gilmore that, under the new arrangement, some people voting absent on election day are subsequently and incorrectly appearing on new electors' lists after the election when they no longer reside at those addresses and have not done so for some time, I emphasise that this problem is largely due to the design and wording of the declaration form that the prospective voter is required to sign in order to receive an absent vote ballot-paper. I do not believe it is beyond the wit of this Parliament, the Electoral Matters Committee or the Electoral Commission to come up with a solution to this relatively simple problem. For instance, an elector has to sign a form which details the address for which he or she claims to be enrolled. Nowhere on that form does the elector have an opportunity to declare a current address. How difficult would it be to require both the address for which the elector claims to be enrolled and the address at which the elector currently resides, if this is not the same? That would mean that honourable members would receive up-to-date lists that did not contain the addresses of people who no longer lived in their electorates. The declaration could be treated as an enrolment form in much the same way as it is currently, but it would have the advantage of updating the electoral role in respect of the current residential addresses of all absent voters.

On the matter of itinerant voters and the provisions of this Bill, I say simply that my colleagues the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) and the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) were absolutely correct in their remarks concerning the irrelevance of Opposition arguments against this change in the context of a referendum, when the decision of voters is counted on the basis of a State rather than an electorate. Even in the context of a Federal election, and Federal electoral boundaries, the hysterical scenario outlined by the honourable member for Gilmore is impossible to sustain unless one subscribes to an elaborate conspiracy theory and suffers from severe political paranoia.

The itinerant provisions of this Bill are meant to permit people who have no fixed abode to vote back to a nominated and permanent address. When no such address is applicable the elector may be enrolled in an electorate with which he or she has some particular connection; for example, it may be their place of birth or the place where their parents live. Generally it would be a place in which they have a special interest and not a marginal seat. This provision is hardly capable of rorting on a grand scale and is carefully monitored by the Australian Electoral Commission officers, as are all new provision particularly those relating to secret enrolments.

Previously itinerant workers were deprived of the opportunity to vote because of the transient nature of their employment and lifestyle and the rigid residency requirements of the Electoral Act before it was amended, which is obviously the three-month rule. Why should any person be deprived of a vote simply because he happens to move around the State or nation? Rural labourers such as shearers and fruit pickers contribute to the wealth of Australia in the same way as do all other workers; but their lifestyle is rendered more mobile as a consequence of their employment. Do they not deserve to have a say in how the nation is run? I am sure that none of the National Party members in this place would want some of their rural workers not to vote-but that is currently what happens. Certainly it happened before the last changes to the Electoral Act.

It seems that members of the Opposition have a fundamental problem with this legislation as well as with the earlier amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act even though they were supported by the Liberal Party. Members of the Opposition do not really believe that every adult Australian should have the right to vote. At least that is how it appears to me. They would prefer to put people in little boxes from which they could not escape. Those who do not conform to their rigid view of life and responsible behaviour are denied the right to participate in decision-making processes at all levels, commencing with the right to vote. I am certain that many Opposition members would be far happier to see a return to property franchise. Fortunately, however, adult franchise is here to stay, and this Bill will ensure that the right to participate in a referendum is extended to as many Australians as practicable, as the right to vote in a Federal election was extended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-First, I thank all honourable members who participated in this debate both on the Government side of the House and from the Opposition ranks. Most of the points raised tonight in this debate by the Opposition relate to what might occur or what might be put before the people of Australia in future referendums. The points raised by the Opposition were not about the content of this Bill. One can only conclude from those facts that the Opposition is not serious about putting forward objections to the purpose of this Bill otherwise we would have heard much more about those objections when the opportunity presented itself during the past hour or so.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply say that the Government has always said that it accepts most of the 86 recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and the amendments to the Commonwealth electoral legislation.
