In 1987 we amended the Commonwealth Electoral Act accordingly in line with those beliefs. As all honourable members understand, this Bill brings the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act into line with the Commonwealth Electoral Act and will give effect to those committee recommendations that specifically affect referendums.

The Opposition stated that it gives qualified support to the Government on this Bill. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), outlined seven of the specific amendments that are agreed. He said in his contribution at the second reading stage of the Bill that he disagrees with three aspects. As I understand it those three aspects are clause 8, which relates to the definition of informal ballot-papers; clause 10, which relates to the extension of time for acts by officers; and clause 11, which deals with the schedule that amends different sections as set out in the foreshadowed amendments of the Opposition.

I inform the House that I have examined closely the proposed amendments and I am not of a mind to accept them. I shall give my reasons for not accepting them when I have heard what the Opposition spokesman has to say during the committee stage of the Bill. I refrain from further comment at this state on the foreshadowed amendments; I am sure I will have no difficulty shooting down the Opposition's amendments in a short while. Again I thank those honourable members who participate in the debate, particularly those who were more thoughtful and who restated their commitment to democracy in this country-a concept with which I and the Government wholeheartedly agree.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 8, page 5, lines 13-16, omit paragraph (b).
(2) Clause 10-Opposition to oppose.
(3) Schedule, page 6, omit the following:
``Subsection 30 (3):
Omit the subsection.
Paragraph 30 (5) (a):
Add at end of paragraph `or'.
Paragraph 30 (5) (b):
Omit the paragraph.
Subsection 30 (6):
Omit the subsection.''.

As the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) did, I take this opportunity to thank those honourable members from this side of the Committee who contributed to the debate. I thank the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and the honourable member Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). Some honourable members from the Government side also made worthwhile contributions. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) also contributed. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) made an interesting and well considered contribution, from his point of view, as did the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins).

I listened with interest to the contribution of the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen). Before I address the actual amendments that I moved, I believe it is important that I say, on behalf of the Opposition, that the honourable member for Cowan spoke tripe when she said that it was quite clear that members of the Opposition believed that people did not have the right to vote. Obviously that assertion is totally and utterly untrue. She said also that Opposition members believe in property franchising rather than the adult vote concept. Again that assertion is not true. I take this opportunity to deny those statements. It is fatuous that anyone should make such a claim. The three specific amendments the Opposition is moving as a whole tonight are: the deletion of clause 8 (b), clause 10, and the first four amendments to proposed new subsection 30 of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I point out to the honourable member for Gilmore that in relation to clause 10 the notation is `Opposition to oppose'. It is not actually an amendment.

—That is so. The Opposition is opposing it. The first amendment relating to clause 8 (b) refers specifically to the determination of a valid or invalid vote. We believe that the Government's proposals would confuse the issue rather than clarify it. The Government in clause 8 (b) is seeking to provide:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purpose of ascertaining a voter's intention, regard shall only be had to the word `Yes' or `No' written alone or without words of qualification.

The crucial words there are `written alone or without words of qualification'. We believe that that will lead to possible confusion not only among voters but also among scrutineers who are seeking to ascertain the proper results of a referendum. At present section 24 of the Act reads:
The voting at a referendum shall be by ballot and each elector shall indicate his vote-
(a) if he approves the proposed law-by writing the `Yes' in the space provided on the ballot paper; or
(b) if he does not approve the proposed law-by writing the `No' in the space so provided.
Section 24 lays down specific and clear instructions as to how people are to fill in a vote in a referendum, yet the proposal the Government has put before the chamber states:
For the purposes of ascertaining a voter's intention, regard shall only be had to the word `Yes' or `No' written alone or without words of qualification.

This is an area in which we have a concern. To give an example: if the referendum was, `Do we approve of Queen Elizabeth being the monarch of Australia?', it is possible for a person voting in the referendum to write in the box that asks `Do you approve?' the word `Yes', and next to it the words `God Save the Queen'. If one reads the proposal put forward by the Government containing the words `written alone or without words of qualification', it can be seen that the intent of a person who clearly marks in the box `Do you approve?' the word `Yes' does approve of the Queen remaining the monarch of Australia, but if that person writes next to it `God save the Queen', according to the new proposal, would that vote be invalid.

We believe that the voter's intention is the primary consideration. We say the intention of the voter in the example I gave is quite clear, namely that he approves of Queen Elizabeth remaining the monarch of Australia. We believe, by comparing the present Act with the proposed legislation, that voters who for various reasons want to say something on the ballot paper apart from just putting in the box `Yes' or `No', will invalidate their vote. It may not be that example; a person could vote in approval of a referendum proposal and put beside it `Bob Hawke is a great bloke' or `John Howard is a great bloke'. Because he wrote that beside his vote the vote would be invalid. Yet it is clear from the outset that a person's intention, and what he believes the referendum is all about, is clearly indicated by putting `Yes' or `No' in the box provided. Therefore, we propose to delete that provision.

The second point I raise relates to the 48-hour extension which the Electoral Commissioner will have at his discretion in the event of industrial disputes. The Minister in his second reading speech said:
This will enable the Electoral Commission to extend by 48 hours the time in which acts must be completed in the event of a failure by any person to perform a statutory duty or function.

We believe that that is a complete backdown to industrial muscle, to the union movement. It should be opposed right from the outset. If anybody-whether he is a district returning officer or somebody working in a mailing house or printing shop-tries to interfere in the proper voting or electoral procedures in this nation, he should not be given a second chance, as is indicated by the Government's proposals to extend the actions relating to industrial activity by 48 hours. The Electoral Commission has to be firm and precise and there cannot be any indication of the Government being prepared to move, compromise or back down on this issue. One of the most fundamental issues of our democracy is that elections be carried out in a proper way without industrial action interfering with them, and the same applies to referendums. This is purely and simply complete acquiescence by the Government in relation to industrial action. We do not stand for that sort of thing, and therefore we oppose it.

The third part of our amendments relates to the residential requirements for a person who will be eligible to vote in a referendum. Much has been made of this matter tonight and on previous occasions when this matter has been debated. I make it quite clear that we realise that in this specific legislation we are talking about a referendum and not a general election, but it has been proved since the last general election in July 1987 that there is considerable doubt as to the wisdom of this method of ensuring that people are correctly enrolled in a division of an electorate. In about three weeks time the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters will be reviewing this aspect of the July election. I am sure that in a couple of months time it will be bringing down recommendations. If those recommendations are that the Government should change these residential requirements, we should not accept tonight those residential requirements for referendums. If the Government does not accept our amendments, perhaps in a few months' time the Joint Select Committee will propose a totally different method of ensuring that voters are correctly enrolled. We believe that the wise, sensible decision is to wait until after the Joint Select Committee has carried out its review of residential requirements for enrolment before this provision relating to referendums is included in the legislation.

To sum up, the three points are as follows: on the yes or no vote we believe that the Government's proposal will only confuse the issue rather than clarify it. We believe that the extension by 48 hours for industrial matters is purely a backdown to the union movement. As for the residential requirements, we believe that by far the most sensible and wise thing to do is to wait until after the Joint Select Committee has reported on these matters to see what its recommendations are, so that we do not end up with two totally separate means of identifying voters in their subdivisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition seeks to amend the Bill by deleting paragraph (b) from clause 8. The Government does not accept that. The Opposition says that the paragraph will confuse rather than help the counters of ballot papers because section 24 of the Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: The voting at a referendum shall be by ballot and each elector shall indicate his vote-
(a) if he approves the proposed law-by writing the word ``Yes'' in the space provided on the ballot-paper; or
(b) if he does not approve the proposed law-by writing the word ``No'' in the space so provided.

In view of the Opposition's comment that the Government's proposal will confuse the intent of section 24, I turn to paragraph (b) of clause 8 of the Bill which the Opposition wishes to delete. This provision amends not section 24 but section 93. Section 93 is a separate section and has regard to the formality or informality of ballot papers, which position the Government is seeking to clarify. Clause 8 (b) seeks to add words to the end of certain paragraphs. There are eight criteria in section 93 which qualify formality or informality in the Act. The Government seeks to add a ninth paragraph to the Act, namely:
For the purpose of ascertaining a voter's intention, regard shall only be had to the word `Yes' or `No' written alone or without words of qualification.

How can the combination of section 24 in the original Act, which is not amended in any way, and section 93, as amended by clause 8 of this Bill, cause further confusion? It definitely cannot be confusing.

I refer now to advice I have sought which I can relay to the chamber. The nature of that advice is that prior to the 1984 referendums the Australian Electoral Commission sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department in respect of the formality of certain hypothetical referendum ballot papers, including votes marked with ticks and crosses and with slogans comprising the words `yes' or `no' inside the voting square and a word or words inside or outside the square. The advice supplied, firstly orally, on 29 November 1984 from the Attorney General's Department and confirmed in writing on 21 December 1984 confirmed that section 24, prescribing the method of voting, should be read subject to section 93 (8), which deals with the saving of ballot papers where the voter's intention was clear.

After consideration of the issue of the formality of referendum ballot papers the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform in its report No. 2 of December 1986 recommended that the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act be amended to provide clearly that only unequivocal yes and no answers should be regarded as formal, as set out in recommendation 100. Of course, clause 8 of the Bill does exactly that. We have accepted the Joint Select Committee's recommendation. The purpose of the amendment is to remove any confusion in the mind of the electoral officer as to intention by simply stating unequivocally and without reservation that in ascertaining a voter's intention regard will be had only to the words `yes' or `no' written alone or without words of qualification. So I cannot see how what we intend to do would create further confusion in the mind of the electoral officer because there could be no doubt whatsoever that the combined effect of section 24 and amended section 93 is simply to say that a person writes yes or writes no and nothing else, otherwise the vote shall not be formal. Members of the Opposition can criticise this for being overefficient or overpedantic, but it cannot be criticised on the ground that it will cause further confusion. So we reject what the Opposition has said, and I have to reject the amendment.
The second amendment would delete clause 10 from the Bill. Clause 10 creates a new section to provide for an extension of time to perform certain acts.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could clarify the position, the Opposition is saying that it is opposing that clause, not seeking its withdrawal.

—The Opposition is opposing it; I am saying that we support it. As the honourable member raised the matter during his contribution, I will tell him why he is wrong in opposing it and we are right in supporting it. I want to explain why we have included this clause because I really want the honourable member to accept what I say and agree with me rather than oppose me. Briefly, the proposal to provide an extension of time in which acts must be completed in the event of the unforeseen failure of a person to discharge a statutory duty was put to the Joint Select Committee by the Commission in 1985 following industrial action by divisional returning officers in New South Wales in 1984 which nearly messed up the election. It threatened the progress of the December general election. The Opposition says that by allowing for an extension of time to get over that threat we are actually capitulating to industrial action.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment contained in clause 10 will reduce the effectiveness and therefore the attractiveness of industrial action in a dispute during an election or referendum period by introducing some flexibility into an otherwise concrete situation. So, far from being an acquiescence to industrial muscle, the clause recognises that because the election process would be irretrievably damaged by such action the Commission must be given an opportunity to minimise the disruption by allowing time for its officers to fulfil their duties and, if they have not done so, to restart the process as soon as possible. Once people know that that can happen and know that their industrial action will be ineffective, that will lessen the chance of industrial action taking place. Rather than capitulating to industrial action, we are actually firming up the situation and are signalling that industrial action will not be effective so that the people would not be likely to take it.

On the final point, the third amendment, I understand the Opposition wishes to delete the provisions of the schedule which amend section 30. These amendments are, I understand, designed to delete the requirement that an elector should have resided in the division in which he or she is enrolled at some time in the three months immediately preceding polling day in order to vote in the division. The point has to be made that the three months residence rule as it stands now operates only as an additional test over and above the requirement that a person should have resided in a subdivision for one month before being entitled to enrol for that subdivision. So the residence requirement for enrolment is not to be changed in any way. The amendments will simply make a person's appearance on the role conclusive evidence of his or her entitlement to vote, which is what most people presume to be the case anyway.

The amendment to the Electoral Act was made in 1987 on the unanimous recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. In the course of discussing the issue, the Committee noted that the three months rule is in practical terms incapable of across the board enforcement. It went on:
. . . its operation is anomalous in that it only works to disenfranchise those electors who have not correctly maintained their enrolments, but are honest enough to admit it.
The Committee went on further:

The rule . . . is not an obstacle to fraud or impersonation. Very few electors were ever asked the complex pre 1983 prescribed questions . . . and there is nothing to suggest that any more were asked the sub-section 229 (3) question regarding places of living during the previous 3 months. Any person contemplating fraudulent voting can, without difficulty-
this was before we changed it-
state addresses or make declarations which will not of themselves prevent the admission of the vote.

Finally, real practical difficulties would arise in a joint election referendum if the three months rule were to be retained for referendums only. The most important would be the frustration which would be caused to electors who would be allowed to vote in the election but not in the referendum. Different question would be prescribed to be asked of persons voting at the election and the referendum, and different declarations might also be required. This means that if it is necessary to do this under the Electoral Act, it is now not practical not to do it in the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Bill.

I do hope that those I admit rather technical explanations, but nevertheless necessary explanations-and I have drawn heavily on the report of the Joint Select Committee-will convince the Opposition that there is no need for the chamber to carry its two amendments tonight and that there is no need for those opposite to register their opposition to clause 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are one or two facts of life in relation to elections that I wish to explain. If on Saturday the Liberal and National parties are to win in New South Wales, they will have to get in excess of 52 per cent of the vote. If the Liberal and National parties are to win in this place at the next Federal election--
—Order! I draw the honourable member's attention to the amendments before the Committee.

—I am speaking to the amendments and the reason for the residential requirement. We have to gain 53 per cent of the vote to win government in this place. What I am suggesting, Mr Deputy Chairman, is that your Party-and I am not reflecting on the Chair when I say this-is capable of the most subtle skulduggery when it comes to fiddling the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Labor politicians in this place take a pious approach and pretend that they are standing up in the name of justice, but what they are doing is indulging in one huge fiddle.

SPEECH.PARA: The justification given by the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen), for instance, in her heartrending story about fruit pickers being disenfranchised was absolute rot. The reason that the Government initially introduced the one-month enrolment rule was so that it could shuffle people into those seats in which the margin was close. My friend the former member for Forde, David Watson, won in 1984 by about 45 votes. At the last election he lost the seat. One can be absolutely sure about what was going on. It is no wonder that the Government pushed through that change before the last election. The Australian Labor Party shifted people into the electorate of Forde to ensure that it would get the right result. I am sickened by Labor politicians making their claims in the name of democracy when all that they are indulging in is a more subtle approach than Johannes Bjelke- Petersen, who used to proscribe different zones and was quite open about it. These people opposite do exactly the same, if not worse-in the name of feigned democracy. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) described his speech as technical. I do not really think that it was. It was quite basic. It was a paper that was probably prepared by the Electoral Commission or some other group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is not drawing his remarks to the matters before the Committee. He seems to be ranging far and wide.
—I am listening very carefully to what the honourable member is saying. I draw his attention to the amendments before the Committee, as I did earlier.

—The amendments are wide-ranging. I believe that we on this side asked for our amendments to be taken together so that we did not have to repeat all the points. I am trying to discuss a wider range of issues. I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) for responding to my request for a glass of water so that I can continue to attack his Party. The claims made by the Minister at the table were supposed to be technical, but all that he was doing was parroting some pre-written response to the very legitimate objections that the Opposition holds to this legislation. I see that the Minister is leaving the table to seek some more technical advice. My comments have been fairly uncomplicated. I support what the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), has said. I wonder whether it is true that those on our side of politics were sufficiently naive during the earlier stages of deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which was set up with Senator Robert Ray as its head, to go along with the Labor proposals.
—You could hardly call John Carrick naive.

—John Carrick may well have been so shocked by the subtleties of the Government's approach that Government members misread a shake of his head for approval when it signified disapproval. They have now claimed that the Committee's findings were unanimous. John Carrick was one who, at a very early stage--
—Order! The honourable member will return to the matters before the Committee, which are two amendments.
—We are talking about John Carrick, an ex-senator.
—No, we are not talking about John Carrick. If the honourable member cannot relate his remarks to the two amendments, I will ask him to resume his seat.

—I will return to the two amendments. The 48-hour extension rule is a weak expression of the Government's inability to say, `We can't control the electoral officers. If they want to put on a bluey, to slow down counting or something like that, we will be embarrassed'. It lacks the courage to stand up to people who might be acting in what is almost a gangster-like style. It says, `By adding a couple more days to the time that is required to count postal votes, they will be less likely to take us on'. I say to the Minister that his Party is losing touch. The whole nation is saying that. This is one example of a government that does not have the guts to stand up, but bends at the knees and gives in by amending the legislation. I realise that the Government wants to pass this legislation tonight. I will comply by sitting down and allowing divisions to be called so that we can take our stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to some of the comments made by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron).
—You have had one go.
—Not in the committee stage.
—Order! The honourable member will address her remarks through the Chair.

—The honourable member for Moreton accused as naive people on his side who were members of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and who are on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. —I will. I am saying that there is obviously a pretence in the Liberal Party about the reason for opposing these very valid and necessary changes. —It has nothing to do with the Senate. If Opposition members had any knowledge of politics they would not have to worry about things like getting people on the roll and their residence requirements in order to win an election.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: CYSS Scheme: Wagga Wagga, New South Wales-Western Australian By-Election-Queensland Labor Party-Petrol Pricing

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr West) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform members of the House how the Wagga Wagga community youth support scheme (CYSS) is being politicised. Until recently the project officer was Mr Scott Milne. He has been dismissed by the local management committee, and the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) has advised me that numerous absences from work by Mr Milne, some which he said were without authorisation of the committee, left little alternative. It is interesting to note that Mr Milne was the Australian Democrats candidate for Hume at last year's Federal election. Following Mr Milne's dismissal, Mr Rod Milliken who was the Labor candidate for Hume also at the last election was appointed the executive officer of the project. The Minister has claimed in a letter to me that Mr Milliken's appointment was unrelated to the dismissal of Mr Milne. I am very concerned about the high rate of youth unemployment which prevails in Australia under the Hawke Labor Government and am therefore prepared to support initiatives designed to assist unemployed young people, even some that I consider not to be cost effective. However, I am not prepared to support Government funded programs that are allowed to become political cells of a political party.

SPEECH.PARA: When the events I have referred to were brought to my attention I called for a public inquiry. This has been refused by the Minister. If the Minister for Employment and Education Services was not prepared to establish a properly constituted public inquiry he should have removed Mr Milliken from his newly acquired position or at the very least obtained an assurance from him that he would discontinue his political activities whilst he held that position. Such a position should not be filled by a person actively engaged in political activities. The community youth support scheme is designed to assist young unemployed persons and no government should allow an activity of this kind funded by it even to appear to be politicised. Young people's futures are at risk as a result of the record high youth unemployment I have referred to. Youth work in this field is specialised and only trained and experienced personnel should be employed to direct such a scheme.

The Hawke Government has earned the reputation-this has been highlighted during the last week-of making inappropriate political appointments at the national level, and what I am reporting to the House tonight is clear evidence that this is now being extended to the local level. The Minister in his response to my request for a public inquiry has endorsed the decisions of the Wagga Wagga CYSS committee and has failed dismally to provide a satisfactory explanation for what is taking place. I view this matter seriously. I am concerned that a CYSS scheme in my electorate is being used as a political cell, and I believe that the Government should take immediate action to clear up the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

—I know. The Party could not get anyone to run for the position so it got the wife of a State member. Beattie goes; Goss gets the job. One wonders what will happen next in the Queensland Labor Party. I can tell honourable members what will happen next. The State President of the ALP in Queensland-

When it has done that the balance of power in the Queensland ALP, which is somewhat different from here-the faction divisions in Queensland do not quite relate; they are different--
—What about the--
—I know the honourable member does not understand it.

—If the honourable members opposite knew what the factions were in Queensland they would know where they stood. You know differently in your area, Mr Deputy Speaker. As a consequence of these incredible divisions within the ALP we will see on Saturday a sweeping victory for the Liberal Party in the Brisbane City Council elections. When he does come down here all those other Queensland members had better look out because Beattie will be a darn sight smarter than the rest of them. The ALP has more to risk on Saturday. Not only will it lose, but also it will get the State Secretary of the ALP down here.
—Mr Deputy Speaker--
—What about the price of petrol?

—Yes, the price of petrol again. The Trade Practices Commission is inquiring into the price of petrol in Australia. With some of the things that have happened over the years, it is about time we had a proper inquiry into the activities of the oil companies-not that I am against all oil companies because they provide jobs for many people in Australia. When the price of petrol in Tasmania is compared to the price of petrol in other parts of Australia, not only Tasmanian motorists but all Australians are concerned. With the price variations in the heavy volume areas of Australia, sometimes the price is below the wholesale price. What is the use of having the Prices Surveillance Authority? We may as well get rid of it. It is not worth anything. The former Minister for Consumer Affairs in the Fraser Government, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), would have heard this all before.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether Mr S. Parnell, an organiser for the Transport Workers' Union (TWU), has or had a trustee company of which 98% was owned by TNT executive, Mr J. Doig.
(2) Is he able to say whether the trust bought 2 properties in the early 1980's, neither of which was mortgaged.

(3) Is he also able to say whether (a) Mr Parnell was given a Jaguar car, a boat, and thousands of dollars by transport contractor Mr L. Edwards to secure a beer carting contract, (b) the N.S.W. Secretary of the TWU, Mr H. Quinn, was given 100% complimentary travel from Sydney to Hobart and accommodation at the Wrest Point Hotel Casino and (c) renovations at Mr Quinn's home at Yowie Bay were also paid for by TNT.
(4) Is he able to say whether the Australian Federal Police investigated these matters; if so, what has been the outcome of these investigations.

(5) If the AFP have not investigated these matters, will he pursue the matters further by instituting a wide-ranging Royal Commission similar to that in Victoria which exposed a system of bribes and kickbacks to the Builders Labourers' Federation.
(6) Is the behaviour by Mr Parnell, Mr Edwards, Mr Quinn, and TNT consistent with the Government's aims and objectives of its industrial relations policies.
(7) After having the facts fully ascertained, will he ensure that the Industrial Registrar and other law enforcement officers are informed so that appropriate action might be taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) I do not know whether these statements are correct.
(4) and (5) Allegations along the lines of the matters referred to in parts (1)-(3) of the honourable member's question appeared in the media in 1985 and 1986.

In view of the seriousness of the 1985 allegations, I drew them to the attention of the Attorney-General, the then Special Minister of State, and the Commissioner of Taxation. I was advised by the Ministers and the Commissioner that there was no basis for the Commonwealth to take action in relation to the matters which were the subject of the allegations. The Special Minister of State informed me that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police (``AFP'') had advised him that no breaches of Commonwealth law were involved.

I also referred further allegations which appeared in the media in 1986 to the Attorney-General and the then Special Minister of State. The Attorney-General advised me that there did not appear to be a breach of Commonwealth law involved. The Special Minister of State informed me that the AFP had not been able to proceed with its examination of the allegations because a particular witness could not be located.
Since then, some further information has been given to me, which I have referred to the Minister for Justice and the Attorney-General for consideration as to what further action should be taken.
(6) In the light of the previous answers, I do not consider it necessary or appropriate to make a judgment of this type.
(7) Having regard to the action already taken and the advice provided to us, I do not consider action of this type to be warranted.
